column7: Problem Title: Weather and turblance in urban coordidors for Advanced Air Mobility (AAM) vehicles. Advanced air mobility will lead to more aircraft flying and engaging in vertical takeoff and landing in and around urban corridors where turbulant flows and wind gusts can pose challenges.
column9: Solution Title: Advanced Air Mobility and turbulance shredding or wind gust breaking building artchitecture. Make urban spaces friendlier to flight where architecture of large structures in cities are known to create turbulent wind flows

column1: AEROcAST - Advanced Exploration of Reliable Operation in Low Altitude Meteorology, Simulation, and Technology
column4:
Create a weather sensing, modeling, and reasoning framework for enabling weather tolerant operations
Make urban spaces friendlier to flight where architecture of large structures in cities are known to create turbulent wind flows
Enhanced safety and efficiency of AAM in adverse weather conditions
More efficient vertiport operations
Improved navigation and decreased turbulence in urban environments
Filling the gap of weather observations in the atmospheric boundary layer and better understanding of wind flows in the urban environment
Improved weather forecasts for many applications

column1: BEAM - Wireless Beamed Energy for Advance Air Mobility
column4:
• Build, test, and characterize a prototype 'power- beaming' system intended for aerial wireless power transfer, collection, conversion, and storage of 10 GHz RF to DC energy within the vertiport and Advanced Air Mobility (AAM) airspace.
• Evaluate detrimental impacts, potential benefit to the aircraft system, and functionality.
Does beamed energy impact other systems or
people in a detrimental way (human exposure,
reflected RF interference...)
Is the system scalable and does it provide a net
benefit (cost, operations, safety...)
Can GHz energy be converted efficiently and at
a high enough power to offset on-aircraft energy storage requirements?

column1: AENode - Airports as Energy Nodes
column4:
• Determine how airports can prepare for the future aviation and community energy needs that are
Land area available at thousands of airports for renewable energy harvesting, storage, and/or conversion
Little increase in power distribution infrastructure despite large increase in airport electric power use
Less total energy needed, greatly reduced local emissions
highly uncertain in both timing and energy mix 
• Energy system must be able to provide energy to future aviation users (of which the energy mix is unknown) and local community (whose energy needs and types are evolving)
• Energy must be provided to users at affordable cost to enable adoption with low emissions to reduce environmental impact locally and globally
• Airport energy system upgrade path must be in place at critical locations prior to aviation users arriving, resulting in long payback periods with little/no return
• Airport energy harvesting and distribution must comply with uncertain future regulatory framework
• Airport upgrade path must remain viable with uncertainty in number of aircraft served, preferred energy product, and timing, while also navigating regulatory uncertainty and maintaining positive community impact
column7: Problem Title: Renewable Energy Curtailment Inadequate transmission networks lead to renewable energy congestion and curtailment issues. Without proper transmission infrastructure, a significant amount of energy from renewables can be wasted
column9:
Solution Title: High-altitude pseudo-satellites (HAPS), are high-altitude aircraft designed to bridge the gap between traditional satellites and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs)  These include:Airplanes: High-altitude aircraft that can hold a fixed position or flexible trajectory.
Airships: Aerostatic vehicles that remain aloft through buoyancy or hybrid aerodynamic lifting surfaces. These include non-rigid (blimp/balloon) semi-rigid, and rigid (zeppelin) vehicles

column1: Digital Flight
column4:
Explore a potential new operating mode that uses digital data, processing, and cooperation to empower aviation’s growth. We call it digital flight.
Enabling increasing diversity of flight operations, including highly automated flight
Scaling to high tempos and densities
Improving flight flexibility and predictability
Increasing airspace access and growth with safe operations at scale, digital flight could lead to greater efficiencies, new mission capabilities, and emergent markets for aviation to serve the public.

column1: Data & Reasoning Fabric
column4: create an information infrastructure that can help assemble useful data and reasoning services to provide in-time information to autonomous aircraft for decision making. The intent is to form a connected, interwoven “fabric” of intelligence that sends aircraft specific, tailored information, wherever they are. This infrastructure would enable the vision of a “smart” city and airspace. While this project is focused on future autonomous systems, DRF could even be applied to traditional transport systems.

column1: SABERS - Solid-state Architecture Batteries for Enhanced Rechargeability and Safety
column4: Develop a solid-state bipolar battery stack based on novel Li-S/Se chemistry and a non- flammable solid state electrolyte (SSE) to produce a battery which satisfies the system level needs of urban air mobility (UAM) concepts including: safety (non flammable), energy density, discharge rate, packaging design, and scalability.

column1: SPARRCI - Sensor-based Prognostics to Avoid Runaway Reactions & Catastrophic Ignition
column4:
Improve safety of existing batteries + accelerate adoption of next- generation batteries
Battery Failure Analysis
• Off-nominal material morphology studies
• In-situ imaging for fault precursor
• Post-cycling analysis to correlate sensor/NDE results
Sensor Development
• Embedded miniature sensors for real-time state-of-health monitoring within cells
• Multifunctional parameter measurements
Nondestructive Evaluation
• In-situ and off-line monitoring techniques
• Battery health data without damage
• Advanced modeling & analysis
Fault Algorithms & Machine Learning
• Multiphysics modeling for off-nominal operation
• Fault algorithm + failure prognostics
• “Smart” battery management
• Advanced state-of-health and hazard detection
 •Actionable warnings during off-nominal events to prevent catastrophic
failures
•Improved aircraft performance & enhanced reliability

column1: SUSAN - Subsonic Single Aft Engine
column4:
The  SUSAN Electrofan Aircraft is a subsonic regional jet transport aircraft concept which utilizes Electrified Aircraft Propulsion (EAP) to enable propulsive and aerodynamic benefits to reduce fuel usage, emissions, and cost.  
Transformative concept: single engine transport aircraft.  Five decades later we still have not achieved single engine transport
The target market is the regional low cost carrier airline with mission specification: 180 passenger, design range of 2500 miles, economic range of 750 miles, speed of Mach 0.78.
Additionally develop the capability to accelerate ground and flight demonstration through workforce development and Small Business Innovation Research

column1: SWIFT - Accelerating and Enabling Novel Flight Research
column4:
How can NASA conduct flight research more often and more cost effectively? 
What new research can be enabled by high risk flight test opportunities? 
Can we save on cost and schedule with a modular and reusable architecture that utilizes flight proven hardware and software?
A cost-effective, aircraft research architecture that enables rapid flight research and has a flexible risk posture to evaluate novel technologies

column1: MISTRAL - Multiscale Intelligent System for TRAcking & Localization of Emissions
column4:
Persistent monitoring and localization radically curtails release of GHG at large oil-and-gas production sites and other focused release areas because many emissions are due to failure in equipment, such as leaks and undetected cessation of burn-off.
Inform emittersand enable optimal solution to GHG emission: prevention at the source.
Dynamic: No expensive ground installations; no cost of dismantling; in place on time.
Versatile: Handle a broad range of emitters, human-made and natural; operate at optimal proximity; autonomous system uses state-of-the-art components. Develop affordable, ecologically sustainable, persistent, multiscale, autonomous airborne system for monitoring and localization of emissions over large areas of heterogeneous emitters, with primary focus on oil and gas production sites, such as the Permian Basin, with the area of 86,000 mi2.

column1: SPRUCE - Sustainably-powered Planetary RejUvenation via Carbon Entrapment
column4:
Enabling a sustainably powered scalable GHG sequestration system that can be implemented onto aircraft for direct air capture
• Sustainably capture C using renewable energy.
• Use renewable energy, minimal water, and sunlight to generate a beneficial product
• Solution can be implemented quickly and in stages achieving fast impact
• Address stationary, dynamic, and emergent emitters including those that arise from
human-made or natural disasters.

column1: SUMAC - Sustainable Manufacturing of Aircraft
column4:
Aircraft manufacturers need sustainably-derived thermoplastic composites in order to build environmentally-friendly aircraft considering full lifecycle so that the environmental impact of commercial air transport is reduced.
Identify candidate fiber materials
Determine environmental impact of agricultural burden
Identify target application space
Define best qualified organizations to perform each research thrust

column1: AirMed
column4:
Over 75% of all Medicare Air Transports are in rural communities but patients can wait sometimes days for interfacility transfer and transportation. Transient healthcare specialists in urban centers routinely spend more than 4 hours of "windshield" time getting to rural areas to see patients. In X1, AirMed is exploring how aviation can improve patient and provider transportation in rural areas. We are hoping to collaborate with a broad range of stakeholders from Tribal Nations, Pueblos, and municipalities in NW and central New Mexico. Possible solutions currently being explored with stakeholders include:
Integrated Smart System for Patient Transfer and Transportation
AAM Vehicle Design to Support Medical Needs
Remote Monitoring & Diagnostic Assessment of Patients
Preparation for and Application of AAM in NW New Mexico

column1: Aerial AID
column4:
Emergency medical responders are overburdened and lack situational awareness of medical scenes. Scene descriptions are limited and often reduced to a “game of telephone” between the caller, the dispatcher, and the response personnel. ​Develop nominal data set and corresponding perception engine for medical UAS use-cases, informed by government and industry partners​

Develop framework for state-of-the-art perception capabilities to be successfully applied to emergency medical UAS use-cases, including transfer learning to enhance state of the art object detection tools​

Integrate cutting-edge assurance research into framework for edge case detection and runtime monitoring​

​

column1: Battery Pack Modelling
column4: Battery Pack Modelling Proposal Electro-Chemical & Structural-Thermal pack modelling proposal for TTT / Green Aviation Call, 2023 1) Problem, Objectives, Approach, and Anticipated Benefits: Many of novel aircraft concepts include some degree of electrification to reduce carbon footprint. To date, the battery models that have been able to be incorporated into NASA aircraft preliminary design studies such as the quadrotor0F 1 have been cell-level models1F 2, with knockdown factors for pack-level effects. There is an interest from EPFD, TTT, AATT, and other projects, in being able to more accurately model and optimize pack-level structural and thermal effects in addition to the cell-level effects. However, to date, there was no clear path on how this could be accomplished while still being compatible with cutting edge gradient-based aircraft optimization tools like OpenMDAO2F 3 and Aviary3F 4. The objective of this research proposal is to create an open-source battery pack model that includes cell electro-chemical effects as well as pack-level structural-thermal effects. The resulting model will be differentiable to ensure compatibility with OpenMDAO and Aviary. Our approach is to create a multi-center team and use open-source tools that we are already familiar with to create a system-level battery pack design. Figure 1 shows an Extended Design Structure Matrix (XDSM) diagram that details of how each of the component disciplines fits together to make the overall battery-pack model. In Figure 1, Discharge curves from cell-tests are input into the cell electro-chemical model which allows for the configuration of the parameters of the cell and later analysis. The cell electro-chemical effects based on models from ProgPy4F 5. A CAD model of the pack (multiple cells) is then created and imported along with the number of packs into the structural-thermal model TACS5F 6. The TACS software performs structural analysis to evaluate the mass of the pack as well as configure parameters for use later in the analysis. At this point the battery pack will be run through a sample mission which will primarily consist of pulling a specified quantity of amps at a particular voltage from the system over a given amount of time. During the mission, the cell electro-chemical model will keep track of the state of charge and voltage of the cells. TACS will keep track of the temperature throughout the pack subject to the heat produced by each cell and a assuming a constant cooling flow. Figure 2 (left) shows an example compliant battery pack designed and (right) a TACS structural-thermal pack model. Both of these models were designed by team members on this proposal. 1 E. Hendricks, E. Aretskin-Hariton, D. Ingraham, J. Gray, S. Schnulo, J. Chin, R. Falck, and D. Hall, “Multidisciplinary Optimization of an Electric Quadrotor Urban Air Mobility Aircraft,” in Aiaa 2020 aviation forum, 2020. 2 J. C. Chin, E. Aretskin-Hariton, D. Ingraham, D. Hall, S. L. Schnulo, J. S. Gray, and E. Hendricks, “Battery Evaluation Profiles for X-57 and Future Urban Electric Aircraft,” in Aiaa propulsion and energy forum, , 2020. 3 J. S. Gray, J. T. Hwang, J. R. R. A. Martins, K. T. Moore, and B. A. Naylor, “OpenMDAO: An Open-Source Framework for Multidisciplinary Design, Analysis, and Optimization,” Structural and Multidisciplinary Optimization, 2019. 4 Aviary will be a preliminary design tool for aircraft capable of modeling traditional and novel designs. This tool is built on top of OpenMDAO and will be Open Source and will provide easy-to-follow examples that will support both analysis and optimization. Aviary is scheduled for public release in December of 2024. 5 C. Teubert, K. Jarvis, M. Corbetta, C. Kulkarni, P. Banerjee, M. Daigle, ProgPy Python Prognostics Packages, v1.5, May 2023. URL nasa/progpy. doi: 10.5281/ZENODO.8097013 6 Kennedy, G. J. and Martins, J. R. R. A, "A parallel finite-element framework for large-scale gradient-based design optimization of high-performance structures", Finite Elements in Analysis and Design, 2014, doi:http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.finel.2014.04.011 Figure 1, XDSM of Battery Pack Subsystems Figure 2, LEFT: CAD pack model, RIGHT: TACS Structural-Thermal Pack Model Benefits of this work would include creating a higher-fidelity battery pack model that can be used in aircraft system-level optimization by AATT, EPFD, TTT and other projects. This will enable better understanding of the trade-space for electrified aircraft studies. Additionally, by open sourcing the model and publishing a paper on it, this will provide other researchers in government, academia and industry with an understanding of how they can use the same methods to create their own higher fidelity battery pack models. 2) Milestones and how to Evaluate Success: • January 2024 – CAD Battery pack model completed • April 2024 – Cell electro-chem model input constraints narrowed to decrease multimodality of solution space. • April 2024 – Demonstrate TACS successfully ingesting CAD pack model and producing weights. • July 2024 – Overall pack subsystem linked together, and first optimization / analysis run. Preliminary paperwork filed for open-source release. SciTech 2025 abstract submitted. • September 2024 – Battery pack optimization completed. Optimization will vary wall thickness in one or more parts of the pack model. The optimization objective will be minimum mass while completing the mission objective based on a pre-determined voltage and amperage draw. Repository is released open source. 3) Next Steps and Areas for Transition: Completion of this work through open-source code release and publishing in SciTech 2025 would immediately enable TTT, AATT, and EPFD projects to use the pack-level model created to investigate specific battery pack and cell chemistries for electrified aircraft studies like the TTBW. This is a higher level of fidelity than they can currently achieve with the cell-only models that currently exist. Additionally, academic partners like U. Michigan, Georgia Tech, and Iowa State, could immediately take the models created from this work and integrate them into their electrified aircraft studies that they perform on an ongoing basis using simplified battery models. Further work would need to be performed in order to parameterize the pack-model into something that could handle changing the number of cells inside the pack without engineer input. CAD modelling of the pack, while useful for an initial design, is a time-consuming process that parametrization should help to simplify. Additionally, parameterization enables the optimizer to trade battery pack design for other aspects of the aircraft like thermal system mass and wing volume. 4) Challenge Scenario In the case where a subset of the analysis was infeasible, (i.e. if ProgPy was not capable of supplying the cell electro-chemical models but the other aspects of the thermal-structural analysis were working well,) we would use one of our other cell models or create a new cell model as a substitute. This scenario has happened multiple times in the past with other projects and we have been successful at finding substitute models. In the case where the entire approach was invalid, we could shift our focus to leveraging an already working battery cell model and enhancing it with better pack-level estimates for weight. While this would not be as thorough as analyzing the full structural-thermal system, it would still provide for increased fidelity which will provide useful for aircraft design studies. Regardless of what challenges appear before the team during this work, the entire team will be involved in the decision-making process of how to pivot and still create useful advancements in battery pack modelling for electrified aircraft design.

column1: Effects of Atmospheric Conditions and Sustainable Fuels on Contrail Radiative Forcing
column4:
1
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT
FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL
Title: Effects of Atmospheric Conditions and Sustainable Fuels on Contrail Radiative Forcing
1. Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated
benefits).
Executive summary
Contrails create about two-thirds of aviation’s contribution to climate change. To guarantee the success
of contrail mitigation strategies such as flight altitude changes, the sensitivity of contrail optical depth to
atmospheric parameters must be quantified with the associated uncertainty. Additionally, impact from
both SAF and hydrogen needs to be studied: Are future aviation fuels more or less prone to contrails?
We address these concerns by applying modeling, simulation, and uncertainty quantification (UQ) to
contrails to assess and reduce the aviation’s impact on global warming.
What problem are you solving?
Current estimates of the
anthropogenic radiative forcing (RF)
due to aviation are crippled by a very
high level of uncertainty. This
uncertainty comes from non-CO2
processes in the formation and
persistence of contrails[1]. To address
it rigorously, the influence of the local
atmospheric conditions (which are
only known up to a certain degree of
confidence from weather models)
must be propagated through contrail
simulations. Similarly, the effect of the
chemical composition of the jet exhaust gas (also a large source of uncertainty) must be factored in to
enable predictions for different types of engines and fuels, such as SAF and H2, and unconventional aircraft
technologies, such as Quesst. Eventually, we aim to predict the optical properties of the contrails and the
related confidence interval, given uncertain inputs.
Has someone tried to solve this problem before? If no one has attempted to solve this problem
before, why not?
Large Eddy Simulation (LES) of contrails has been performed in several research groups (reviewed in [2]).
The current state-of-the-art methodologies can handle contrails from conventional airplanes using regular
jet fuels. To alleviate computational cost, contrail simulations typically use a time-developing framework,
where the streamwise direction of the flow is replaced by periodicity conditions. Assuming Galilean
invariance, the simulation is performed in a moving frame with a constant translation speed equal to the
free stream velocity.
Figure 1: Spatially developing wake simulation using VPM [3]. 
2
Where did they go wrong?
1. No formal quantification of the uncertainty has been performed to date. At most, simple parametric
studies have been conducted [4].
2. Only few works have simulated contrails from SAF [5], and virtually none from H2. There is a need to
improve simulation codes and models so they can handle situations with fewer aerosols and/or soot
particles which in turn affect the nucleation and growth of ice particles.
3. The effect of the time-developing assumption on the simulation results has never been quantified.
However, it impedes physical processes that involve axial velocities (since they are not Galilean
invariant). Consequences on the mixing in the plume and the ensuing contrail RF must be studied.
What is different about your approach? How does your proposed work transform current
capabilities, tools/methods or state-of-the art approaches?
Our simulations will address the above shortcomings as follows:
1. Use of QUEST (NASA UQ software) to propagate uncertainty through the simulations.
2. Use of a Lagrangian super particle approach to deal with the microphysics of ice nucleation in a variety
of environments, with different concentration of aerosols/soot particles and diverse background
conditions (humidity, temperature, stratification, etc.), specifically targeting the microphysics of SAF
and H2 contrails.
3. Use of a Vortex Particle-Mesh (VPM) approach to perform regular space developing simulations (as
opposed to time-developing) at a moderate computational cost (Figure 1) and quantify the model
error associated with the time-developing assumption by comparing with regular LES performed with
the code NTMIX.
In these efforts we will collaborate with Stanford Univ. (Dr. Tania Ferreira, Prof. Catherine Gorle, Prof.
Juan Alonso) and Poly. Montreal (Prof. Roberto Paoli) to cross-validate our simulations and models.
If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable?
Our simulation results will lead to parameterizations and surrogate models based on machine learning
(ML) techniques trained on our simulation results. Such models can then be used to improve climate
models and devise efficient contrail mitigation strategies (see sect.3).
Potential customers: FAA, airframe and engine manufacturers, policy planners, etc.
2. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion.
# Description Exit criteria
1 Generate high-fidelity LES of aircraft wakes in a stratified
atmosphere + engine exhaust vapor depositing onto ice
crystals (NTMIX code).
Code working and validated
against canonical benchmark.
2 Incorporate stratification and engine vapor into a VPM
method for rapid predictions. Perform spatially developing
simulations using VPM and compare with the time-developing
LES results.
Code working and validated
against canonical benchmark.
Time-developing model error
quantified.
3 Vary ambient stratification, temperature, humidity,
atmospheric turbulence, and fuel type. Use UQ to sample the
parameter space and obtain uncertainty bounds.
LES and VPM results compared
and validated against
observations (e.g., ND-MAX).
3
4 Extract a parametrization/surrogate of contrail optical depth
versus the atmospheric parameters for each fuel.
Model available as a set of
equations or a numerical
implementation.
5 Analyze uncertainty with respect to the aerosol content and
ice nucleation modes of hydrogen/SAF combustion
Study ready to be
published/disseminated.
3. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? Where are the potential
areas for transition? What follow-on research do you anticipate?
• Our parameterization should be implemented in global circulation models to better quantify the nonCO2 impact of aviation on climate change and the related uncertainty.
• Air traffic trajectory should be optimized under uncertainty. Mitigating non-CO2 effects is challenging
because it usually increases direct CO2 effects. Efficient strategies should use the information about
uncertainty from our models to target the operational adaptations that have the highest likelihood of
making a positive overall impact. This connects with the transition goals of ATM-X.
• Future research should focus on reducing the uncertainty in the inputs to our models. One example
is the predicted humidity at high altitude, which will require refinement of current weather simulation
and forecasting methods.
4. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation: Three months
into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach
is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot? What
alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?
Let us first note that:
• Two independent simulation codes will be used: NTMIX and VPM. This mitigates the risk since it is
highly unlikely that neither will work for the intended problem. Both codes have been used in the past
for similar problems.
• If UQ does not work with QUEST, other software can be used such as DAKOTA.
• If ML does not work for the parameterization (e.g., because too much data is required to train the
model), we can rely on more conventional method for surrogate modeling such as kriging.
In the unlikely event that the initial approach is unfeasible because none of the simulation codes work,
we could redirect the focus of this project in several ways. For example:
• Contrails can only persist in the atmosphere in ice super-saturated regions (ISSR). Predicting the
position and spatial extent of these ISSR is notoriously difficult. We could work on improving the
modeling of ISSR using a combination of numerical weather predictions, observational data, and
machine learning.
• The interaction between a contrail, the ensuing contrail cirrus, and natural cirrus clouds is not well
understood. We could work on improving ice/mixed cloud modeling using Lagrangian capabilities like
those we envisioned for the proposed work.
References:
[1] D.S. Lee, D.W. Fahey, A. Skowron, et al., The contribution of global aviation to anthropogenic climate forcing for 2000 to 2018, Atmospheric
Environment, Volume 244, 117834, 2021.
[2] Paoli, R. & Shariff, K. Contrail Modeling and Simulation, Annual Review of Fluid Mechanics, 48:393-427, 2015.
[3] D.-G. Caprace, Modeling of lifting-dragging devices for large eddy simulation of space-developing wakes: application to wings, rotors and
formation flight. PhD thesis, Universite Catholique de Louvain, 2020.
[4] Unterstrasser, S. and Gierens, K.: Numerical simulations of contrail-to-cirrus transition – Part 1: An extensive parametric study, Atmos.
Chem. Phys., 10, 2017–2036, 2010.
[5] Voigt, C., Kleine, J., Sauer, D. et al. Cleaner burning aviation fuels can reduce contrail cloudiness. Commun Earth Environ 2, 114, 2021.

Title: True Zero Emission Closed Turbogenerator For A Universal Electric Aircraft Powertrain

benefits). Address any or all the following questions (if relevant):
a. What problem are you solving? Zero-emission scalable quiet aircraft propulsion
b. Has someone tried to solve this problem before? Yes, but with fuel cells,
batteries, and hydrogen turbofans.
c. Where did they go wrong? Fuel cells and batteries are too heavy. Turbofans
still produce greenhouse gas emissions (NOx, pm, contrails).
d. What is different about your approach? We use a newly invented Closed
Strayton Quad Generator that is more efficient and lighter than fuel cells. It is a
drop-in replacement for turbofans in any aircraft that needs zero-emission
performance while supporting a variety of fuel options.
e. If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not? Closed Brayton
systems have been developed in the past for space missions but were not
practical for aircraft until the recently developed high power electric motors
became available.
f. How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools/methods or
state-of-the art approaches? This technology provides a Green Aviation Zero
Emission net system fuel burn reduction benefit of 50% according to a recent
University of Michigan study.
g. If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is
unattainable? Please include references/citations to back up claims where
appropriate. This technology enables zero emission aircraft without
compromising safety or range. It was selected AIAA Aviation EATS Conference
Best Paper, “True Zero Emission Electric Aircraft Technologies”, AIAA 2023-3987.
It enables a common EAP architecture as shown in Fig.1 and Fig.2 that can save
at least 30% fuel burn with a multi-fuel zero-emission power generator as shown
in Fig. 3. The University of Michigan Institute of Sustainable Aviation (MISA) also
completed this study, “Conceptual Design Studies of Zero Emission Electric

a manufacturing company in the Cleveland area.

demonstrated, replaces fuel cells, batteries, and turbofans in future green
aviation electric aircraft.
