column1: Improved Propulsion Airframe Integration (PAI) Simulations for Design, Analysis and Optimization of Both Airframe and Propulsor
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT 

FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE 

Title: Improved Propulsion Airframe Integration (PAI) Simulations for Design, Analysis and Optimization of Both Airframe and Propulsor 

Description of the work  

Propulsion Airframe Integration (PAI) at NASA is inadequate for addressing subsonic transport Mach numbers and higher, as well as distortion for blades with a lot of twist consistent of typical high bypass ratio turbofans for relatively quick design-study or optimization types of runs.  PAI capability for design understanding is critical for getting improved performance of aircraft and to meet key sustainability goals of NASA. The current codes have actuator disk capability for steady simulations which are inadequate or have the ability to run time accurate with rotating blades installed but require thousands of CPUs and thousands of CPU/GPU hours to run.   

The Sustainable Flight Demonstrator (SFD), a TTBW configuration is designated as the X-66A as shown on the left of Figure 1.  It consists of a Pratt and Whitney Geared Turbofan.  That configuration can be simulated under existing cruise conditions using existing NASA CFD tools where the propulsor can be modeled as either an actuator disk or with appropriate boundary condition at the Nacelle inlet and exhausts.  Crosswind configurations or very high angles of attack will be more difficult or not possible with those same tools.  On the right of Figure 1 is the Open Fan concept engine that GE is currently developing in their partnership with CFM International.  Having this architecture engine on the TTBW and simulating with existing NASA tools would not produce an accurate description of the interaction unless one spent months getting one unsteady result.  This capability is not only lacking at NASA, but in the industry as well.  Improved PAI simulation capability that can be done relatively quickly can allow for reduced fuel burn through modifications of the propulsor and airframe at the same time. 

A blue and white airplane

Description automatically generated with low confidence A black and white spider

Description automatically generated with medium confidence 

Figure 1.  On the left is the TTBW in X-66A configurationwith the turbofans with Nacelles.  On the right is the GE RISE concept OpenFan (image from CFM International).  

  

Two NASA codes are widely used for Aircraft Simulation: FUN3D developed out of NASA Langley, and LAVA developed out of NASA Ames.  The proposed approach would be valid for both codes but would be explored with this TTT effort first using FUN3D.  The approach is to use volumetric source terms as well as the physical blockage to represent the impact of the propulsor (fan, Open Fan, or Propellor) rotor on the steady and stationary flowfield (the rotor effects are smeared out).  The physical blockage is known from the thickness distributions of the blades and their stagger angle.  The source terms would first come from current unsteady solutions and then from first-principal models that have been developed by others and can be improved by propulsion experts, AI (trained from unsteady simulations), and using test data. 

 

Currently, FUN3D has an excellent actuator model [1] shown in Fig 2.  It allows for circumferential variations in flow quantities and is adjoint capable.  The method uses a low-speed blade element theory and does not account for the propulsor blockage.  LAVA has actuator disk capability, a volumetric source term capability but without blockage, and without production adjoint capability.   

 

 

Figure 2.  Actuator Disk capability in FUN3D shown for PEGASUS concept [1].  

 

Rod Chima retired from NASA and had added a source term and blockage capability to his turbomachinery code, SWIFT [2].  This code is structured multi-block, is not in active use at NASA, and was not applied to aircraft.  It was used for turbomachinery only.  

 

The volume sources with blockage terms are outlined in a paper by Xie and Uranga [3] and the equations below come from this paper.  This method builds on work by David Hall in his MIT PhD work but added the blockage terms.  The blockage term, b, represents the blade thickness in the circumferential direction, 
𝜃
𝜃
 
, and by the number of blades, B, and is defined by  

 

and the equations of motion have the added source terms f in the momentum and energy equation: 

 

These equations are implicit in the code, APNASA, but those terms come a different model.   

 

For this proposal, the source terms will come first from averaging (in time) the time dependent solution of an undistorted propulsor and a distorted propulsor.  The distorted propulsor will be the BLI2DTF case [4,5] that has been run experimentally and for which a Turbo [6] has been used coupled with LAVA.  Following that, the source terms will come from the models outlined in references [2,3].  Turbo will be used to demonstrate the source terms and to implement the blockage terms since it is a simpler code than FUN3D and is used extensively for Turbomachinery simulations at NASA. 

 

Another key aspect is that T-Blade3 [7], a turbomachinery geometry generator, will be used to define the geometry of the propulsor including the camber line, thickness and then the entire 3D turbomachinery blade.  It has been effectively used at NASA and for NASA applications since 2015. It is parametric and fully differentiated so applicable for eventual adjoint-enabled optimization. 

 

Describe the anticipated milestones  

The following work tasks are proposed.  Each task completion would be a low or higher level milestone. 

Add blockage terms to Turbo by GRC Aeromechanics group 

demonstration using TURBO for BLI2DTS case.  The source terms come from very careful averaging of the unsteady simulation 

demonstration using TURBO with Spacefan* with and without blockage terms 

Model source terms in TURBO with basic loss model and knowing geometry and rpm 

use source terms (without blockage terms) with Fun3D for spacefan and compare to Turbo without blockage terms 

Define the changes needed in FUN3D for blockage terms 

Define geometry integration with T-Blade3 and Fun3D with loss and turning model 

Outline 2nd year efforts 

Each of these tasks would be done to demonstrate capability and not be done with the most rigor necessary for complete understanding.  Tasks 1 will require modifications of the TURBO source code as well as adding the source terms to Turbo.  Source terms input into FUN3D would require a small change of source code in FUN3D. 

*   The Spacefan case is a convenient low-speed ventilation fan designed for the ISS.   

 

Next Steps 

The following tasks would be necessary after the first year: 

Add blockage terms to the equations of motion in FUN3D. 

Demonstrate a low speed wing with a propeller with source terms 

Use adjoint to modify the wing spanwise with effect of propeller 

Choose a test case such as TTBW with OpenFan to demonstrate full capability. 

Alternative approaches?  

Since many of the steps have already been done in other contexts, the biggest risk to this approach is the aggressiveness of the schedule.  It would be focused more after a detailed assessment is done for each of the tasks. 

References: 

Ordaz, Irian, Li Wang and Eric J. Nielsen, “Design of a Distributed Propulsion Concept Using an Adjoint-Based Approach and Blade Element Theory to Minimize Power,” AIAA Aviation, AIAA paper 2020-2632, June, 2020. 

Rodrick V. Chima, “Rapid Calculations of Three-Dimensional Inlet / Fan Interaction,” Presented at the NASA Fundamental Aeronautics 2007 Annual Meeting, Oct. 30 – Nov. 1, 2007, New Orleans, LA. 

Tianbo Xie and Alejandra Uranga. “Development and Validation of Non-Axisymmetric Body-Force Propulsor Model,” AIAA 2020-3686. AIAA Propulsion and Energy 2020 Forum, Aug. 2020. 

Arend, David J., John D. Wolter, Stefanie M. Hirt, Andrew Provenza, John A. Gazzaniga, William T. Cousins, Larry W. Hardin, and Om Sharma. "Experimental evaluation of an embedded boundary layer ingesting propulsor for highly efficient subsonic cruise aircraft." In 53rd AIAA/SAE/ASEE Joint Propulsion Conference, p. 5041, 2017. 

Mark L. Celestina and Mary J. Long-Davis, “Large-scale Boundary Layer Ingesting Propulsor Research,” ISABE-2019-24264. 

Heinlein, Gregory & Chen, Jenping & Bakhle, Milind. (2020). Aerodynamic Behavior of a Coupled Boundary Layer Ingesting Inlet – Distortion Tolerant Fan. 10.2514/6.2020-3780. 

Sharma, Mayank and Mark G. Turner, “Continuous Modified NACA Four-Digit Thickness Distribution for Turbomachinery Geometries,” AIAA Journal, Vol 59, No. 4, April 2021, https://doi.org/10.2514/1.J060023.

column1: Technical and economic trade study on using Photo-and-Photovoltaic-Batteries in Tandem with conventional or novel LH2 for long-haul (inter-continental) flights.
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT
FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE
INSTRUCTIONS
Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name.
Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger.
Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission
and do not need to be addressed in this template.
RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW
Title: Technical and economic trade study on using Photo-and-Photovoltaic-Batteries in
Tandem with conventional or novel LH2 for long-haul (inter-continental) flights.
1. Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated
benefits). Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant): What problem are you
solving? Has someone tried to solve this problem before? Where did they go wrong? What
is different about your approach? If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why
not? How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools/methods or stateof-the art approaches? If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is
unattainable? Please include references/citations to back up claims where appropriate.
Green aviation faces multiple challenges (technical, processing, resources, and economic). To realize this
vision, the aviation industry needs to solve various parts (energy storage, propulsion, supply chain,
recyclability, and safety) of the puzzle. Short-haul flights could be solved using battery technology alone,
it is unlikely that long-haul or intercontinental flights would be able to run on battery technology in the
foreseeable future. There are a few alternative ideas proposed in the literature such as sustainable aviation
fuel (SAF), hydrogen propulsion, fuel cells, and hybrid electric vehicles, however, each of these faces its
own technical, economic, and climate challenges.
Any hybrid solution will require a separate battery to store energy, in addition to any backup or auxiliary
systems. In such cases, the battery will occupy precious volume and mass in an aircraft. In addition, these
batteries will need to be quickly recharged at an airport since other fuels require less turnaround time. This
leads to two possible solutions, either fast charging at the destination or charging during the cruise portion
of the flight (which is also the low-power portion of the flight). One possible solution is a photon or a
photovoltaic battery, such a combined solution could reduce weight, use amble solar energy above the cloud
cover, and charge the battery during flight. Note that NASA has envisioned solar cell-driven aircraft with
Helios and Pathfinder in the past, but these efforts were limited to unmanned aircraft. Thus, some of the
techniques and technologies can be leveraged. One of the major shortcomings of a solar cell (apart from
low efficiency) is that it must be connected to a battery or other energy storage device, or a micro-grid to
store/distribute the electricity it generates.
For this project, we propose a high-level techno-eco-sustainability study to investigate the potential benefit
of combining energy storage and photovoltaics into a single integrated solution. However, a combination
of these technologies is in a nascent stage with some explored integration ideas [1], choosing a
photosensitive material as an electrode or putting a PV or a battery as an integrated package (Fig. 1), for
combining photovoltaics with batteries. One of the challenges is that the efficiency of a combined system
is about 10%, significantly lower than a single junction (about 20% [2]), as well as current state-of-the-art
multi-junction devices (the maximum efficiency is greater than 45%). Another approach that is being
developed is to use persistent phosphor for "Photon Energy-Storage". Here the photon energy is thermal
energy, which can be converted through an electrochemical or a photovoltaic route.
Figure 1: Different photo-charging techniques: a) closed system, b) integrated solution.
The research in developing a technology can be significant and it is often necessary to develop trade-offs
to venture into a new technology that is still nascent. Here we propose to perform a techno-economicenvironmental impact to understand the practicality of pursuing improving either technology while,
performing the life-cycle-assessment of materials used in the technology and its environmental impact
during the materials life-process (extraction, processing, reuse capability).
Developing a trade study from a material, technology, recyclable, integration, supply chain, and greenness
in addition to the viability of a novel technology can provide a good decision tool for new technologies.
For this study, we will investigate the viability of photon-thermal/electrochemical energy conversion and
storage for electric aviation.
a) b)
The work will focus on three aspects: 1) Safety, a combination of volatile electrolytes, and low
melting point materials with photovoltaics could generate heat that could be catastrophic. A simple
thermal analysis will be performed to identify safety risks; 2) techno-economic-recyclability, using
the Circular Economy Modeling and Analysis tool [3] from NREL will be used to perform
technical, economic, and recyclability of technology and supply chains. Lastly, Environmental
Sustainability: A comparative LCA with a cradle-to-gate approach will be performed using
NREL’s GREET (The Greenhouse Gases, Regulated Emissions, and Energy use in Technologies
Model) software [4]. The platform evaluates the material and energy flows for battery and
photovoltaic materials from raw material extraction to device production.
2. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon
completion.
The study is divided into 3 parts and will have 3 milestones: 1) weight benefits should exceed 20%,
while safety should be similar or better than a hybrid system; 2) techno-economic-recyclability,
material availability and recyclability should be like the hybrid system; 3) LCA analysis should reveal
the complete life-cycle reduces carbon emissions (or carbon costs) similar to the hybrid system.
3. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? Where are the
potential areas for transition? What follow-on research do you anticipate?
If the trade-study reveals that either photon or a photo battery is beneficial to either hybrid-aircraft or
future electric aviation focused airports, then the next step would be to work on identifying technology
bottlenecks and solving them from a material or performance perspective. For (hypothetical) example,
if photo battery was found viable for hybrid-aircraft, next step would be to focus on improving energy
conversion efficiency, changing material to provide higher voltages, or charging rate of these photobatteries. Since this is a trade study, if viable it would also allow us to focus on infrastructural, material
processing, device optimization, system optimization, or improving material efficiency.
4. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation: Three
months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial
proposed approach is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining,
how do you pivot? What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?
It is unlikely that a trade-study reveals nothing, since by nature the goal of it is to identify feasibility on
various fronts. But if the project’s outcome is that either photon or a photo battery is beneficial, the
next step would be to focus on the technological challenge for the rest of the year. However, if it was
found that neither of them would be reasonable either from an economic or safety perspective, then
depending on the barrier, if it is the battery coupling, then solar cell could be explored for generating
O2 and H2 for a fuel cell. However, if solar cell is found limiting, then the framework for feasibility
study environmental friendly cradle-to-grave analysis for materials and process for batteries and fuelcells are developed which could be used to apply to other challenging studies.
References:
[1] Y. Yang, M.T. Hoang, A. Bhardwaj, M. Wilhelm, S. Mathur, H. Wang, Perovskite solar cells based
self-charging power packs: Fundamentals, applications and challenges, Nano Energy. 94 (2022)
106910. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nanoen.2021.106910.
[2] L. Zhu, M. Zhang, J. Xu, C. Li, J. Yan, G. Zhou, W. Zhong, T. Hao, J. Song, X. Xue, Z. Zhou, R.
Zeng, H. Zhu, C.-C. Chen, R.C.I. MacKenzie, Y. Zou, J. Nelson, Y. Zhang, Y. Sun, F. Liu, Singlejunction organic solar cells with over 19% efficiency enabled by a refined double-fibril network
morphology, Nat. Mater. 21 (2022) 656–663. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41563-022-01244-y.
[3] S. Ovaitt, H. Mirletz, NREL/PV_ICE: v0.2.1 Solar Futures and PV ICE Journal Release, (2021).
https://doi.org/10.5281/ZENODO.5659151.
[4] R.K. Iyer, J.C. Kelly, Updated Production Inventory for Lithium-Ion Battery Anodes for the
GREET® Model, and Review of Advanced Battery Chemistries, (2022).
https://doi.org/10.2172/1891640.

column1: Photovoltaics for Energy Augmentation of Electric Aircraft
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT 

FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE 

INSTRUCTIONS 

Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name. 

Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger. 

Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission and do not need to be addressed in this template.  

RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW 

Title: Photovoltaics for Energy Augmentation of Electric Aircraft 

Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits).  Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant): What problem are you solving?  Has someone tried to solve this problem before?  Where did they go wrong?  What is different about your approach?  If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not?  How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools/methods or state-of-the art approaches?  If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable? Please include references/citations to back up claims where appropriate.  

 

Climate change is the greatest threat to humanity.  We are in a race to develop solutions that maintain and improve quality of life without intensifying causes of climate change.  The development of electrified aircraft allows humanity to maintain civilization with less carbon emissions. One challenge to electrification of aircraft is the mass of batteries required to sustain flight significantly limits the aircraft payload and flight duration.  We propose the inclusion of high voltage, thin film, perovskite based solar arrays laminated onto the aircraft wings and fuselage in production. The integration of these solar cells offset power density needs for batteries for electrified aircraft reducing weight. When coupled with a fuselage manufactured from light weight next generation materials.  

 

Outfitting an electric airplane with perovskite solar cells would offset power density needs for the Lithium ion batteries, reducing weight.  If we assume a 737 airplane traveling from NYC to LA on a sunny day, with modest 20% efficient perovskite solar cells integrated, the solar cells would generate 320 kWhr of energy on that flight. This is achieved with just 1.2 kg of perovskite solar cells total mass over the plane. That energy allows a mass reduction of 1200 kg of lithium ion batteries. These ultralight weight solar cells save 1200 kg of battery mass. Perovskites are especially propitious for photovoltaic application due to their exceptional properties, such as large-charge carrier diffusion lengths [1], long carrier lifetimes, strong optical absorption [2], weak exciton binding [3], and favorable band gaps [2]. Perovskite based photovoltaics are thin films (300-500 nm) light weight, low cost, and are compatible with solution or vapor phase processing techniques. Multi-junction (tandem) solar cells consisting of multiple light absorbers with considerably different bandgaps show great potential in breaking the theoretical efficiency limit of a single junction solar cell (33%) by absorbing light in a broader range of wavelengths.[4] These tandem solar cells are expected to achieve power conversion efficiencies up to 25.2% (with theoretical limits of 42%) and are 500X thinner than the current state of the art (SOA) technology.  Perovskite solar cells also absorb light more strongly than SOA GaAs solar cells. 

 

My previous research has led to the development of single junction perovskite solar cell at reproducible 20% power conversion efficiency that can withstand the harsh low earth environment and are stable to terrestrial stressors. We can apply lessons learned from that effort to develop a lightweight low-cost perovskite based tandem photovoltaic capable of greater power output. We will select materials suitable for the wide bandgap (1.7-1.9 eV) second junction solar cell and we will demonstrate the ability to fabricate these cells, regardless of solvent compatibility, with a lamination technique that has been demonstrated to be effective with perovskite interlayers.[5]  

 

Electrified aircraft is a newer venture with the first passenger electric aircraft, Alice, flight in September 2022.  Long duration unmanned air vehicles augmented with photovoltaics like the AeroVironment Helios vehicle have demonstrated feasibility of solar and fuel cell powered aerial vehicles.  These vehicles have currently been limited to small payload vehicles as mass is limited.  Emerging photovoltaic technologies, like those based on perovskites, allow for previously unachievable specific powers (W/kg).  When compared to the state of the art III-V or Silicon solar cells, perovskites  

 

Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion. 

MS1: Demonstration of lamination of single junction perovskite solar cell with heat press showing the feasibility of the process to combine two junctions together to form a tandem cell. 

MS2: Material down selection for wide bandgap second junction active layer material with special considerations for efficiency, durability, and manufacturability.  

MS3: Model the electrical performance of the second junction solar cell with primary candidate material. 

MS4: Deposit and characterize the optical and electrical performance of the wide bandgap perovskite material.  

This work should be evaluated on the delivery of materials identified and selected for the second junction wide bandgap perovskite solar cell.  This work should also be evaluated on the computational predicted performance of the resulting tandem device. The proposed tandem device efficiency, manufacturability, and durability should be considered.  

After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps?  Where are the potential areas for transition?  What follow-on research do you anticipate?  

The next steps of this research should include deposition of the champion wide bandgap perovskite active layer for the second junction. We will then use the lamination technique to combine the first and second junction of the devices to yield a tandem perovskite based photovoltaic. We will perform local optimization to increase the power conversion efficiency and test the cell in relevant environmental stressors including humidity and thermal stresses. 

This work has applications in both the terrestrial and space markets. Potential transition to TACP or GCD can facilitate further technical development and advancement of technology readiness level.  There are also many small businesses and universities in this area so SBIR/STTR opportunities could facilitate tech transfer and commercialization.   

Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation:  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically.  You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot?  What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?  

If, three months into this work, I discovered that our lamination technique was not feasible for the materials I selected, I would first revisit where in the stack I was laminating. There may be a different material layer more suited to undergo this process.  If that did not resolve the technical challenges I would revisit materials selection, guided by literature, and alter my deposition technique either to omit the need for lamination or to ensure compatibility. We will use a combination of the literature, evidence-based decision making, computational modeling, and experimental materials development to design a wide bandgap perovskite photovoltaic that will supplement the absorption of existing perovskite solar cell providing a path toward energy augmentation for electrified aircraft.  

 

[1]	L. R. V. Buizza et al., “Charge-Carrier Dynamics, Mobilities, and Diffusion Lengths of 2D–3D Hybrid Butylammonium–Cesium–Formamidinium Lead Halide Perovskites,” Adv. Funct. Mater., vol. 29, no. 35, p. 1902656, 2019, doi: 10.1002/adfm.201902656. 

[2]	I. E. Castelli, J. M. García-Lastra, K. S. Thygesen, and K. W. Jacobsen, “Bandgap calculations and trends of organometal halide perovskites,” APL Mater., vol. 2, no. 8, p. 081514, Aug. 2014, doi: 10.1063/1.4893495. 

[3]	F. Ruf et al., “Temperature-dependent studies of exciton binding energy and phase-transition suppression in (Cs,FA,MA)Pb(I,Br)3 perovskites,” APL Mater., vol. 7, no. 3, p. 031113, Mar. 2019, doi: 10.1063/1.5083792. 

[4]	H. Li and W. Zhang, “Perovskite Tandem Solar Cells: From Fundamentals to Commercial Deployment,” Chem. Rev., Aug. 2020, doi: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.9b00780. 

[5]	S. P. Dunfield et al., “Curtailing Perovskite Processing Limitations via Lamination at the Perovskite/Perovskite Interface,” ACS Energy Lett., vol. 3, no. 5, pp. 1192–1197, May 2018, doi: 10.1021/acsenergylett.8b00548.

column1: Hydrogen Powered Aviation Through Sustainable Manufacturing and Repair of Carbon Fiber Reinforced Thermoplastic Composite Cryotanks.
column4:
Title: Hydrogen Powered Aviation Through Sustainable Manufacturing and Repair of Carbon Fiber
Reinforced Thermoplastic Composite Cryotanks.
1. Provide a description of the work: The current use of fossil fuels within the aviation industry
contributes more to global warming than is generally appreciated because of the mix of climate
pollutants it generates. A recent model analyzed the CO2 and non-CO2 effects (like nitrogen oxide
emissions and contrail formation) to assess aviation's total warming footprint. The report found aviation
contributed approximately 4% to observed human-induced global warming to date, despite being
responsible for only 2.4% of global annual emissions of CO2.(1)
One solution to the continued impact of aviation on climate change is a shift toward Sustainable
Aviation Fuels (SAFs), such as hydrogen. The European Clean Aviation Initiative reports that hydrogen
power can be part of the green aviation solution in that hydrogen power completely eliminates
CO2 emissions and can be produced carbon-free. Considering non-CO2 emissions as well, the latest
estimates show that hydrogen combustion could reduce the climate impact of flight by up to 75%, and
fuel-cell propulsion by up to 90%.(2) The Clean Sky 2 Program, which is part of the Clean Aviation
Initiative found that hydrogen either for fuel cells, direct burn in gas turbine engines or as a building
block for synthetic liquid fuels could feasibly power aircraft with entry into service by 2035 for shortrange aircraft at a cost of less than $20 extra per person on a short-range flight, and reducing climate
impact by 50 to 90%. (3)
Problem: While a clear pay-off exists for hydrogen powered aircraft, the physical space required to carry
gaseous hydrogen is large, requiring cryogenic storage hydrogen fuel as a liquid, at -253oC. The
successful utilization of lightweight carbon fiber/polymer composite tanks has met challenges cycling to
this temperature, the primary challenge being microcracking of the matrix.
Has someone tried to solve the problem before. Composite cryotanks have been evaluated by industry
and Government for decades.(4) The most common materials and manufacturing approach for
composite tanks has been autoclave consolidated carbon fiber and epoxy composite. As the tank is
subjected to repeated fill/drain cycles, the mismatch in the coefficient of thermal expansion between
the carbon fiber reinforcement and epoxy matrix leads to residual stresses in the laminated tank wall
resulting in matrix microcracking (5). This was addressed by the NASA Composite Cryotank Technology
Demonstration Project in 2013 by using thin plies to reduce interlaminar stresses. This approach was
successful in reducing, but not eliminating microcracking. Once microcracking starts, it cannot be
repaired in an epoxy matrix cryotank. In addition, the epoxy matrix material is cured in an autoclave
which is a high energy process and requires the use of non-recyclable/ non-reusable consumable
materials.
A separate materials option for composite cryotanks is carbon fiber reinforced thermoplastics.
Thermoplastic matrix composites offer greater compliance than the traditional epoxy (thermoset)
matrix materials and therefore the potential to reduce matrix microcracking. There has been limited
research using thermoplastics due to manufacturing challenges such as low drapability of the composite
prepreg and the requirement for high processing temperatures. Recent developments in low melt
temperature materials and automated manufacturing provide new opportunities for this material class.
Thermoplastic composites are receiving attention for cryogen storage, most notably a study is currently
underway in the Netherlands to build and evaluate thermoset and thermoplastics composites for liquid
hydrogen cryotanks for commercial aircraft. (6)
Where did they go wrong/what is different about this approach: We propose to focus on
thermoplastics, and pushing a step further than the European study we propose to experimentally and
analytically evaluate thermoplastic composites for (a) viability as a composite cryo-tank material for
hydrogen, (b) repairability of microcracking within the matrix to increase the lifetime and reduce waste
and (c) reduce the cost and environmental impact of manufacturing relative to the state-of-the-art
autoclave consolidation through use of thermoplastic welding options, such as ultrasonic welding.
If successful the proposed work will enable hydrogen-based propulsion opportunities within the aviation
industry, energy savings in manufacturing, and increased safety through repairability of the
thermoplastic tank.
2. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion. The
key performance requirement for a composite cryo-tank is that it holds cryogenic liquid. Microcracking
has been identified as the primary path for cryogen loss through the tank wall, therefore the feasibility
of microcrack mitigation and repair will be the focus of this initial effort.
a. State-of-the-Art (SOA) assessment and partner identification. The past 3-5 years have seen a
resurgence of U.S. based research with thermoplastic matrix composites leading to rapid
advances in manufacturing and materials testing.
i. A SOA assessment will be used to establish baseline metrics for consolidation quality for
composites manufactured out of the autoclave and repaired composites.
ii. A partner will be identified for ultrasonic welding of thermoplastic composites. NASA
GRC has current contracts for thermoplastic welding with Agile Ultrasonics in Columbus
Ohio. This is for flat coupon welds, (as opposed to a tank)
iii. Feasibility assessment will be performed to ‘trade’ thermoset and thermoplastic
composite materials through analysis. Existing database properties will be used.
b. Assess feasibility of sustainable (out-of-autoclave) manufacturing: build upon NASA’s recent
experience with thermoplastic welding to demonstrate out-of autoclave consolidation of flat
panels and plates.
i. Establish industry partnership for out-of-autoclave manufacturing via ultrasonic welding
methods.
- Manufacture flat panels to generate test coupons for compression
strength and interlaminar shear strength.
- Manufacture cylindrical components to demonstrate manufacturing at
the subcomponent level.
- Finite element analysis to for failure prediction.
- Evaluate consolidation quality through standard inspection techniques
and baseline mechanical tests.
ii. Establish in-house capability for ultrasonic welding.
- Manufacture flat panels to generate compression and interlaminar
shear strength test coupons for comparison to industry fabricated parts.
- Manufacture cylindrical components to demonstrate manufacturing at
the subcomponent level.
- Evaluate consolidation quality through standard inspection techniques
and baseline mechanical tests.
- Data comparison between in-house and industry manufactured parts
will be used to inform in-house process development.
c. Assess feasibility of microcrack repair: utilize established welding techniques to re-melt/heal
microcracks in the composite matrix.
i. Induce microcracking in the thermoplastic composite through cycling to cryogenic
temperature.
ii. Repair the cracks through ultrasonic welding methods.
iii. Mechanical testing of repaired coupons for comparison to pristine
d. Budget: Costs for this project are associated with materials, manufacturing, and test. This
includes a contract for ultrasonic welding (out of autoclave consolidation) while concurrently
building the capability in-house.
3. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? This work will establish
feasibility of the material class to enable sustainable aviation through reduced energy manufacturing
and a transition to hydrogen fuel. Next steps include but are not limited to the following.
a. Establish a team with expertise in the requirements of hydrogen powered aviation to define
requirements of the composite tank and support structure.
b. Establish a team to design the tank and support structure including connections, fittings,
baffles/slosh mitigation, fuel lines, etc.
c. Establish a design and analysis team to ensure margins of safety are met for the cryo-tank.
d. Develop analysis tools to predict microcracking based on micromechanics models.
e. Follow the building block approach to manufacture and test from the coupon to the component
level.
Potential area of transition includes the Commercially Viable Hydrogen Aircraft for Reduction of
Greenhouse Emissions Project.
4. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation: Three months
into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not
feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot? What alternative
approaches or methods would you pursue?
a. For this effort there are multiple paths to address this scenarioi. We have proposed two technology developments, lightweight composite tank, and
energy savings through out of autoclave manufacturing. The energy savings in
manufacturing is the higher risk component of this proposal due to challenges in
meeting the consolidation quality achieved in an autoclave. If deemed technically infeasible we can focus on the composite tank in a traditional manufacturing
environment.
ii. Second option would be to shift the focus away from tanks and move to more energy
efficient manufacturing for aircraft structures. This is work we had started through CIF
funding and can continue.
References
1. Klower, et al “Quantifying aviations contribution to global warming” Environmental Research Letters,
2021 DOI 10.1088/1748-9326/ac286e)
2. https://www.clean-aviation.eu/media/executive-directors-blog/how-can-hydrogen-technologiespower-the-clean-aircraft-of-the-future
3. https://www.clean-aviation.eu/media/publications/hydrogen-powered-aviation
4. Chen, D., et.al., “A Review of the Polymer for Cryogenic Application: Methods, Mechanisms and
Perspectives”, Polymers 2021, 13, 320.
5. Grogan, D.M, et.al., “Damage Characterization of Cryogenically Cycled Carbon Fibre/PEEK laminates”,
Composites Part A: Applied Science and Manufacturing, Vol. 66, 2014.
6. https://www.compositesworld.com/articles/demonstrating-composite-lh2-tanks-for-commercialaircraft

column1: Robust Repair and Refurbishment Technologies Enabling Reusability and Life Extension of Ceramic Matrix Composites Propulsion Components
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT 

FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE 

Title:  Robust Repair and Refurbishment Technologies Enabling Reusability and Life Extension of Ceramic Matrix Composites Propulsion Components  

Advanced silicon carbide fiber reinforced silicon carbide matrix (SiC/SiC) composite components are currently in service and being further developed for insertion in several turbine engine applications. The advantages of ceramic matrix composites (CMCs) over metals include lower weight, higher temperature capability and stability, and corrosion resistance while the advantages over monolithic (non-fiber reinforced) ceramics include damage tolerance, graceful failure, and thermal shock resistance. CMC turbine engine components offer significant performance benefits of reduced cooling, fuel burn, and emissions (NOx and COx), however, the materials are relatively expensive with complex manufacturing required for the integrated constituents of the CMC. During service, the CMC components (e.g. turbine blades, vanes, shrouds, and combustor liners) experience degradation in performance due to various forms of damage including oxidation, impact damage, erosion, surface spallation, and delamination. Currently, as CMC parts wear out and, in some cases, when cooling channels within CMCs are degraded or clogged, they need to be replaced with brand new parts. The continuous replacement of CMC components will be quite expensive given the high acquisition cost of components. It will also contribute to material waste and a higher demand for labor, time, and energy resources during their fabrication compared to that of refurbished parts.  

Currently, metallic turbine engine components are regularly repaired and refurbished during engine overhauls to extend life of components. This repair and refurbishment provide significant cost savings, extends reliability, safety, and life of components as well as reduce wastes. However, looking at the ceramic matrix composite landscape, no viable repair or refurbishment technology is available. At GRC, we have significant experience in developing repair and refurbishment technologies for space shuttle leading edges (C/C composites) and a collaborative program with Goodrich Corp. for the C/C composite aircraft brake repair and refurbishment.  These technologies were developed at high TRL level and wide variety of testing was conducted.  

We propose to advance the state-of-the-art by developing methods to repair and refurbish SiC/SiC CMCs to retain material performance requirements and extend their service life thus reducing waste. As of now, there are no suitable methods to extend the life of damaged CMCs using repair and refurbishment technologies. One method investigated by other researchers is the self-healing of cracked CMCs by forming glasses in the matrix or coating which melt and flow to fill in cracks (ref. 1-2). However, the formed glass can only slowdown the oxidation in the vicinity of a matrix crack without contributing to CMC mechanical load carrying capability. Also, low melting glasses are not appropriate as they create stress corrosion, vaporization, and reduce service life. Currently used CMCs do not have any glass forming constituents due to these reasons. Any repair and refurbishment technology should not only be able to repair only cracks but other forms of CMC damage such as cooling channels restoration. It should also avoid potential chemical incompatibility with the CMCs and/or their environmental barrier coatings (EBCs). Furthermore, the self-healing crack methods have temperature capabilities well below the SiC/SiC maximum service temperature of 2400°F and especially the new target of 2700°F for next generation SiC/SiC. A group from Boeing has investigated patches for repairing space shuttle leading edges (ref. 3). Their approach does not seem to have been fully developed or reported. The leading-edge patches are not fully processed until earth-atmosphere-reentry heating where the high reentry temperatures act to pyrolyze the material. At NASA GRC, Dr. Mrityunjay Singh, who is part of this proposal, had developed “Glenn Refractory Adhesive for Bonding and Exterior Repair (GRABER) (refs. 4-8)”, which was successfully used for repairing reinforced carbon/carbon composite (RCC) with different types of damage (cracks, spallation, delamination, etc). The verification and qualification testing was carried out in arc-jet testing facilities at NASA JSC, NASA Ames, and Boeing LCAT facilities in St. Louis, MO. He has also worked with largest US aircraft brake manufacturer for the repair and refurbishment of C/C composite aircraft brakes. Experience gained from the assessment of CMC damage and repair techniques will be leveraged for our specific case of SiC/SiC CMCs for turbine engine applications with an emphasis on retaining mechanical properties and environmental stability in a steam environment. Engine combustion environments are rich in water vapor which can cause reactions and surface recession and degradation of SiC/SiC materials.  

The approach is to develop a method for the repair and refurbishment of SiC/SiC CMCs. Material compositions will be developed and evaluated. Processing conditions will be optimized. Various types of flaws (e.g. surface, through holes, and de-laminations) will be introduced into the CMC test specimens. For larger flaws, a preform of SiC woven cloth will be integrated with the repair materials for maintaining CMC structural integrity. The ability for the repair and patch methods to retain mechanical strength and environmental durability will be assessed. Testing of tensile coupons while under a mechanical stress in a steam environment will be conducted to compare the performance of undamaged, damaged & unrepaired, and damaged & repaired CMCs. The results will be analyzed to determine repair effectiveness. Correlations will be made between material microstructures, processing conditions, and properties.  

CMC materials and lab equipment are available for the activity. Mechanical testing will be conducted in load frames with the ability to test in various environments such as oxidizing and steam. Strain will be monitored by high temperature extensometers and digital image correlation. Damage will be monitored and assessed using acoustic emission technique which will help determine conditions for inducing damage in samples prior to applying the repair technology. The well-equipped labs and relevant experience in ceramic processing, repair, mechanical testing, and environmental exposure provides a good chance for success, rapid progress, and requires no new capabilities.  

CMCs enable more efficient turbine engines for reducing fuel consumption, carbon emissions and environmental impacts due to their higher operating temperatures, reduced cooling requirements, and improved engine efficiency. Successful repair methods will further enhance the green technology benefits of CMCs by contributing to their greater utilization in turbine engines, longer component lives, and reduced costs and waste. 

Milestones 

Identify relevant types of SiC/SiC CMC damage, suitable repair materials, and processing approaches (12/2023). 

Develop compositions and processing conditions for repair materials to be applied to damaged SiC/SiC coupons (3/2024).  

Develop a silicon carbide fiber reinforced patch repair method for larger flaws (6/2024). 

Evaluate repaired and unrepaired composites under relevant mechanical stresses and environmental conditions (9/2024).   

The work will be evaluated based on the ability to retain the mechanical properties and environmental durability in the repaired CMC compared to the performance of the unrepaired CMC. Success will be achieved if there is significant improvement in the usability of the repaired CMC. Monotonic tensile tests will be performed at room or high temperature on repaired and unrepaired CMCs to quantify the enhancement in strength provided by CMC repair technology. Additionally, stress rupture testing of repaired and non-repaired CMC test coupons in a steam rig under a constant or cyclic load until failure will be conducted. Next, the times to failure will be compared for as-fabricated, repaired, and non-repaired SiC/SiC tensile specimens to identify the improvement in CMC life and reusability provided by the implemented CMC repair technology. 

If the repair of SiC/SiC activity is successful, the next steps are to further increase the technology readiness level (TRL). Composite repair could be progressed toward an actual SiC/SiC turbine engine component. Repair of a complex geometry could be addressed as well as integrating the reapplication or repair of an EBC coating. For patch repairs with woven SiC cloth, fiber coatings can be integrated for enhanced mechanical properties. Also, for repairs over CMC components with film cooling holes, the reintroduction of cooling holes can be demonstrated.  

The CMC repair technology can be transferred to engine companies. Also, there are transition opportunities for ground-based power generation. There may be opportunities to collaborate with NASA aeronautics projects or engine companies which are testing or are already using CMC components. The repair of their tested and in-service parts could be demonstrated.  

With our past experiences and lab capabilities, we stand a good chance of developing SiC/SiC CMC repair technology and believe we have made a fair assessment of the feasibility. However, if the method was determined to be non-feasible, we could quickly pivot our activities. If there was an issue with material or processing compatibility, we could adjust our approach to be better matched with SiC/SiC materials. If the whole approach is not feasible and needs to be abandoned, we would pursue another necessary and relevant technology for CMCs. During the remaining months, joining and integration technologies could be pursued which allow for the buildup of larger and more complex shaped CMC parts as well as their incorporation with metal-based systems (e.g. support structures, blade roots and hubs, cooling manifolds, etc.). Our team has extensive experience in developing joining and integration technologies which can be leveraged here. Each joining approach must be tailored for its specific case based on material pairings (e.g. CMC to CMC or CMC to metal), joining interlayer approach (e.g. paste, foil, hybrid, and multi-layer), joining method (e.g. brazing, diffusion bonding, eutectic phase bonding, reactive slurry infiltration), part geometries, applications conditions (e.g. operating environment, temperature, and stress) and performance requirements. A narrowed focus could be to demonstrate the feasibility of a brazing approach for the case of brazing a SiC/SiC CMC blade root to a metallic rotor hub.  

References 

1.  Rebillat, F. "Advances in self-healing ceramic matrix composites." In Advances in ceramic matrix composites, pp. 475-514. Woodhead Publishing, 2014. 

2.  Quemard, Ludovic, Francis Rebillat, Alain Guette, Henri Tawil, and Caroline Louchet-Pouillerie. "Self-healing mechanisms of a SiC fiber reinforced multi-layered ceramic matrix composite in high pressure steam environments." Journal of the European Ceramic Society 27, no. 4 (2007): 2085-2094. 

3.  Hogenson, Peter A., Gordon R. Toombs, Steven Adam, and James V. Tompkins. Patches for Repairing Ceramics and Ceramic-Matrix Composites. No. MSC-24018. 2006. 

4. M. Singh, In-Space Repair of Reinforced Carbon-Carbon Thermal Protection System Structures, World Ceramics Congress (CIMTEC 2006),  https://ntrs.nasa.gov/citations/20070018032 

5. M. Singh, IN-SPACE REPAIR and Refurbishment OF Thermal Protection System Structures for Reusable Launch Vehicles, International Conference and Exposition of European Ceramic Society, Germany (2007). 

6.  M. Singh, On-Orbit REPAIR OF RCC Structures, 7th National Thermal Protection System (TPS) Workshop, Dayton, OH (2004). 

7. M.Singh, T.Schpargel, Glenn Refractory Adhesive for Bonding and Exterior REPAIR (GRABER) Developed for Repairing Shuttle Damage, R&T Report, NASA Glenn Research Center, Cleveland, OH, June 2005. 

8. M. Singh and Tarah Schpargel, Glenn Refractory Adhesive for Bonding and Exterior Repair (GRABER) 

Technology Given 2005 R&D 100 Award, NASA R&T report, 2005, Page 99-100.

column1: Performance Enhancement of Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell Components with Machine Learning for Electric Aircraft Propulsion
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT 

FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE 

Title: Performance Enhancement of Proton Exchange Membrane Fuel Cell Components with Machine Learning for Electric Aircraft Propulsion 

Description of the work  

NASA aeronautics goals include pioneering new technology to reduce emissions, noise, and carbon footprint from air travel.  The feasibility of using fuel cells and on-board cryogenic hydrogen (H2) systems in combination with electric motors for zero emission commercial transport aircraft has been widely examined.  Developing a practical, implementable carbon-free electric power system for a highly constrained “electric aircraft” application is a complex and complicated poly-dimensional optimization problem. The primary factor limiting fuel cell implementation remains thermal management at the required high fuel cell stack specific power levels resulting from inadequate heat transfer and unacceptably inefficient operation manifesting as low average cell voltage (Vcc). Despite many historical and current research efforts by government, academia, and aviation industry, the relative importance of design parameters across multiple systems and levels of assembly remains poorly understood.  Materials science and engineering has played a central role in the evolution of improved electrochemical technologies such as fuel cells and batteries. However, traditional ‘‘Edisonian’’ approaches to evolve from discovery to commercial implementation is too costly and time consuming relative to the accelerating anthropogenic climate change resulting from Carbon Cycle disruptions. The emergence of Machine Learning (ML) modeling methods with increasingly powerful computers has augmented cross-disciplinary technological advances from materials discovery to commercialized products.  This activity proposes using the latest artificial intelligence (AI) research to develop two ML models. the first model is critical to understand the relationships among system-level variables for electric aircraft propulsion (EAP) by assessing fuel cell power system response (Vcc) to the normalized aircraft electrical load current density (i) (

). The second model will implement a self-driven approach based on the first model and leverage existing models to elucidate the critical supporting parameters for optimizing the fuel cell system operation and calculate the EAP fuel cell power system performance metrics of power density (W/L), specific power (W/kg) and long-term stability (

) from repeated experimentation.  Establishing a self-driving laboratory for a ML fuel cell technology modeling tool marks a pioneering leap in sustainable energy research which sets it apart from traditional modeling methodologies like Monte Carlo modeling. This information will focus objective development goals by identifying material, components and/or system interfaces that can viably meet EAP performance metrics and provide feasible performance profiles for aircraft-level models investigating EAP. These sensitive parameters potentially can range from fuel cell component materials, mechanisms to enhance convective heat transfer, to low mass phase change materials, to optimizing power management and distribution (PMAD) components for reducing ohmic resistance. The study is a general development of a tool of FC for implementing EAP in the medium-scale commercial aircraft as it provides the most impactful transformation to zero emission commercial aviation. 

References 

Abolhasani, M., Montoya, J., & Fathabadi, H. (2019). Industry 4.0 applications in energy systems: A comprehensive review. Energy Reports, 5, 1349-1377. 

Zhou, Z.; Zholobko, O., et alia, Polybenzimidazole-Based Polymer Electrolyte Membranes for High-Temperature Fuel Cells: Current Status and Prospects. Energies 2021, 14, 135. 

Qu, E.; Hao, X et alia; Proton exchange membranes for high temperature proton exchange membrane fuel cells: Challenges and perspectives. Journal of Power Sources 2022, 533, 231386 

High Temperature Polymer Electrolyte Membrane Fuel Cells Approaches, Status, and Perspectives, edited by Li, Q.; Aili, D.; Hjuler, H.A.; Jensen, J.O., 2016, Springer International Pub., Switzerland 

Anticipated milestones and Performance Metrics 

Figure 1 illustrates the proposed iterative project workflow required to develop and train the ML model within the self-driving laboratory and conduct the statistical data evaluation for producing feasible and actionable data products of system sensitivity parameters influencing cell voltage response (Vcc) to the power demanded by the aircraft when assessed in electrical current density (i in mA/cm2). The five-(5) project milestones are shown in a GANTT chart in Figure 2. 

Figure 1: Schematic of Project Work Plan 

The work starts with collecting relevant PEM FC performance data, especially those for vehicle and aircraft propulsion, to develop the ML training data sets. Where the statistical evaluation determines that data gaps exist, synthetic data will be generated based on first-principal models. In parallel, the first ML tool element will develop a precise machine learning model that can predict the voltage response of the fuel cell system to the vehicle electrical load demand. Through preliminary statistical work, model building, and feature engineering, this first element will provide valuable insights into system variables and the relative relationship among these variables. While Monte Carlo models are valuable for probabilistic analysis and estimating outcomes within well-defined distributions, self-driving AI/ML labs offer a superior approach. The most influential ML tool element will drive NASA software in a self-driven lab for closing any gaps between the fuel cell system performance metrics and aircraft performance requirements. These labs are equipped to autonomously conduct experiments, adapt to changing conditions, and continuously learn from data. By harnessing machine learning and AI, they minimize the potential for errors and inefficiencies associated with human intervention. This innovative approach aligns with the vision of Industry 4.0, where the integration of cutting-edge technologies reshapes manufacturing and research processes (Abolhasani et al., 2019). Furthermore, the self-driving lab seamlessly integrates with our software to drive tools toward achievable desired outputs. This symbiotic relationship enhances fuel cell performance, ultimately advancing the frontiers of sustainable energy research and development. Any deficiencies in the resulting specific power, power density, and performance stability then guide development objectives to improve FC power and propulsion system performance.  

This effort will produce six-(6) deliverables: a preliminary EAP requirements set, a ML modeling tool consisting of two elements, a preliminary PEM fuel cell model performance set, Data Gap Closure Resource Estimate, a ML model Validation Resource Estimate, and a final report.  

 

  

Figure 2: Project GANTT Chart 

Follow-on Activities 

The products of this foundational work would be integrated into existing aircraft-level models for developing electric aircraft and accelerate the development of the FC power and propulsion systems. Learning more about the relationships between system variables (features or input) will focus future research on the technologies limiting this application. In the next phase of this work, a significant experimental data collection is anticipated in order to replace the synthetic data by empirical data to validate and improve the ML model fidelity. Should these products become sufficiently mature, it remains feasible to incorporated them into an eventual Digital Twin model architecture.  

PI Scenario 

This scenario does not apply to this process as ML modeling is inherently an iterative process that utilizes the “fail early, fail often, but always fail forward” (J.C. Maxwell) approach. The ML model matures with each iteration and provides valuable insights into the poly-dimensional space under investigation. There exist multiple tools that can be used should one fail and there exists a great deal of data to mine that could be temporarily supported by synthetic data until credible empirical data became available. Implementing FC power and propulsion systems in a carbon-free electric aircraft includes many challenges available for ML modeling. There are many components, sub-systems, and interfaces that require additional performance data and development prior to integrating into an electric aircraft. Should resources become available, conducting experiments to close any identified data gaps would improve data quality.

column1: Maximizing the Efficiency of Advanced Air Mobility with Formation Flight
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT 

FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL 

INSTRUCTIONS 

Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name. 

Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger. 

Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission and do not need to be addressed in this template.  

RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW 

Title: Maximizing the Efficiency of Advanced Air Mobility with Formation Flight 

Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits).  Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant): What problem are you solving?  Has someone tried to solve this problem before?  Where did they go wrong?  What is different about your approach?  If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not?  How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools/methods or state-of-the art approaches?  If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable? Please include references/citations to back up claims where appropriate.  

 

Formation flying is a well-known approach for improving the efficiency of flight. Migratory birds flying in V-formation gain significant efficiency by taking advantage of the upwash from the wing tip of the leading bird, which allows the trailing birds to fly with reduced angle-of-attack and lower induced drag [1]. For birds and aircraft alike, the key to gaining maximum efficiency with this technique is identifying the optimal configuration of the formation. While birds can do this adaptively in actual flight (and millions of years of evolution), computational tools are needed to investigate the possible benefits for safely improving the efficiency of human air transportation especially for use of newly emerging electric-Vertical Takeoff and Landing (eVTOL) vehicle designs. 

The computational objectives needed for a comprehensive study of formation flight are: 

Finding the optimal formation configuration as function of vehicle types/design and flight conditions, 

Identifying the most efficient (and safe) way to form the configuration, 

and maneuver within the formation, e.g., to transfer the lead-aircraft 

potentially with specialized actuators for control within the wake where traditional actuators (e.g., ailerons) lose effectiveness. 

A study of the control laws to 

automatically hold the optimal configuration, 

while remaining robust to adverse weather disturbances, 

Determining methods to maneuver the overall formation as one,  

and compute optimal trajectories of the formation in weather. 

 

The concept of formation flight is not new and has been studied extensively. Some theoretical studies have shown potential drag reduction for extended formation flight at 38%-45%, and flight tests with more conventional vehicle types (F/A 18 and C-17) at AFRC have shown fuel flow reduction of 7%-18% [2].  Flight dynamics in wake is not necessarily LTI (linear time invariant) but is nonlinear LTV (linear time varying) [3].  The efficiency gains from free lift associated with formation flight may be offset by degradation in stability and control.  Safety and ride quality are important considerations.  The uncertainty around the trade-space for eVTOL vehicles is exactly why this type of work needs to be funded initially at a small funding level.  Because of the nature of the challenges in many different areas (nonlinear aerodynamics, nonlinear LTV flight dynamics, and nonlinear control), this is a rich area for research.  There are computational models for wake interaction currently under development [4] which could be utilized in this study to enable rapid assessment and trade-space exploration. 

 

There are however few (if any) studies on optimization of formation flight for more efficient Urban Air Mobility operations with eVTOL vehicles. Also, the simultaneous considerations of control robustness and formation safety are missing from all the studies that we know of. Traditionally, flight safety is concerned with wake avoidance, whereas the objective here is to leverage it for energy savings.  

 

[1] J. C. Chan, P. C. Wang, and H. Hesse. Aerodynamic interactions in formation flight for wake vortex surfing. In AIAA AVIATION 2023 Forum, 2023. 

[2] J. Pahle, D. Berger, M. Venti, C. Duggan, J. Faber, and K. Cardinal. An initial flight investigation of formation flight for drag reduction on the c-17 aircraft. In AIAA Atmospheric Flight Mechanics Conference, 2012. 

[3] J. E. Bacui, N. Nguyen, W. Okolo and J. Xiong. Wake Vortex Effects Between Urban Air Mobility Aircraft, AIAA Atmospheric Flight Mechanics Conference, AIAA-2023-1558, January 2023. 

[4] N. Nguyen. A Physics-Based Spatial Wake Interactional Model of Fixed-Wing Aircraft and Rotorcraft for Urban Air Mobility.  In AIAA SciTech Forum, 19-21 January 2021. 

 

Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion. 

In the seedling effort, a sandbox demonstration case will be developed for a formation of three UAM Lift+Cruise reference design vehicles (already available from collaborative work with the RVLT project). The problem will be analyzed computationally to determine optimal vehicle configuration (distance and orientation of vehicles to each-other) in a cruise flight-condition for maximum range given a total energy constraint. Initial models for the formation in the cruise condition (with additional states for aerodynamic interactions) will be developed and analyzed from a robust control perspective to gauge the feasibility for safe operations with adverse weather (simulated using a gust and Dryden turbulence models). The final results are intended to inform the creation of new formation flight-based sustainability technical challenges within TTT. 

Schematic of the NASA Lift+Cruise reference vehicle concept ... 

Figure 1: RVLT Lift+Cruise Concept Design 

After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps?  Where are the potential areas for transition?  What follow-on research do you anticipate?  

Analyzing the overall safety of formation flight and, especially, convincing the FAA, will be the most difficult part. Further investigation will be required into vehicle technologies for detecting failures in advance and the ability to break formation safely when adverse events occur. Developing the computational technology (and leveraging existing solutions) required to address all of the aforementioned objectives could form the basis for a new technical challenge within the TTT project, one that simultaneously explores the aerodynamics, vehicle design, and robust fault-tolerant control required to realize the full benefit of formation flight for sustainable aviation. 

 

Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation:  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically.  You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot?  What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?  

If initial results show insufficient benefit, pivoting to consideration of vehicle design for increasing the benefit of formation flight is a possibility. This might include the design of wing-tip modifications, use of variable camber flaps, or even the optimized design of a specialized unmanned lead vehicle that allows passenger carrying vehicles to fly behind it with maximized efficiency.

column1: Sensor System Study for Health Management of Sustainable Aviation Based on Electric Propulsion
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT
FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL
Title: Sensor System Study for Health Management of Sustainable Aviation Based on Electric
Propulsion
1. Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated
benefits).
Problem: NASA is committed to supporting the U.S. climate goal of achieving net-zero greenhouse
gas emissions from the aviation sector by 2050 and is leading federal agencies and industry to
accelerate the development of sustainable aviation technologies. This includes developing and
deploying alternate, new vehicle designs and architectures including Hybrid Electric or All Electric
vehicle concepts [1,2]. Examples are the Subsonic Single Aft Engine (SUSAN) Electrofan, the Singleaisle Turboelectric AiRCraft with Aft Boundary Layer propulsor (STARC-ABL), and other activities
[3,4,5].
However, these aircraft concepts introduce new hardware systems along with new health
management challenges. For example, fault detection and diagnostics of hybrid electric or all
electric propulsion systems requires an understanding of the operation, performance, degradation,
and failure mechanisms of electric machines, converters (inverters/rectifiers), and power cables
along with the operation of these devices in increasingly complex flight environments [6].
Introduction of new vehicle types and integrated power and propulsion systems requires
increasingly intelligent vehicle systems with capability to detect, diagnose, and predict system
degradation, faults, and failures in a resilient and trustworthy manner. Furthermore, intelligent
vehicle systems must be capable of estimating system capability as it degrades. Monitoring the
system health state has an impact on system operating cost, performance, efficiency, and
environmental impact. Predictive maintenance reduces maintenance cost and vehicle down-time
through reduced unnecessary maintenance costs and improved vehicle availability and throughput.
Efforts are ongoing to evaluate and document potential failure modes and hazards posed by an
Electrified Aircraft Propulsion (EAP) system [6]. Due to their increased complexity and integrated
nature, EAP systems present additional failure modes and hazards not found in conventional
aircraft propulsion designs. Mitigation of these EAP failures requires a system-level design and
analysis approach, which is on-going. Major findings of this work include that EAP degradation,
faults, and failure modes present new health management challenges. This requires background
understanding of electrical engineering and system control and concept of operations (motor
control, generator control, battery management systems). Furthermore, electrical systems don’t
always degrade/fail gracefully, which makes early (timely) diagnosis to enable maintenance
challenging.
Faults include those associated with: electric machines (motors/generators) such as the health of
bearings, lubrication and cooling, windings, rotor, insulation; converters (inverters/rectifiers),
electronic components and the cooling system; high voltage wire and cables, including short or
open circuits and insulation breakdown; overall power quality including degradation/faults leading
to voltage ripple and power instabilities; and thermal management system and battery failures
(thermal runaway). These types of faults require new sensor measurement types compared to
turbine engine, e.g., concentrating on current and voltage, and tailored for a new infrastructure
associated with EAP rather than turbine engines. Although these faults are being identified in 
System Analysis and Failure mode, effects, and criticality analysis (FEMCA) studies presently
ongoing in the ARMD [7], there is limited ongoing work related to understanding the sensor types
and sensing approaches most optimized for this new aircraft infrastructure. Such an understanding
is a necessary first step toward Integrated Vehicle Health Management (IVHM), combining sensing,
diagnostics, and prognostics, for future Sustainable Aviation based on EAP.
Objectives: This task will work in parallel with the ongoing analysis of EAP fault detection [6,7] to
examine sensors and sensor systems that can address fault detection in EAP aircraft. The challenges
for sensor technology for EAP applications include: operation in a high noise environment or with
corona discharge at altitude; increasing integration of sensor technology into electric components
to minimize size weight power and cost; multi parameter measurements to better understand the
health state of the EAP system; providing actionable information for higher level diagnostics; and
leveraging the EAP architecture itself to provide better system level diagnostics. This task intends to
formulate a framework for sensor and sensors systems for EAP health management applications
addressing these challenges.
Approach: In particular, this task will examine the EAP architecture and fault studies to first
understand the wide range of potential failure mechanisms. It will then survey the existing methods
of EAP fault detection to both understand how it is done now, and shortfalls to these approaches. It
will then examine methods for improved EAP sensing including, e.g., new sensor types or additive
manufacturing. The conclusion of this work is a white paper summarizing the above activities and a
preliminary road map for possible ARMD future investment in this area.
This task leverages the ongoing activities in the Intelligent Control and Autonomy Branch (LCC) and
related existing expertise and capabilities [7]. Coordination between multiple sensor Subject Matter
Experts (SME) within the Communications and Intelligent Systems Division, as well as SME in other
Branches both at NASA Glenn Research Center and across the agency is planned. At least one trip is
planned given available resources to a relevant conference related to this topic and/or industry to
broaden the input provided to this study.
Although not presently proposed, but could considered with project management, is the possibility
of hosting a Technical Interchange Meeting (TIM) on the topic Sensor Technology for EAP Health
Management, or even more broadly for IVHM for Sustainable EAP Aviation.
Anticipated Benefits: This task performs the initial survey work needed to define a sensor approach
to be combined with both on-going and future ARMD activities in IVHM for EAP applications
program in sensing, diagnostics, and prognostics. IVHM for EAP is necessary for eventual system
application, whether it be for safety, economic, efficiency, or performance reasons. Overall, new
electric vehicles can be smarter, safer, and more efficient leveraging the difference in architecture;
this work is a first step in providing sensor technology to enable this vision.
2. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion.
Milestone Date
Project Initiation 11/6/23
Documentation of EAP Identified Fault Mechanisms (On-going Project) 12/6/23
Survey of Present EAP Fault Detection Approaches 3/30/24
Evaluation of Potential Alternate EAP Sensor Architectures 7/30/24
Summary Whitepaper and Draft Roadmap for EAP Sensor Development 9/1/24
This project should be evaluated upon whether a core understanding of the challenges of sensor
detection in EAP systems has been clearly articulated, and potential approaches for future work
coupling both sensors and diagnostics for EAP sustainable aviation have been reasonably identified
for future program implementation potentially in FY25. It is also expected that coordination with
other organizations related to, e.g., structural diagnostics or sustainable aviation prognostics, will
be ongoing.
3. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? Where are the potential
areas for transition? What follow-on research do you anticipate?
The need for IVHM for Sustainable Aviation has been introduced to ARMD project management
with positive response. In particular, it is our understanding that TTT Management has
acknowledged the importance of this area and expressed interest for potential future funding.
Assuming no project funding in FY24, this proposed project matures an understanding of the field
and establishes a framework for a more expansive IVHM development in FY 25 if chosen by project
management.
4. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation: Three
months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed
approach is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you
pivot? What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?
Sensor development for health management of EAP systems is one component of what is necessary
for possible sustainable aviation. An equally challenging area is health management for hydrogen
powered vehicles especially those using cryogenic hydrogen. A NASA workshop identified a wide
range of challenges associated with converting from conventional hydrocarbon fuel systems to
hydrogen-based systems [8]. These include a significant range of safety concerns associated with
hydrogen leakage, seals degradation, or structural embrittlement. If a change of direction is decided
related to defining sensor technology for EAP applications, transition of the task to another aspect
of sustainable aviation, hydrogen powered vehicles, would also have a significant impact on
understanding the potential of IVHM for sustainable aviation.
References
1. EAP is called out as a key part of Thrust 3 in the ARMD Strategic Implementation Plan:
https://www.nasa.gov/aeroresearch/strategy
2. Overview of NASA's EAP Research for Large Subsonic Aircraft:
https://ntrs.nasa.gov/search.jsp?R=20170006235
3. Subsonic Single Aft Engine (SUSAN) Aircraft | Glenn Research Center | NASA
4. High Efficiency Megawatt Motor Preliminary Design,” Jansen et al.
https://ntrs.nasa.gov/citations/20190029589
5. NASA X-57 Project: https://www.nasa.gov/aeroresearch/X-57/technical/index.html
6. D. Simon, Health Management Considerations for Electrified Aircraft Propulsion Systems”, SAE E32
Aerospace Propulsion Health Management Committee Meeting March 29-31, 2022.
https://ntrs.nasa.gov/api/citations/20220004260/downloads/EAP_HealthMangementConsideration
_DSimon_v2.pdf
7. NASA Advanced Air Vehicles Program, Advanced Air Transport Technology Project, Power and
Propulsion Subproject
8. NASA’s Meeting on Cryogenic Fuel Systems for Aircraft, NASA Glenn Research Center, Sept. 2022.

column1: Additive Manufacturing of Polyimde Composites for Battery Packaging
column4:
Additive Manufacturing of Polyimde Composites for Battery Packaging 

Introduction  

Advances in lithium battery has made electrical propulsion a reality in the electrified aircrafts. Lightweight aluminum has been used preferentially chosen as the packaging material due to the large amount of power require to propel the electrified aircrafts.  the weight saving in engines often translates into 3 times of weight saving in the aircrafts, it is imperative to find alternative materials for battery packs other than aluminum. Additive manufacturing of lightweight, high temperature thermoset polyimide matrix composites (PMC) in place of aluminum casing for battery packaging will save 50% weight (Al:PMC density ratio = 2.7:1.3 g/cc), ease the manufacturing process of complex shape and improve production efficiency. Furthermore, the boron nitride filled polyimide composite is thermally conductive but not electrically conductive, which may be a plus for battery packs to prevent the loss of electricity.  

 

Update on Additive Manufacturing (AM) of Polyimide Composites by Principal Investigator (PI) 

Traditional Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) or Fused Filament Fabrication (FFF) uses the extruded thermoplastic polymer filaments by melting the filaments to carry out the 3D printing following CAD files.  Conventional laser sintering (LS) is another 3D printing technique that builds 3D objects layer by layer using laser to selectively melt cross-section of a powdered thermoplastic polymers.  However, the resultant 3D objects are often weaker in their strength due to the lack of polymer inter-chain connection in the z-direction; thus, limiting their use temperature to ~200°C based on the commercial thermoplastic polymers. 

 

Previously this PI has developed a melt-processable thermoset polyimide RTM370 resin powder, which can be subjected to laser sintering (LS) at 180°C to build a 3D “Green” object, and subsequently post-cured at 371°C in an oven to fully crosslink the reactive terminal groups within the resin into a network with a glass transition temperature (Tg, softening temperature) of 370°C.
