A high temperature thermoset polyimide carbon fiber composite bracket with >300 °C capability was additively manufactured by laser sintering (LS) for the 1st time in collaboration with U. of Louisville and funded by the Air Force during 2016-2018. 

    

       image003   

FDM (FFF)     b) Laser sintering of resin powder               c) LS-printed carbon fiber composites 

                                                                                     

Recently the PI has also demonstrated the feasibility of 3D-printing composite specimens with boron nitride 

(BN) filled RTM385-SLS polyimide resin powder by laser sintering to afford “Green” dogbone specimens, which was subsequently post-cured at 343°C to afford a 3-dimensional network of BN-polyimide composites with a Tg of 395°C and a thermal conductivity of 0.7 W/m-K with a 6-7%  porocity ─ a major accomplishent under TTT and AATT funding.  Therefore, it is feassible to 3D-print thermally conductive but electrically insulating battery packs by laser sintering, using BN-filled thermoset polyimide resins. 

 

  

 

Text Box 

                                               Post-cured@343°C 

                                              

   

 

      LS-printed BN-PI composites                       Cured BN-PI composites            Proposed battery pack 

 Objective and Innovation of This Proposal: An Improved Fused Powder Fabrication (FPF) 

Although PI’s previous advance in the state-of-the art of laser sintering of thermoset polyimides with boron nitride fillers has certainly made additive manufacturing of thermally conductive, but electrically insulating battery packs an attainable goal. However, the required use of vast area of powder bed in laser sintering creates a large amount of unused resin powder in the peripheral surrounding the desirable object.  It is the objective of this proposal to initiate a Fused Powder Fabrication (FPF) of melt-processable BN-filled thermoset polyimide that will print the actual 3D object directly very similar to Fused Filament Fabrication (FFF) using thermoplastic filaments.  1) This fused thermoset polyimide powder fabrication approach will save cost on the valuable resin powder, and 2) the use of thermoset resin powder which can be further post-cure the as-printed “Green” object to achieve a higher use temperature than the commercial thermoplastic filaments can achieve.  It also eleminate the cost of extruding of filaments for FFF. 

2) Project Plan 

Using melt-processable thermoset polyimide resin powder, PI will collaborate with Hyrel 3D printing company to design a prototype Fused Powder 3D Printing Head that is capable of attaching to the existing commercial Hyrel 3D printer at GRC.  The goals are 1) demonstrate the capability of printing prototype 3D objects; such as square or dogbone-shaped tensile specimens. 2) print a prototype battery pack with high temperature of >300°C capability. 

 

  

Task Description 

Estimated completion Date 

Award contract /Acquire resin 

January, 2024 

Design/Trial for resin printing 

June, 2024 

Complete composite specimens 

September, 2024 

Characterization/testing samples 

November, 2024 

Complete yearly report 

December, 2024 

 

3) Strategic Alignment: 

Battery packaging fits into STMD “Live” framework of human life support, advanced materials/structures/manufacturing. It also fits into GRC’s Power and Energy Storage focus area. Battery packaging is the critical safety requirement for the success of power supply in space and electrified aircraft in aeronautic propulsion on Earth. The packaging materials typically prefer to be multifunctional; they must provide the necessary thermal and safety performance without significantly increasing the mass of the pack. Furthermore, additive manufacturing is an essential thrust in both STMD and GRC strategies. 

    Technology Readiness and Taxonomy: 

       Starting TRL:  2   Target End TRL:  3 

        Primary TX:  Additive manufacturing of polymer composites fits into 

                              TX.12.2.1 Advanced Materials, Structures and Manufacturing.   

        Secondary TX: Battery components fit into TX.03.2.3  Aerospace Power and Energy Storage .  

 

Technology Infusion or Transition Plan: 

● When an additively manufactured composite battery pack is built, it will be transfer to Photovoltaic 

    Electrochemical Systems Branch (LEX) for evaluation in certain existing programs for space  

    power and electrified aircraft applications.   

● GRC’s RTM imide resins are already licensed to Imitec Inc. as a commercial product, and a patent has  

    been filed in 2019 for the said laser sintering technology to make high temperature thermoset  

    composites with >300 ̊ C capability.  

● This same technology of fused powder fabrication of melt-processable thermoset polyimide composites 

    can also be used to build the Thermal Protection Systems (TPS) for reentry as these polyimide resin  

    have shown to have higher char yield than the state-or-the-art of phenolics. 

 

4) Contingency Project Plan: 

In a hypothetical instance that the proposed fused powder fabrication (FPF) method was not successfully in demonstrating the technology advance after 4-month of trying, the team always has a fall back plan of 3D-printing the battery packs by laser sintering of RTM385-SLS polyimide resin with h-BN fillers, which has demonstrated its feasibility in the introduction section of this proposal.

column1: Modeling and mitigation of hydrogen embrittlement of GRX-810 alloy for hydrogen propulsion storage tanks
column4:
Title: < Modeling and mitigation of hydrogen embrittlement of GRX-810 alloy for hydrogen propulsion storage tanks > 

     Cryogenic hydrogen fueled aircraft (under development at NASA GRC, Airbus, etc.) is one of the options to slash CO2 emissions related to air transportation. The main issue with using hydrogen in aircraft is its very low density [1]. Storing hydrogen in its liquid state (at cryogenic temperature) is one of the methods to increase the density. Liquid hydrogen storage tank needs to be resistant to hydrogen embrittlement and capable of structurally withstanding the temperatures of liquid hydrogen. Hydrogen embrittlement is a reduction in the ductility of the structural material (metal alloy) due to absorbed hydrogen. The main goal of this proposal is to investigate the effects of hydrogen absorption on ductility of the alloy GRX-810 [2], that is under development at NASA GRC. GRX-810 is a new breakthrough 3D-printable alloy with remarkable high temperature properties, e.g., creep. It is an oxide dispersion-strengthened alloy with a Ni-Co-Cr matrix. Preliminary tests of this alloy at cryogenic temperatures also show promising results (Yield Strength (YS) T®77K ~ 0.9 GPa, Elongation to Failure (EF), or ductility T®77K ~ 40%). We note that recently developed Ni-Co-Cr-based Medium Entropy Alloys (MEAs) in general demonstrate exceptional mechanical properties at cryogenic temperatures, e.g., a remarkable increase in strength accompanied by a simultaneous increase in ductility (YS T®77K ~ 0.7 GPa, EF T®77K ~ 90%, FT T®77K ~ 280 MPa×m1/2), with decreasing deformation temperature from Room Temperature (RT) to cryogenic temperatures [3]. The diffusivity of hydrogen (e.g., along the grain boundaries), its segregation at lattice defects and the corresponding effects on deformation behavior (e.g., ductility) have not been quantified in the literature for Ni-Co-Cr-based MEAs, in general, and GRX-810 alloy, in particular. Atomistic modeling and simulations are perfectly suited to study the mechanisms of hydrogen embrittlement in full atomic detail and provide recommendations for novel alloy compositions that improve deformation behavior at cryogenic temperatures. Our proposed effort will be leveraged by the capabilities we already have. In particular, the Density Functional Theory- (DFT) informed simulation potential for Ni-Co-Cr, recently developed in our group, will be used for this project, along with the state-of-the-art atomistic simulation techniques (including ab-initio, molecular dynamics, kinetic Monte Carlo, and their combinations) [4, 5]. 

      

     First, we will fit the interatomic potential for Ni-Co-Cr-H (using the existent interatomic potential for Ni-Co-Cr, recently developed in our group), to enable realistic modeling of hydrogen diffusion and segregation at lattice defects in the material. Next, the segregation of hydrogen at lattice defects (e.g., grain boundaries) will be investigated, employing hybrid Molecular Dynamics / kinetic Monte Carlo (MD/MC) simulations. And finally, the effects of hydrogen segregation on deformation behavior at cryogenic temperatures will be studied. In particular, a series of MD deformation tests will be carried out at cryogenic temperatures, varying the amount of hydrogen (and the amounts individual Ni, Co, Cr elements) in the simulation system containing a lattice defect, which would serve as a sink for hydrogen (e.g., a grain boundary). The successful accomplishment of the proposed work will lead to identifying the composition that most effectively improves the performance of the material at cryogenic temperatures. 

     The anticipated milestones will include the following:  

ab initio calculations for the H energetics in the Ni-Co-Cr alloys. 

Interatomic potential for Ni-Co-Cr-H, suitable for simulation of hydrogen diffusion in the Ni-Co-Cr alloys. 

Effects of hydrogen, segregated at a lattice defect (e.g., grain boundary) on deformation behavior at cryogenic temperatures. 

Effects of Ni-Co-Cr composition (by varying the amount of individual Ni, Co, Cr elements in the simulation system) on the above behavior. 

 

     In the next step we will study the behavior of the composite system, containing hard oxide (Y2O3) particles embedded in the Ni-Co-Cr-based matrix, under deformation at cryogenic temperature. The interface between the oxide particle and Ni-Co-Cr-based matrix will possibly serve as a sink for the absorbed hydrogen. The effects of hydrogen segregation at this interface on deformation behavior at cryogenic temperatures will be studied, as well as the effects of solute atoms segregating at the interface on the above processes will be investigated and recommendations will be made regarding solute additions that maximally improve the deformation behavior.  

     Dedicated experiments will be carried out at NASA GRC to test the theoretically obtained results. If successful, the proposed project will enable a number of new Air/Space applications for the GRX-810 alloy, e.g., as a structural material for cryogenic liquid hydrogen storage tanks (liquid hydrogen-fueled aircraft technology: under development at NASA GRC, etc.). 

 

     The results of MD/MC simulations heavily depend on the quality of interatomic potential. Our initial choice is the Finnis-Sinclair semi-empirical potentials which are the computationally cheapest reasonable interatomic potentials for metals. However, if we find that this type of potential cannot reproduce our ab initio data obtained within first 3 months, we will switch to machine learning (ML) potentials. 

 

References: 

[1] A.J. Colozza, L. Kohout, Hydrogen storage for aircraft applications overview, 2002. 

[2] T.M. Smith, C.A. Kantzos, N.A. Zarkevich, B.J. Harder, M. Heczko, P.R. Gradl, A.C. Thompson, M.J. Mills, T.P. Gabb, J.W. Lawson, A 3D printable alloy designed for extreme environments, Nature  (2023) 1-6. 

[3] D. Liu, Q. Yu, S. Kabra, M. Jiang, P. Forna-Kreutzer, R. Zhang, M. Payne, F. Walsh, B. Gludovatz, M. Asta, Exceptional fracture toughness of CrCoNi-based medium-and high-entropy alloys at 20 kelvin, Science 378(6623) (2022) 978-983. 

[4] V.V. Borovikov, M.I. Mendelev, T.M. Smith, J.W. Lawson, Dislocation-assisted diffusion-mediated atomic reshuffling in the Kolbe mechanism for micro-twinning in Ni-based superalloys from molecular dynamics simulation, Scripta Materialia 232 (2023) 115475. 

[5] V.V. Borovikov, M.I. Mendelev, T.M. Smith, J.W. Lawson, Molecular dynamics simulation of twin nucleation and growth in Ni-based superalloys, International Journal of Plasticity  (2023) 103645.

column1: Energy Efficient, Out-of-Autoclave Manufacturing of Thermoplastic Composites for Aircraft Structures
column4:
Title: Energy Efficient, Out-of-Autoclave Manufacturing of Thermoplastic Composites for
Aircraft Structures.
Background: Industry enthusiasm around thermoplastic composites (TPCs) is seeing a
resurgence due to the potential for rapid manufacture of large aerospace structures. TPC
matrices differ from the traditionally utilized thermosetting resins in that fabrication of a
thermoplastic (TP) part requires only heating the material above its softening temperature and
applying pressure to consolidate multiple layers of material. Currently, this process requires
consolidation in a press or autoclave. The autoclave process for TPs has a substantial energy
requirement for heating and cooling (processing temperatures are higher for TPs than
thermosets) and autoclave/press consolidation requires non-reusable, consumable materials.
However, opportunity for manufacturing flexibility exists for TPs because the requirement for
consolidating thermoplastics includes only heat and pressure. Of particular interest is out-ofautoclave consolidation.
Problem: Out-of-autoclave or ‘in-situ’ consolidation eliminates the energy intensive
processing step of autoclave or press consolidation. To date, mechanical tests on parts
manufactured by this process have shown a reduction in interlaminar strength. Previous work
at the University of Delaware studied the physical mechanisms controlling laminate quality
during in-situ consolidation by automated fiber placement (AFP). Process variables such as heat
transfer, inter-ply contact time, and void reduction were modeled, tested, and quantified. The
causes of inadequate consolidation were correlated with process, material, and machine
parameters. The study concluded that heat transfer, lay-down speed, and consolidation
pressure were the principle controllable process variables affecting laminate quality. (1,2)
Current AFP and braiding processes do not support the time, temperature or pressure
requirements to allow single-step production of aerospace quality composites.
Has someone tried to solve the problem before. Out-of-autoclave processes have been
attempted and is an area of active research but, to date, has been unsuccessful in meeting the
mechanical properties achievable by traditional processing methods. The issue is partly due to
time, temperature, and pressure requirements as described above. However, this cannot be
the entire story as well-established fusion bonding processes such as induction welding and
ultrasonic welding are very rapid in nature and still yield strong bonds. The fundamental
difference between these welding processes and in-situ consolidation is in the number of
heating and cooling cycles experienced per ply of the TPC during fabrication and consolidation.
When carbon fiber/thermoplastic plies are consolidated the air trapped between those layers is
condensed by the consolidation pressure and absorbed in the matrix. In-situ consolidation by
AFP, for example heats every ply as it is laid down, and several plies beneath. Each time a layer
is reheated, trapped air expands, eventually leading to interlaminar void formation and reduced
interlaminar mechanical properties.
Where did they go wrong/what is different about this approach: There is evidence to suggest
that the issue with current approaches is related to the repeated heating and cooling of 
consecutive plies during laminate fabrication. Work supported through a GRC 2022 Center
Innovation Fund (CIF) has demonstrated that at least 8 plies of a braided preform can be
successfully consolidated in one step by an induction welding approach, with dynamic crush
properties comparable to autoclave consolidated parts.(3) Induction welding is a common
thermoplastic joining technique and is effective for consolidating a braided composite
architecture. Here we propose exploring ultrasonic welding as well, which provides a lower
cost alternative and greater composite design flexibility than the induction welding process. A
New Technology Report was submitted for this manufacturing approach within the NASA GRC
NTR system and the work will be presented at the CAMX conference in Atlanta, GA.
1. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon
completion. We propose a building block approach to demonstrate this technology with
the success metric including (1) laminate consolidation and (2) interlaminar mechanical
properties that are comparable to press or autoclave processed composites.
a. Literature and market survey to assess full environmental impact of in-situ
consolidation.
b. Establish in-house capability for in-situ consolidation.
c. Coupon/Subcomponent Coupon Data: apply building block approach to verify
that consolidation and strength metrics can be met with single-step
consolidation processes. This includes in-situ consolidation and mechanical tests.
d. Budget: Costs for this project are associated with materials, manufacturing, and
test. This includes a contract for welding (out of autoclave consolidation) while
concurrently building the capability in-house. Previous work at GRC has
demonstrated out of autoclave consolidation with induction welding. In this
activity we would like to explore other options.
2. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? Where are the
potential areas for transition? What follow-on research do you anticipate? This work will
establish feasibility of the material class to enable sustainable aviation through reduced
energy manufacturing costs. Next steps include but are not limited to the following.
a. Evaluate feasibility through consolidation of a representative structure, i.e.,
variable thickness and diameter.
b. Manufacture braided subscale fuselage and wings. Explore opportunity to
leverage the AFRL DMAAPS (Design for Manufacture of Attritable Aircraft Primary
Structure) program. In this program the AFRL manufactured a braided fuselage
and wings of a small, UAM size aircraft with an out of autoclave thermosetting
epoxy. Using their tool and design for manufacturing would allow direct
comparison to cost, time, energy savings and consolidation quality of our process
with that of a state-of-the-art material and process.
Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation: Three
months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial 
proposed approach is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining,
how do you pivot? What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?
c. Fusion welding is a well-established process for joining thermoplastic composite
parts. The novelty and risk associated with this proposal is using the fusion
welding processes for consolidation purposes. In the event this is not technically
feasible the project can pivot to documenting the strength and stiffness knockdown inherent to in-situ consolidation with the understanding that the
applications may be acceptable for attritable aircraft and/or unmanned vehicles.
References
1. Gruber, M.B, et. al. “Thermoplastic In-Situ Placement Requires Better Impregnated
Tapes and Tows”, International SAMPE Technical Conference, 2012.
2. Cai, X., “Determination of Process Parameters for the Manufacturing of Thermoplastic
Composite Cones Using Automated Fiber Placement”, Master’s Thesis, Concordia
University, 2012.
3. Cromer, A., et. al., “Consolidation of Braided Carbon Fiber/ Thermoplastic Tubes by
Induction Heating”, The Composites and Advanced Materials Expo (CAMX) Conference,
Atlanta, GA. 2023

column1: High Lift High Load LPT Blade for Hybrid Engine
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT
FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE
Title: High Lift High Load LPT Blade Design for Hybrid Turbine Engines
Problem Statement
Hybrid electric aircraft concepts, in general, offer the potential to downsize the core design of turbine engines, a
concept currently under examination in the HyTEC program. Additionally, they provide operational benefits
influenced by developments through TTT initiative. Both endeavors aim to enhance the efficiency of turbine engine
components while increasing the overall bypass ratio of the aircraft. It is important to acknowledge that there are
inevitable challenges associated with the downsizing of engine components, which must be addressed. While
HyTEC focuses on promptly finding solutions to these challenges for near future, it is imperative to remain mindful
of and proactively tackle the technical difficulties that might affect such efforts for the long term. On the other
hand, new aircraft concepts like SUSAN and STARC-ABL aim to hybridize aircraft operations by employing turbine
engines to power electric machines, thus further increasing the aircraft's overall bypass ratio. In order fully unlock
the potential advantages offered by these conceptual aircraft architectures, it is imperative to comprehend and
address the challenges and potential enhancements that will impact the turbine engine. In the turbine engine, high
pressure, and low-pressure turbines (HPT and LPT) are responsible for providing the energy to run the high
pressure and low-pressure compressors (HPC and LPC) respectively as well as providing excess energy for auxiliary
components of the aircraft. the significance of the turbines, particularly the LPT, should not be underestimated
1
.
Understanding the flow physics in LPT is vital and presents a significant challenge, leading to an intricate design
process. On one hand, the LPT must perform optimally in high Reynolds number (𝑅𝑒) condition near sea level
where maximum loading is required for take-off. On the other hand, the majority of the flight time is spent at high
altitude cruise condition where the air density results in a lower 𝑅𝑒 and lower momentum flow in LPT section2
.
Low-𝑅𝑒 conditions can be particularly troublesome, as the lower momentum flow is prone to separation and
transition effects due to the adverse pressure gradient experienced on the suction surface of the blade. Off-design
operating conditions in the LPT section result in performance degradation due to this flow separation. This
phenomenon known as Reynolds lapse3
can be intensified as the LPT gets smaller due to the smaller core of the
future engines. Also, concepts seeking burning Hydrogen as a fuel will decrease 𝑅𝑒 more and contributing to such
losses even further.
Multiple research efforts have addressed Reynolds lapse in LPTs with the most recent one conducted by air force
research laboratory4
through optimal design of high lift high, high load low pressure turbine blades. All the current
and previous works in this field seek to optimize the design of turbine blades in the traditional setting of gas
turbine engines. The proposed work here seeks to utilize the design work conducted through TTT in Operability
Influenced Design (OID) to investigate the possibility of understanding the design space for high-load high-lift LPT
blades for hybrid electric engines. OID currently focuses on redesigning HPC component of a typical gas turbine
engine by realizing the possible benefits of addition of electric motors to the engine enabled by Turbine Electrified
Energy Management (TEEM) concept.
Through this design practice it became evident that high-load blade design and optimization of turbine and
compressor blades is required to fully realize any possible benefits which can be enabled by such control concepts
or use of novel fuels such as hydrogen. Investigating such design spaces requires utilizing tools to allow for correct
estimation of the flow field and flow transition that occurs at low-𝑅𝑒 in LPT. NASA currently lacks such crucial tools 
and thus is incapable of conducting thorough analysis on the blade design to investigate correct benefits of these
technologies on the engine components. OID mostly benefits the design of the compressor section which is tied to
LPT and HPT closely. Moreover, there are similarities in the design process which can be translated from the
turbine section to the compressor section.
This work will to investigate the feasibility of designing high-load high-lift LPT blades for hybrid-electric aircrafts in
cooperation with air force research laboratory through a one-year effort. Through this design process, significant
expertise and blade design capability will be transferred to NASA work force.
Approach
The work will be divided in three phases with each contributing to a milestone.
Milestone 1 [2 months from actual start date (AS)]: The requirements for the LPT blade design will be identified
using a NASA 𝐸
3
engine as a relevant open system which can be applied to both NASA OID effort and power
extraction technical challenge under HyTEC. This milestone will be completed by defining the loading at each stage
of the LPT according to a high lift, high load blade design approach. This milestone will be completed by providing a
detailed requirements for each blade row of the 𝐸
3
LPT. The substantial volume of data accessible for this engine
design guarantees a high level of confidence in achieving this milestone.
Milestone 2 [10 months from AS]: The first stage LPT blade design space will be explored based on the
requirements identified in milestone 1. Turbine Design and Analysis System (TDAAS) will be used in this effort. It is
a tool currently utilized by air force research laboratory to perform similar type of analysis for traditional turbine
engines. TDAAS uses an airfoil generator along with a grid generator and flow solver to build the workflow for
blade design. The various first stage LPT blade designs generated through this system will be evaluated
aerodynamically first along with physical buildability. This milestone will be completed by designing the first stage
blades for a hybrid-electric high-lift high-load LPT. In the event that we do not fully attain this milestone, it will
provide us with a deeper understanding of the technical hurdles associated with LPT design necessitated by a
reduction in the engine core size. This, in turn, will guide us in pinpointing areas for future research focus.
Nevertheless, as a positive outcome, NASA stands to gain valuable expertise in blade design and optimization,
which will prove indispensable for numerous ongoing research initiatives, including but not limited to addressing
power extraction technical challenge in the HyTEC project, OID, SUSAN, and endeavors related to thermal
management for energy extraction from the engine core.
Milestone 3 [12 months from AS]: The blade design achieved in milestone 2 will inform the researchers on the
feasibility of the high lift, high load blade design for the other four stages of the LPT. While a thorough redesign of
the blades is required to accurately assess any possible benefits in LPT, it will not be in the scope of this work.
However, analytical methods can be utilized to estimate such benefits and investigate the possibility of reducing
the stages in this LPT. This milestone will provide an analysis of the overall benefits to the LPT design through the
analysis of the engine system with a redesigned LPT in NPSS. If Milestone 2 is successfully accomplished, this task
can be carried out using analytical methods based on the principles of turbomachinery design. However, if the
second milestone is only partially achieved or not completed, it will provide valuable insights into the system-level
constraints when designing high-load LPTs. This, in turn, will enhance the realism of evaluating new aircraft or
engine concepts.
Upon its successful conclusion, this endeavor will primarily enable NASA to acquire the knowledge and resources
essential for in-depth blade design of turbine engine components. While initially the licenses for software in this 
effort should be purchased, it is the goal of this work to subsequently integrate these methodologies with NASA's
internal tools, including NPSS, OTAC, FUN3D, and others, to empower researchers in the design or redesign of
turbomachinery blades. This approach will facilitate the development of innovative conceptual architectures and
the tools required to effectively evaluate potential advantages stemming from new technologies. Furthermore,
this work will offer valuable insights for the OID and SUSAN projects, as well as forthcoming projects focused on
the assessment of new fuels and engine concepts.
Special Scenario
"If it proves unfeasible to design new high-lift, high-load blades, the project can easily shift its focus towards the
redesign of the compressor within the OID work. This effort aimed to develop a new HPC design for the 𝐸
3
by
leveraging the advantages of adding electric machines to the engine. In this context, the ongoing work can
reallocate its resources to delve deeper into the aforementioned effort, exploring the redesign of one or multiple
stages within the new HPC concept. While the primary goal of this effort is to attain expertise and tools for blade
design, it will still contribute to the project's success.
References
1. Walker, G.J., 1993. The role of laminar-turbulent transition in gas turbine engines: A discussion.
2. McQuilling, M.W., 2007. Design and validation of a high-lift low-pressure turbine blade (Doctoral dissertation,
Wright State University).
3. Wisler, D.C., 1998, June. The technical and economic relevance of understanding boundary layer transition in gas
turbine engines. In Minnowbrook II, 1997 Workshop on Boundary Layer Transition in Turbomachines (pp. 53-64).
NASA/CP-1998-206958.
4. Clark, J.P., Paniagua, G. and Cukurel, B., 2023, June. On the Development of High Lift, High Work Low-Pressure
Turbines. In Turbo Expo: Power for Land, Sea, and Air (Vol. 87097, p. V13BT30A029). American Society of
Mechanical Engineers.

column1: Dual Hydrogen-Jet Fuel Aircraft - a path to zero emissions
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL
Title: Dual Hydrogen-Jet Fuel Aircraft – a path to zero emissions
1. The work will build upon the dual hydrogen-jet fuel aircraft concept first demonstrated
in 1956 to enable a path to low emissions, which reduced demands on renewable energy and
infrastructure, towards zero emissions. The dual hydrogen-jet fuel aircraft concept retains the
wing tanks and economically adds hydrogen to a 737-class single aisle offloading Jet A to retain
the same range enabling flexible aircraft operations and paths forward. Dual Hydrogen-Jet Fuel
aircraft with only 2080km of zero emission range, or 30% hydrogen by energy can reduce
emissions by 50% can be raised to an astonishing 97.5% at lower and more stable fuel costs
than SAF and Jet A. The low energy per unit volume of hydrogen introduces significant aviation
challenges for 100% LH2 fueled aircraft to economically meet the stringent mass, volume, and
safety requirements and the first order optimum is ~30% LH2 by energy. The 97.5% U.S.
emissions reduction will require a change in the airline business model.
The dual hydrogen-jet fuel concept is a significant departure from the 2021 U.S. Aviation
Climate Action Plan based on drop-in carbon-based Sustainable Aviation Fuels (SAF) and most
importantly, is not a ‘farther term technology” that also retains the current Aero portfolio to
offset increases in cost. The U.S. Climate Action Plan stated that there was no expectation that
LH2 aircraft would make a significant contribution towards achieving net-zero emissions by
2050. The much slower adoption of hydrogen fuel was also based primarily upon the need to
access renewable energy and to develop ground storage and distribution systems, and to a
lesser extent, upon the need mature electric and hydrogen technologies and to tackle several
other technical and safety challenges. The 2020 European Hydrogen Aircraft study cited a
derived need for ~4300GW for 100% SAF vs 1450 GW for 100% LH2--likely overlooked--while
30% LH2 would require 435 GW, a ten-fold decrease, but must add back liquefaction energy. By
relying on off-grid and excess energy, LH2 production will not have to rely on grid provided
renewable energy. Note that plant based SAF may only achieve 25% carbon emission
reduction, ~4X less than carbon free hydrogen and SAF via direct air capture.
At present, 2050 SAF goals are unstainable beyond ‘not achieving the net-zero by 2050
goal’. In general, limited supply SAF (HEFA) is the lowest cost while unbounded supply based on
direct air capture [a massive green prize] plus green LH2 (PtL/e-kerosene) is the highest cost
fuel. SAF’s have predicted costs 2-10x the cost of Jet A, creating a significant risk to national
and world security, in an attempt to limit aircraft and infrastructure modifications, besides
incorrectly assuming SAF would require less renewable energy and that off-grid, excess
renewable energy is not available, which would favor hydrogen.
The U.S. Climate Action Plan correctly identified that Aviation *must change the fuel* to
meet net zero goals and that technology alone showcased in the in EPFD and TTBW/X-66A
demonstrators would *not* be sufficient. In *contrast*, hydrogen aircraft would become the
pull technology in fewer higher energy locations to help eliminate grid bottlenecks and reduce
emissions in the hard to decarbonize industries. In contrast, rather than remove fuselage and
engines from a MD-90 to form the TTBW/X66A, adding hydrogen tanks could fly the same
number of PAX with hydrogen plumbed to the rear-mounted engines. The Airbus A380 LH2
demonstrator adds a 3rd hydrogen engine cantilevered from the fuselage along with the
hydrogen fuel system and tank. In contrast, while the truss braced wing is an excellent design
for battery and 100% hydrogen aircraft since ~no energy will be carried in the wings, the lower
amount of jet fuel carried must be further considered in a dual hydrogen-jet fuel concept.
In the proposed work, hydrogen must be approached from a systems level, because it
won’t work unless you have all the pieces to make it work from an operating system. Since
hydrogen production results from off-grid and/or excess renewable energy, dual fuel does not
have to be dependent on grid green energy and wait 30 years. Conversely, objectives are
achieved when a bottoms-up understanding of the assumptions, physics, and resources
including those outside NASA’s domain are tracked, compared, and traded versus
vehicle/system goals requiring proper communication/insight, including what happens when
projects are not priorities or technology risks are not properly identified, and subsystems are
not compatible. Safety cannot be assessed without integrated designs and hardware. Indeed,
many others recognize one must limit the need for renewable energy and potential
infrastructure buildup and dual fuel enables aircraft flexibility across the globe while
significantly reducing emissions economically. UH: “Boeing and Airbus are likely to develop a
replacement for these venerable models (single aisles dominated by the B737 and A320) for
entry into service in the mid-2030s. The only way aviation can meet Paris Agreement emissions
targets is if the new single aisle airplanes are hydrogen powered.” “A hydrogen single aisle
does not need to be a radical new design” an unstretched MD-90 or a ‘Transatlantic Concept’
flying the same number of PAX as a A320 needs to be examined, as well as adding the
unducted fan/ultra-high-bypass engine, to name but a few paths to explore.
A 100% hydrogen powered aircraft increases fuel volume over four-fold versus a
conventional aircraft occupying cargo and passenger space, while 30% hydrogen by energy can
provide 50 to 97.5% reduction in emissions via 2080km of zero emissions range to tackle the
easy part of the range sooner and more economically with 9 times less energy than ekerosine/Power-to-Liquid (plus liquefaction energy) at 2 to 10 times less cost than SAF.
The dual fuel concept--ready for short term demonstrations as there are no insurmountable
problems--opens up the design space for further out technologies including those beyond NASA
and all of the areas identified in this Green Aviation New work: Alternative Propulsion, Aircraft
Design, Materials and Manufacturing, Air Traffic Management, Emission Control, Sustainable
Infrastructure, and Contrail Formation requiring $100Ms not $M.
Dual Hydrogen-Jet Fuel aircraft with 14% hydrogen by weight can reduce emissions safely
by 50 to 97.5% to supplement SAF reductions at less costs, and more importantly, will reduce
demands on renewable energy and infrastructure. The work will perform studies of the dual 
hydrogen-jet fuel concepts and many key components, describe key SAF challenges and
limitations, outline the pathways, challenges, and infrastructure changes for dual fuel aircraft
and technologies to speed the transition safely and economically to beyond net zero.
2. The work will further examine the strengths and weaknesses of the dual fuel concept to
reduce emissions by 50% sooner and more economically than SAF within the time frame of the
award and resources provided. Benefits and opportunities for dual hydrogen-jet fuel electric
propulsion will be described. The milestone is to provide sufficient justification that leads to a
demonstration path or to be unlikely usurped by alternative approaches. Many innovative
design details and the 97.5% justification are not described due to proposal limits but will be
further developed as bottoms up design is required for system assessments, to address safety.
3. The limited resource Green Aviation New Work is only a path to zero emissions which
will require $Bs to place aircraft into service, identify the limitations and hence opportunities
for further R&D in an expanded design space that transcends NASA—a significant effort beyond
the PI abilities to raise the TRL. Before this work is completed, NASA could outsource the same
work to a University Led Initiative, add a task to the Truss Braced Wing Demonstrator, have
another organization help develop a key technology( e.g., tanks), or collaborate further with
other agencies to develop the infrastructure, to name just a few.
4. If the concepts are not technically feasible, it then creates the opportunity to examine
or ignore alternatives and/or breakdown current approach to the key challenges likely
presenting opportunities to other disciplines. Proposal constraints prevents addressing many
detailed design issues. Innovation occurs when folks presented with a problem ask, ‘how may
we look at this differently’. How one pivots depends on many factors, but especially on how
complete the current approach was examined. With so many areas to investigate listed above,
it will require a re-examination of the path forward to first expand and then contract the trade
space with data. Another factor is that SMEs are not always correct, and often do not present
limitations clearly, so it’s important to understand the rationale for this assessment, especially
if new data/methods and/or a breakthrough overcomes the limitation.
In the case of dual fuel, the most obvious alternative approach is SAF via DAC that becomes
sustainable or funded by DOD for National Security, which is only a small fraction of NASA
domain, so this is a limited opportunity. A logical pivot would be toward technology to reduce
fuel burn to reduce resources required for zero emissions. The pivot would have to make an
impact since there are no rewards for failure in a very mature and challenging industry since
the story being told in general is that one shifts to line or project management. Further
developing AI, propulsion, electrical, materials, and other discipline and technology skills almost
always help develop paths forward so will also be included in the pivot options-perhaps better
than let the team understand that path forward is unlikely.

column1: Computational Design of Superconductors for Superconducting Aircraft Propulsion Motors
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT
FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE
INSTRUCTIONS
Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name.
Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger.
Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission
and do not need to be addressed in this template.
RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW
Title: Computational Design of Superconductors for Superconducting Aircraft Propulsion Motors
1. Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated
benefits). Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant): What problem are you
solving? Has someone tried to solve this problem before? Where did they go
wrong? What is different about your approach? If no one has attempted to solve this
problem before, why not? How does your proposed work transform current capabilities,
tools/methods or state-of-the art approaches? If successful, what does your proposed work
enable that currently is unattainable? Please include references/citations to back up claims
where appropriate.
All electric airflights offer climate-neutral aviation by greatly reducing carbon emission [1]. However, the
traditional electric motor is limited by its power density, i.e., the power to weight ratio. Superconducting
aircraft propulsion motors have the potential of achieving power densities 2-3 times the state of the art for
machines in the megawatt (MW) or larger class with > 99% efficiency [2]. This requires superconductors
to carry very strong current, and therefore, the superconductor coils [3,4] must be kept well below its
superconducting critical temperature. Currently, the high-temperature superconductors (HTSCs), in
particular, cuprates (such as GdBa2Cu3O7 films) [5] are used in such motors and must be cooled to below
20 K by liquid hydrogen, although their critical temperatures are well above 77 K, the boiling point of
nitrogen. However, liquid hydrogen is not only expensive but also poses a substantial risk to safety.
Previous researches in this field have been focused on designing new structures of the superconducting
motors while employing the existing cuprate HTSCs. Though this approach has led to operational
superconducting motors with much improved energy to weight ratio compared with the traditional ones,
the target MW and larger class are still beyond reach without considering new superconductors which can
carry stronger current and/or at higher temperatures. Such researches on new superconductors require
totally different technical expertise than what the engineering groups working on this filed usually have.
In this project, we propose to computationally design novel superconductors, in addition to current
researches on designing novel motor structures. The combination of these two approaches has the potential
of reaching the desired energy density at a much higher output power scale. Furthermore, previous
theoretical researches [6] on superconductors have been mostly dedicated on predicting the critical
temperatures �!, and very few efforts [7,8] have been spent to consider and calculate the critical current
density as a function of temperature and to find out superconductors with higher critical current. 
Technically, the critical current density �(�) has the same temperature dependence as that of the
superconducting gap amplitude Δ(�), and Δ(�) can be obtained theoretically by solving the coupled
integration equations for superconducting and total charge densities, respectively, which are a direct
consequence of the well-known mean-field BCS theory [9]. To obtain �(�) and Δ(�), firstly, one has to
calculate the critical temperature �!, which depends on a number of physical quantities according to the
BCS relation and the McMillan’s analysis [10]:
�! = �
1.45 exp /− 1 + �
� − �∗(1 + 0.62�)
7
#.%&
.
Here � is the Debye temperature, �∗ the Coulomb repulsion, and � the electron-phonon coupling constant.
These three key quantities are also needed to obtain the parameters in the coupled integration equations.
We note that nowadays �, �∗ and � can be computed by solving the quantum mechanical equations (first-
-principles electronic structure calculations) routinely and accurately, and the calculated �! based on the
above McMillian’s expression can be quantitatively comparable with the measured data. Thus, a
breakthrough has been made in superconductivity research, and one prominent example is the experimental
discoveries of the high-T superconductor SH3 under high pressure after the first-principles calculations
were carried out. In 2014, Duan et al. [11] predicted �! of 200 K under a pressure of 160-200 GPa for SH3,
while in 2015 Drozdov et al. [12] measured �! of 203 K under 160 GPa.
Besides first-principles calculations, machine learning and data mining [13] have been successfully applied
to find new superconductors and to determine their �! [14]. Our group members have employed, tailored
and developed both first-principles and high-throughput computational tools to compute lattice vibrations
(phonons) and electron-phonon coupling in metals and insulators. These tools can be used to accurately
evaluate �, �∗ and � and to fast screen materials by efficiently estimating these quantities. Furthermore,
our group members have used machine learning and data mining methods to study battery materials and
biomaterials, and this expertise is directly transferrable for superconductor research.
Superconductivity research requires close collaborations
between theory and experiments since theory alone or
experiments alone are prone to errors and false claims
[15,16]. Our experimental collaborator, Prof. Chen in
University of Houston, is a world-renowned expert on
HTSC and topological superconductors [17-19].
Combining our theory/computation and their materials
synthesis and characterization will be the key for us to
find out superconductors which can carry stronger
electric current at higher T for making aircraft motors.
As summarized in Figure 1 on the right, there exist five
different types of superconductors forming more than
12,000 known superconductors listed in the SuperCon
database [20]. Guided by the existing data, known
empirical rules and experimental observations, we will
employ the high-throughput screening and machine
learning and data mining to find out potential candidates.
Then we will apply the accurate first-principles methods
to compute �' and �(�) for these materials. Finally, our
theoretical findings of the most promising candidates will
be synthesized and measured by our experimental collaborators.
Fig. 1: The major advances in superconductivity vs year [6].
2. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion.
During the first year of the work, we will focus solely on employing, developing, and examining firstprinciples methods to calculate the superconducting critical temperature �! and the critical current density
�(�). As mentioned previously, methods to compute the associated crucial physical quantities of �, �∗ and
� have been implemented in many popular first-principles programs such as VASP [21] and ABINIT [22],
but we need to program the code to solve the coupled integration equations to obtain the superconducting
gap amplitude, Δ(�), and then �(�). However, reaching the desired accuracy for �∗ and � is still very
challenging, since multiple approximations are involved and we need to carefully examine these
approximate models and numerical convergence for different types of superconductors. Some existing
models need to be further improved or simplified to increase accuracy or efficiency so that these quantities
can be calculated within certain tolerable errors and reasonable computation cost.
The anticipated milestones are the errors in the calculated critical current and critical temperature are
within 50% and 25%, respectively, compared with experimental data for a few prototypical superconductors
belonging to five different types as illustrated in Figure 1, with particular emphasis on calculating and
comparing critical current for superconductors currently used in superconducting aircraft motors.
3. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? Where are the
potential areas for transition? What follow-on research do you anticipate?
After this work is finished, we shall possess the computational capabilities of accurately evaluating the
critical current density in different types of superconductors from first principles. Next, we will employ and
develop the high-throughput tools to compute these quantities, so that we can do fast screening among the
existing 12,000 superconductors and novel possible compositions. The machine learning and data mining
methods will also be built and tested, as an alternative approach to find out potential candidates for further
theoretical investigations using the first-principles methods. Then we will combine these computational
approaches with experimental measurements to find out either existing or new superconductors, which can
carry twice of the maximum current the present HTSC films can do and/or which can carry the same
maximum current as before at temperatures higher than 77 K. Twice of maximum current would increase
the output power density of the aircraft motors by 300%.
4. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation: Three
months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial
proposed approach is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining,
how do you pivot? What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?
After three months into this work, if we find that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically,
we will first identify the cause. The approach based on first-principles calculations that we described in the
first session has been implemented in many codes and has been tested for numerous superconductors with
varying degrees of accuracy on the calculated �!. Large errors in �! normally means that the calculated �,
�∗ and � are not sufficiently accurate, which will also severely affect the accuracy in the predicted �(�),
when solving the coupled integration equations.
The Deby temperature � normally can be predicted very accurately, while the Coulomb repulsion �∗ and
electron-phonon coupling constant � are much harder to be obtained with sufficient accuracy. We will (1)
examine and improve the theoretical models and numerical convergence; (2) use machine learning and data
mining techniques to obtain these two values from the SuperCon database and other existing theoretical
results and measured data; (3) employ phenomenological models, which are based on physics
considerations, but whose parameters are often fitted to measured data.
References:
[1] J. Rohacs and D. Rohacs. Energy coefficients for comparison of aircraft supported by different
propulsion systems. Energy 191, 116391 (2020).
[2] O. Keysan, D. Olczak and M. A. Mueller. A modular superconducting generator for offshore wind
turbines. J. Supercond. Novel Magn. 26, 2103 (2013).
[3] L. Tomkow, I. M. Harca, K. Machaj, A. Smara, T. Reis and B. A. Glowacki. Experimental system
for testing a superconducting motor at temperatures close to 15 K. Cryogenics 112, 103206 (2020).
[4] F. Weng, M. Zhang, T. Lan, Y. Wang and W. Yuan. Fully superconducting machine for electric
aircraft propulsion: study of AC loss for HTS stator. Supercond. Sci. Technol. 33, 104002 (2020).
[5] F. Grilli et al. Superconducting motors for aircraft propulsion: the Advanced Superconducting Motor
Experimental Demonstrator project. J. Phys.: Conf. Ser. 1590, 012051 (2020).
[6] W. E. Pickett. Colloquium: Room temperature superconductivity: The roles of theory and materials
design. Rev. Mod. Phys. 95, 021001 (2023).
[7] D. Dew-Hughes. The critical current of superconductors: an historical review. Low Temp. Phys. 27,
967 (2001).
[8] J. Samuel Millán, J. Millán, L. A. Pérez and H. S. Ruiz. Critical Current Density in d-Wave Hubbard
Superconductors. Materials 15, 8969 (2022).
[9] L. A. Pérez, J. S. Millán and C. Wang. Spin singlet and triplet superconductivity induced by
correlated hopping interactions. Int. J. Mod. Phys. B 24, 5229–5239 (2010).
[10] W. L. McMillan. Transition temperature of strong-coupled superconductors. Phys. Rev. 167, 331
(1968).
[11] D. Duan, Y. Liu, F. Tian, D. Li, X. Huang, Z. Zhao, H. Yu, B. Liu, W. Tian and T. Cui. Pressureinduced metalization of dense (H2S)2H2 with high-Tc superconductivity. Sci. Rep. 4, 6968 (2014).
[12] A. P. Drozdov, M. I. Eremets, I. A. Troyan, V. Ksenofontovand and S. I. Shylin. Conventional
superconductivity at 203 kelvin at high pressures in the sulphur hydride system. Nature (London)
525, 73 (2015).
[13] V. Stanev, C. Oses, A.G. Kusne, E. Rodriguez, J. Paglione, S. Curtarolo, and I. Takeuchi. Machine
learning modeling of superconducting critical temperature. npj Comput. Mater. 4, 29 (2018).
[14] M. J. Hutcheon, A. M. Shipley, and R. J. Needs. Predicting novel superconducting hydrides using
machine learning approaches. Phys. Rev. B 101, 144505 (2020).
[15] E. Snider et al. RETRACTED ARTICLE: Room-temperature superconductivity in a carbonaceous
sulfur hydride. Nature 586, 373–377 (2020).
