column1: Enhanced Aerogel Composites for Lithium-Ion Battery Performance Safety and Efficiency (ECLIPSE)
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT 

FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE 

INSTRUCTIONS 

Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name. 

Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger. 

Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission and do not need to be addressed in this template.  

RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW 

Title: Enhanced Aerogel Composites for Lithium-Ion Battery Performance Safety and Efficiency (ECLIPSE) 

PROJECT DESCRIPTION: 

Concern over climate change has created an opportunity and need to target new aircraft technologies for the next generation of single-aisle airliners which account for greater than 50% of worldwide aviation emissions. NASA Projects such as the Sustainable Flight Demonstrator (SFD) and the Electrified Powertrain Flight Demonstration (EPFD) are tasked with the development of technology and designs for aircraft to meet greener low emission objectives and enable a new generation of electric-powered aircraft. Within the electrified aircraft propulsion (EAP) technologies under EPFD, higher efficiency batteries are of significant interest. Over the past few decades, battery technologies have seen exceptional advancement, however, thermal control and thermal runaway continues to be a challenge.  To combat this issue, an advanced material with phase change capability is necessary to absorb or redirect thermal energy during normal operation and protect cells from the extreme heat produced during a thermal runaway event. One such potential material is a Phase Change-Polymer Aerogel Composite (PCPAC), which will offer the advantages of a typical aerogel such as extremely low density (~ 0.1 g/cm3),1 high porosity (> 95%),2 high specific surface area (500–1,000 m2/g),3 and mechanical strength4. 

 
 
Current methods for thermal management and thermal runaway prevention impose a significant weight penalty. Current assumptions when designing an energy storage system for electric aircraft state that 30% of the overall mass of the system is the packaging of the batteries, which includes the methods of thermal management and thermal runaway propagation prevention. To achieve a realistic solution for electrified aircraft, 400 Watt hours/kilogram (Wh/kg) at the battery module level is the minimum energy density limit. Current Lithium-Ion cells have an energy density of up to 250 Wh/kg, giving an energy density of 175 Wh/kg at the battery module. As energy densities at the battery cell level increase, the weight penalty will remain, and possibly even increase based on the advanced cell chemistry characteristics.   Aluminum is mainly used as a thermal and physical barrier between cells and has a density of 2.7 g/cm3. Replacing some of the aluminum used for packaging with a low-density aerogel (0.1 g/cm3) will allow for substantial weight savings and a decreased percentage of parasitic mass for the battery module while also acting as an effective thermal management material and a lightweight barrier to thermal runaway propagation. 
 

In this study we will demonstrate a new approach to 3D printing polyimide aerogel composites with phase change material capability using the facile, cost-effective process of direct ink writing (DIW) without the need for extreme conditions or additional post-processing steps. This will be accomplished by using a dual-head syringe to print the high temperature resistant polymer aerogel in combination with the target temperature polymer to infiltrate the pores whereby the aerogel acts as a host system for the phase change material. Expanding access to non-moldable complex structures via 3D printing will enable aerogels to insulate more complex arrangements of electronic components. Looking forward, the use of custom-fit aerogels for lightweight thermal insulation of batteries can facilitate electric vehicle and electric aviation applications. 

References: 

P. R. Aravind, P. Shajesh, G. D. Soraru and K. G. K. Warrier, J. Sol-Gel Sci. Technol., 2010, 54, 105–117 

S. L. Vivod, M. Ann B. Meador, C. Pugh, M. Wilkosz, K. Calomino and L. McCorkle, ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces, 2020, 12, 8622–8633. 

S. L. Vivod, M. A. B. Meador, A. Shinko, S. C. Jana, and C. Pugh, US Pat., 10800883B1, 2020. 

S. Malakooti, S. L. Vivod, M. Pereira, C. R. Ruggeri, D. M. Revilock, D. A. Scheiman, H. Guo, J. A. Salem, O. Benafan and J. C. Johnston, Compos. Part B Eng., 2023, 260, 110751 

 

MILESTONES/DELIVERABLES 

PCPAC-Phase Change Polymer Aerogel Composite 

It is anticipated that this project will consist of two main objectives: the creation of a phase change polymer aerogel composite and designing a method to 3D print the materials for enhanced battery operation in electric aircraft. All polymer synthesis will be verified via typical characterization methods to determine thermal conductivity, density, mechanical strength, and resistance to target temperatures. The 3D printed structure will be evaluated by the ability to enhance performance of the target battery. The milestones are as follows: 

Milestone 

Title 

Description 

Timeline post award 

1 

Baseline feasibility study 

Entails deep dive into current SOA materials for enhanced battery life followed by a comparison study of baseline aerogels. This sets the key performance parameters to target for the PCPAC 

1-3 months 

2 

PCPAC Optimization study 

Baseline study of polymer aerogels with target properties and downselect of optimal formulation compatible with phase change material 

2-6 months 

3 

3D print Optimal PCPAC 

Investigate various methods for synthesis and printing PCPAC 

5-9 months 

4 

Analysis of printed material with battery 

Test final material in relevant environment to include battery discharge and thermal runaway testing 

7-11 months 

5 

Final report 

Compilation of data and final material deliverable 

Final month 

 

INFUSION: 

Applications such as Solid-state batteries are particularly promising due to their wide temperature stability resulting from the removal of volatile organic liquid electrolytes. However, lower room-temperature ionic conductivity and poor interfacial contact currently limits the use of solid-state electrolytes for high performance applications. These limitations can be mitigated by increasing the operating temperature, thus increasing the ionic conductivity. As such, the ability to maintain high temperature throughout operation is critical for harnessing solid-state batteries for electric aviation, and lightweight, custom-fit aerogel insulators have potential to address this concern. This application has direct correlation with TTT Convergent Aeronautic Solutions’ projects Solid-state Architecture Batteries for Enhanced Rechargeability and Safety for Electric Aircraft (SABERS) and Electrified Powertrain Flight Demonstration (EPFD). The successful outcome of this proposed work would directly impact commercial electrified aircraft as well as have significant interest to other mission directorates such as SMD and STMD.  

Project Viability 

In the event that the viability of this material does not meet our key performance parameters early on, the possibilities of using alternative chemistries are vast. The structure of the polyimide aerogel that will house the phase change material has been demonstrated through a suite of patents which lends to a high level of confidence for its success. The phase change material can be made from a myriad of chemistries targeting various temperatures. The intention is to perform an optimization study for just this purpose. The study will easily shift to different methods of synthesis or 3D printing if needed.

column1: Thermal Management System Trade Study and Analysis for Hydrogen Fuel Cell Aircraft
column4:
Title: Thermal Management System Trade Study and Analysis for Hydrogen Fuel Cell Aircraft
1. NASA’s Aeronautics Research Mission Directorate (ARMD) recently published their updated Strategic
Implementation Plan which calls for increasing focus on sustainable aviation and achieving net-zero CO2
emissions by 2050. Alternative propulsion is an area of specific interest, and one method involves
hydrogen fuel cells. Through NASA’s ongoing Commercially-viable Hydrogen Aircraft for Reduction of
Greenhouse Emissions (CH2ARGE) project, this technology is thoroughly being assessed through different
aircraft design cycles. This project focuses on medium range aircraft with around 180 passengers and a
range of about 2,500 nmi, which falls into the category of short-medium range aircraft that generate about
two-thirds of the CO2 emissions generated by this industryi
.
There are different types of fuel cells, but the basic idea is that by reacting both hydrogen and oxygen gas,
one can produce power with water and heat as byproducts; therefore, if designed properly, the aircraft
can be a net-zero CO2 emitter. A significant obstacle to adopting fuel cells as a power source for aircraft is
that the thermal management system (TMS) must handle multiple challenges. A benefit of fuel cells is
that they are ~50 %, which is higher than the ~30 % efficiency of the traditional jet engine cycle. However,
unlike traditional aircraft, the hot gases generated by the propulsion system don’t just exit through the
back of the engine; rather, in fuel cell systems, the heat is contained in the fuel cell stack and must be
conducted out and either dissipated or put to good use supporting a secondary system. This becomes
problematic as the propulsion system for a mid-size aircraft will require 20 – 25 MW of power, meaning
that the fuel cells will be producing about 10 MW of heat. Ample consideration must also be given to the
quality of heat generated, since heat dissipation to the surroundings becomes more difficult and complex
as the ambient air becomes warmer.
Another significant challenge is that the aircraft’s high energy-dense hydrogen fuel has cryogenic needs
to be operationally feasible. The design of a relevant TMS would require significant consideration for
hydrogen boil-off, refrigeration, insulation, and others, since all are nontrivial technical challenges that
will substantially impact the TMS design. However, the potential a cryogenic hydrogen fuel offers is also
promising, as this opens multiple design paths not offered in traditional aircraft. For example, the TMS
could leverage any boil-off from the tank to condition or further cool critical aircraft components and
potentially open the doors towards super-conducting applications.
All the above are complex problems that must be addressed for net-zero CO2 emissions in aviation to be
successful, which is why it is important that NASA address this problem now. We have conducted a survey
on the different TMS used by various NASA-funded internal and academic projects of similar electrical
scaleii, iii, iv, vand have found the above issues to be consistent challenges facing the industry with increasing
electrification. Promising technologies that would enable a hydrogen fuel cell aircraft include using
oscillating heat pipe spreaders on the aircraft skin vi
, using liquid hydrogen flow loops to cool
componentsvii
, and using thermal storage devicesviii in conjunction with more traditional pumped-fluid
loopsix
.
Despite the many technologies mentioned above, the design of the TMS has consistently been found to
be a major area requiring development that lacks the appropriate priority in the design cycle of aircraft –
it is consistently an afterthought that results in severe performance penalties. With increasing
electrification, the TMS system must now be designed in-tandem with other major systems to develop a
viable aircraft system. To efficiently design a hydrogen aircraft's TMS, we propose developing a novel
design tool that will integrate TMS design with the design of the electrical power system and the
cryogenic hydrogen storage system. This tool will serve as a framework upon which different sizing and 
analysis tools, such as the in-house developed Electrical Power System – Sizing and Analysis Tool (EPSSAT)
x
, will be integrated to enable the iterative co-design of the TMS, power management and distribution
(PMAD) system, and cryogenic system architectures. The flexibility enabled by this tool will allow for the
quick sizing of components while also providing estimates on important performance parameters such as
TMS mass, volume, area required, drag and power penalties for mid-size aircraft, which to the best of
knowledge has not been done before.
This tool will enable us to conduct a trade study on aircraft fuel cell systems operating in two different
temperature regimes: under 100 oC and between 100 - 200 oC. These temperature ranges correspond to
low temperature PEM, a more mature technology, and high temperature PEM, still in the development
phase, fuel cell technology. The trade study will identify and evaluate various TMS architectures and
interfaces, identify design drivers and technology gaps, and identify bounds and industry standards that
will guide the TMS design. Our analysis will identify high priority test cases for each temperature range
with a focus on system mass, volume, and parasitic power requirements. In addition, it will also be used
to inform a more targeted investigation into more effective technologies for cooling large fuel cell stacks.
Our team is proposing to investigate several enabling technologies that could benefit hydrogen fuel cell
aircraft, such as: outer-mold line cooling enabled by oscillating heat pipes; using high-conductivity heat
spreaders; using passive components like conventional heat pipes; using phase-change materials to
handle transients; storing heat in the fuel, and using the product water from the fuel cell as a heat sink.
The balance of plant components, including the cryogenic fuel storage and conditioning system, and the
PMAD system will also be evaluated to provide a more realistic understanding of the TMS.
2. The milestones from this work result in a final deliverable of a TMS level design tool for low and high
temperature PEM fuel cell hydrogen aircraft. We will deliver two completed TMS trade studies for fuel
cells operating in the temperature ranges mentioned above. This will provide NASA with an understanding
of what fuel cell operating temperature range is most promising with regard to the TMS and allow us to
identify components that will require further development. These milestones are described in detail
below:
The first milestone will be to define the design space and to identify and gather standards that will guide
the design of a hydrogen fuel cell aircraft TMS. We will identify and baseline a mission profile and identify
a range of environmental conditions that a hydrogen fuel cell aircraft will experience under both nominal
and off-nominal conditions. Major components and interfaces within the TMS will subsequently be
identified, with operational limits defined to bound the design space. [Completed Month 2]
The second milestone is to develop system-level models of the TMS, PMAD, and cryogenic storage
systems for a hydrogen fuel cell aircraft. As a result of there being two different fuel cell ranges in this
proposal, there will subsequently be two different TMS designed and evaluated to span the operational
temperature ranges. It follows that each model will determine how heat is extracted and transported
from each aircraft component, and then ultimately rejected to the surrounding air. Enabling technologies
identified from our survey and other literature willsubsequently be subjected to the intense trade studies
that follow from this design cycle. Ultimately, this will result in optimal configurations for each TMS. Both
the PMAD and cryogenic models will be generated through collaboration with the CH2ARGE project,
where efforts are already being made to design and interface these systems through existing tools such
as EPS-SAT, which was created and used in other NASA aircraft projects. [Completed Month 9]
The third milestone is to evaluate the two different TMS developed in milestone 2 and subject them to a
baseline mission profile and nominal/off nominal conditions and provide estimates on parameters
important to a larger aircraft study. These parameters will include mass, parasitic power, and the TMS
efficiency. A significant outcome of this effort will be the identification of design drivers and technology 
gaps that must be addressed to make hydrogen aircraft feasible. Therefore, potential critical components
will be identified and assigned performance requirements to be enabling technologies for hydrogen fuel
cell aircraft. [Completed Month 12]
3. There are many possible paths for follow-on research upon completion of this project. A major goal of this
study is to identify technology gaps and uncertainties for fuel cell-based propulsion systems. This could
include exploring different fuel cell materials and stack designs, deep dives into various TMS and
components, detailed investigation of components within the cryogenic fluids management system, or
the need to further explore innovative cycle architectures. Some potential next steps are described below:
High Fidelity Modeling and Experimentation – experimental prototyping of promising technologies. This
effort would involve a detailed investigation of critical components that require cooling. One example is
the fuel cell as this is a limiting component that not only generates large amounts of heat, but also has
difficulty in having this heat removed. Potential technologies from literature have pointed towards
invasive technologies, such as heat pipes, to efficiently move this heat out; however, this is a
multidisciplinary effort that would require collaboration with fuel cell experts to properly assess
performance penalties. Resulting designs from a dedicated high-fidelity model would then logically move
into a prototyping stage for eventual experimentation.
Performance of additive heat exchangers at cryogenic temperatures - many of the advances in heat
exchanger technology are made possible through additive manufacturing. However, there are very few
studies into how the alloys used in additive manufacturing behave at cryogenic temperatures. The
durability and life of these components is unknown and needs to be investigated.
4. While it is unlikely the actual approach to modeling the TMS will fail, it is possible that the designs won’t
be able to close due to mass, power, or volume constraints. In this situation we will move onto identifying
technology gaps and placing bounds and requirements on enabling technologies. We will also identify
testing that needs to be done on existing components to understand expected performance under the
aircraft operating conditions.
References
i Fuel Cells and Hydrogen 2 Joint Undertaking, Hydrogen-powered aviation – A fact-based study of hydrogen technology,
economics, and climate impact by 2050, Publications Office, 2020, https://data.europa.eu/doi/10.2843/471510
ii Heersema, Nic, and Ralph Jansen. "Thermal Management System Trade Study for SUSAN Electrofan Aircraft." AIAA SciTech
2022 Forum. 2022
iii Haran,K., “CHEETA Electrical System Package”, University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign, Presentation 2021.
iv Vanfretti, L., “CHEETA Power and Energy Management Package”, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. Presentation 2021
v Ordonez, J., et al, “IZEA Thermal Management – Tasks 5.1 to 5.5 + testbed”, FMAU-FSU College of Engineering, Presentation
2022
vi Schnulo, S., et. al, “Assessment of the Impact of an Advanced Power System on a Turboelectric Single-Aisle Concept Aircraft”,
AIAA Propulsion and Energy Forum 2020. 2020
vii W. Stautner, P. J. Ansell and K. S. Haran, "CHEETA: An All-Electric Aircraft Takes Cryogenics and Superconductivity on Board:
Combatting climate change," in IEEE Electrification Magazine, vol. 10, no. 2, pp. 34-42, June 2022, doi:
10.1109/MELE.2022.3165948
viii Lawag, R., Ali, H. M., ‘Phase change materials for thermal management and energy storage: A Review’, Journal of Energy
Storage, vol 55 part C, 2022. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.est.2022.105602
ix Chapman, J. W., Hasseeb, H., Schnulo, S. L. "Thermal Management System Design for Electrified Aircraft Propulsion
Concepts," AIAA 2020-3571. AIAA Propulsion and Energy 2020 Forum. August 2020.
x P. A. Hanlon, G. L. Thomas, J. T. Csank and D. J. Sadey, "A Tool for Modeling and Analysis of Electrified Aircraft Power Systems,"
2019 AIAA/IEEE Electric Aircraft Technologies Symposium (EATS), Indianapolis, IN, USA, 2019, pp. 1-16, doi: 10.2514/6.2019-
4403.

column1: Commoditization of molecular simulation data for exploration of new aerospace polymers
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT 

FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE 

INSTRUCTIONS 

Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name. 

Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger. 

Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission and do not need to be addressed in this template.  

RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW 

Title: Commoditization of molecular simulation data for exploration of new aerospace  polymers 

Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits).  Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant): What problem are you solving?  Has someone tried to solve this problem before?  Where did they go wrong?  What is different about your approach?  If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not?  How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools/methods or state-of-the art approaches?  If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable? Please include references/citations to back up claims where appropriate.  

 

This work proposes to commoditize molecular polymer models by: (1) automating the development of models and their characterization data analysis and (2) developing standard methods allowing models to be compared more easily.  

 

The materials available to design aircraft have a large impact on the capabilities of the aircraft and can be used to define the eras of flight – wood and canvas, aluminum, titanium, fiber reinforced polymer, etc. Traditionally, new materials development is a long-lead and expensive part of new aircraft design. The advent of computational modeling new materials has the potential to advance the efficiency of new material development to accelerate the insertion of new materials to meet challenging aviation goals. For example, non-petroleum derived polymers, polymers for lightweight composites, and low-energy curing polymers can decrease the environmental impact of an aircraft lifecycle. 

 

For state-of-the-art fiber reinforced composite systems, the axial properties are dominated by the fiber, and the purpose of the polymer is to facilitate load transfer between fibers. Properties that depend on this load transfer and therefore on the polymer include fracture toughness, transverse, and shear properties. Improving these properties can reduce the weight of the structure or new non-petroleum-based polymers could be used if their performance can match those of existing polymers. 

 

The problem we are proposing to address is the speed and cost of modeling new polymer materials. Many relevant properties of polymer materials originate from the molecular structure of the polymer and can be predicted using molecular dynamics simulation. However, molecular dynamics models can be time consuming to build and develop, which typically limits in-depth analysis to single polymer systems. Developing new polymers, however, requires screening of many different candidate systems. The individually customized modeling procedures currently in use have costs (time and effort) beyond what is required to generate a large database of properties or to rapidly screen new chemistries. Furthermore, machine learning and other emerging data analysis methods are predicated on the availability of large quantities of reasonably curated data.  

 

There are commercial packages with polymer modeling capabilities, such as the Amsterdam Modeling Suite, Materials Square, and Materials Studio. These are typically wrappers that use the capabilities of open-source molecular dynamics codes and their engine. Often the focus of these commercial packages is “democratizing” molecular models, so the emphasis is on a graphical user interface. The goal of this project though, is to involve as little or no human intervention. Some packages have scripting capabilities, but the user would be required to write the software that performs the automation negating the benefits of the commercial package. 

 

One of the requirements of developing a database of simulation material properties is a set of standardized procedures used to create the polymers and characterize them. For experimental materials, there are standards such as American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) that allow for comparison of material properties. For molecular models, research groups tend to have their own methods, which vary in ways that may or may not be consequential. To overcome the challenge of standard and repeatable results of molecular models of polymers, what is being proposed is method development to establish standard procedures for computationally guided selection of material properties. 

 

To these ends we are proposing: (1) automation of the generation of molecular models of polymer systems and the characterization of the resulting systems, such that new systems can be rapidly screened and (2) standardization (versioning) of molecular simulation procedures, so the resulting predictions are repeatable and comparable.  

 

 

Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion. 

 

Milestone 1: Determination of modeling procedures and system sizes for select material properties. 

Outcomes: Baseline standards for select material properties. Select properties are expected to include crosslink density, mass density, glass transition temperature, Young’s modulus, and may be expanded to include area-under-the-curve toughness, yield strength and other molecular-scale properties. Preliminary polymer systems would include well characterized systems such as epoxy-amine systems and homopolymerized epoxy systems, which are used to validate the procedures and work through the automation steps.  

 

Milestone 2: Estimate compute resources required to generate specific database sizes, based on system size and runtime requirements obtained from milestone 1. 

Outcomes: Estimate the average system sizes required and simulation runtimes required to obtain the select properties from Milestone 1. This data is used to determine database sizes that can be modeled (0.1K, 1K, 10K polymers etc.). 

 

Milestone 3: Identification of workflow steps that require automation and document software requirements for each step. 

Outcomes: A roadmap of the software requirements that need to be developed. For example: what would be involved in automating the assignment of some popular molecular force fields, what would be required to automate the polymerization reaction chemistry definitions – which are required to build the models from their constituent monomers, automatic data analysis of the resulting models to determine the material properties, which currently involves some human intervention.  

 

Upon completion of the milestones the software requirements and compute resources to generate a database of material properties will be known. 

 

After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps?  Where are the potential areas for transition?  What follow-on research do you anticipate?  

After completion of these milestones, the work may proceed to developing the software to automate the simulation workflows and generate a database of properties. Some automation has already been performed under the Hi-Rate Composite Aircraft Manufacturing (HiCAM) and Game Changing Development (GCD) super-lightweight aerospace composites (SAC) projects, which resulted in databases for rapid curing resins and ionic liquid resins, respectively, on the order of tens of polymer systems being developed with reduced human intervention. Through this work it became apparent that there was a plausible path to fully automate the workflow. 

The suite of material properties that are predicted can also be expanded. As the standardized procedures mature and the database grows, data analysis can be performed on the data to identify potential polymers for new environmentally friendly aircraft structures. Multi-scale models that use the molecular dynamics models as input could be built to predict properties that originate at length-scales larger than is possible with molecular dynamics, like fracture toughness. The scope could also be expanded to include investigating requirements for high throughput experimental screening of polymer systems, including identification of chokepoints and estimation of resources required to generate experimental databases of various sizes. The experimental data may also overlap with the simulation data to aid in model validation.  

 

Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation:  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically.  You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot?  What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?  

If the compute resources required to generate a full database are beyond reason, methods to reduce the computational cost can be explored. For example, coarse-grain simulations could be developed. This adds complexity and development costs but could reduce compute resources.

column1: Elastocaloric Cooling: The Missing Link in Green Aviation
column4:
Transformational Tools & Technologies Project
FY24 Green Aviation Proposal
1
Title: Elastocaloric Cooling: The Missing Link in Green Aviation
1. Project Description, Background, and Motivation:
Elastocaloric materials are currently poised to serve as transformative and efficient solid-state
coolants relevant to TX14 Thermal Management Systems (TX14.2.1 Heat Acquisition and TX14.2.2 Heat
transport) in the 2020 NASA Technology Taxonomy [1] but they have yet to be considered as a major
enabling element for Green Aviation. This year (2023), NASA’s Aeronautics Research Mission Directorate
(AMRD) has published a strategic plan to achieve net-zero carbon emissions in aviation by 2050,
whereby hydrogen fuel and other electronic power sources (batteries) are major contenders to replace
carbon-rich fossil fuels. To reach the objective of zero carbon emissions, several milestones must be
reached on a global scale including sourcing and transporting elemental hydrogen, developing hydrogen
combustion systems which burn hotter than fossil-fuels in traditional Brayton cycles [2], implementing
temperature sensitive high-efficiency batteries, and replacing electronics that exhibit losses from joule
heating [3]. Phase change materials (PCMs), such as paraffin wax and heat pipes, have been
implemented in prior studies to overcome these problems, yet their performance relies on specific
ambient conditions and an optimal geometric design for specific duty cycles. Thermal buffering is not
robust enough to keep pace with NASA’s decarbonization efforts. One major limiting factor common to
all these proposed carbon-free technologies (including nuclear) is the peak operating temperature.
Therefore, thermal control is of paramount importance to support the development of Green Aviation.
Current cooling methods rely heavily on vapor-compression technology, whereby, the latent heat of
vaporization of hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) produces the cooling effect with which we are familiar. In
vapor form, these HFCs are greenhouse gases, and therefore cannot support the cooling of Green
Aviation systems. Accidental release of HFCs during the filling or catastrophic bursting of over-pressured
refrigerant lines is a major worldwide problem that contributes to global warming. Therefore, several
agencies and countries have supported the development of high-efficiency refrigeration technology free
of HFCs [4].
Elastocaloric materials offer a carbon-neutral solution to replacing HFCs and vapor-compression
refrigerators. In its simplest description, the elastocaloric effect (ECE) is defined as the temperature
change that occurs within a material when it is elastically deformed by a mechanical load.
Thermodynamically, all materials exhibit this behavior, but some, namely shape memory alloys (SMAs),
are capable of super-elastocaloric effects. These super-ECEs are characterized by adiabatic temperature
changes, ∆𝑇𝑎𝑑, of over 20°C and manifest from the latent heat of reversible martensitic phase
transformations [5] driven during superelasticity. Fortunately, SMAs are under current investigation at
NASA for aeronautical actuation, e.g., in vortex generators and aileron motion. Several of their
properties have been measured and stored in databases, and a unique feature of SMAs is their 2-way
thermomechanical coupling which enables their value as coolants. SMAs are energy converters and are
the archetypal candidates for super-ECE cooling systems [6].
In SMAs, reversible martensitic transformations are driven by mechanical stress, 𝜎, temperature (𝑇)
sweeps, and sometimes a magnetic field, 𝐻. If the transition takes place under a constant 𝜎, a large
shape change can be observed as indicated by the alloy’s strain, 𝜖 (superelasticity). 𝜎-driven changes in
heat capacity, 𝐶𝑝, serve as the backbone of the ECE, and in SMAs the latent heat of the reversible
martensitic phase transformation superimposes with the traditional ECE. Fig. 1(a) demonstrates the
large ∆𝑇𝑎𝑑 measured in a NiCoMnTi SMA which was measured to be ≈ ±18°C [7].
Recently, researchers in academia and industry are pushing to exploit super-elastocaloric
technology, but they often rely on bulky tension/compression instrumentation. The coefficient of
performance (COP) is determined based on both material properties and loading type, as shown in Fig.
1b. In Fig. 1b, SMAs subscripted with a “t” or “c” indicate tensile or compressive loading. 
Transformational Tools & Technologies Project
FY24 Green Aviation Proposal
2
The PI believes that torsion may offer a better excitation mode whereby the mechanical advantage
of gears can be exploited to decrease the power needed to produce the desired ∆𝑇𝑎𝑑. Torsion designs
could enable the miniaturization of the excitation system and minimization of necessary power input.
This project focuses investigations in the “unknown” region labeled in Fig. 1b for materials with COPs
greater than 23 and ∆𝑇𝑎𝑑 greater than 20°C [6]. The development of miniature solid-state regenerators
could revolutionize Green Aviation by enabling better temperature control in zero-carbon emission
systems.
(a) (b)

2. Plan and Anticipated Milestones:
The ECE is usually defined by the ∆𝑇𝑎𝑑 or isothermal entropy change, ∆𝑆(𝑇𝐾, 𝜎) =

𝑇𝐾 = (𝑇𝑘+1 + 𝑇𝑘)/2 [8]. The ∆𝑆 is useful in determining the COP [8] shown in Fig. 1b, and prior work
has demonstrated that the COP of SMAs can be approximated by seven materials properties, namely the
transformation strain, 𝜖𝑡𝑟 , the reverse-transformation Clausius-Clapeyron slopes (slope of phase
diagram co-existence lines), 𝑑𝐴𝑓/𝑑𝜎 and 𝑑𝐴𝑠/𝑑𝜎, the austenite finish temperature, 𝐴𝑓, the martensite
start and finish temperatures, 𝑀𝑠 and 𝑀𝑓 respectively, and the 𝐶𝑝 of martensite. Some of these
parameters have already been measured in several SMAs at NASA Glenn Research Center and the PI
aims to perform bulk data analysis to identify promising compositions for ECE applications.
If funded, this project (Table 1) will result in at least one technical memorandum or journal article in
the first year and a path to design 2 novel SMAs. This project is defined by the 3 tasks listed below:
1. Review databased super-ECE data and the state-of-the-art with an emphasis in identifying
important and missing materials properties and determine if a COP above 25 is feasible with
∆𝑇𝑎𝑑> 20°C in SMAs.
2. Down select and assess both archetypal and novel binary/ternary SMA systems through
common synthesis and processing techniques (arc-melting/vacuum annealing), and characterize
properties at least via calorimetry (latent heat, 𝐶𝑝). The measurement of other characteristics
such as (𝜖𝑇, 𝜎, ∆𝑆, 𝑑𝜎/𝑑𝑇) with isothermal mechanical testing, and iso-stress heating/cooling
experiments will be attempted and potentially pursued with follow-on funding. Mechanical
testing and calorimetry will also be used to determine hysteresis loss.
3. Perform application pathfinding and speculate on potential areas in Green Aviation that would
benefit from miniature high-efficiency carbon-neutral cooling systems.

3. Sustaining research beyond the award period:
The ECE is not specific to SMAs but is a thermodynamic feature of all physical matter. Moreover, the
caloric effects in matter are not limited to mechanically driven temperature changes. Instead, different
driving forces can be applied, including electric and magnetic fields to change temperatures in
electrocaloric and magnetocaloric effects (MCE), respectively. The ECE via tension and compression is
only one potential solution in solid-state cooling to support Green Aviation. Torsional modes should also
be investigated. Therefore, follow-up research and transition areas include studying other non-SMA
calorific materials, the MCE, and various loading modes. Specifically, the giant MCE has been under
scrupulous investigation in meta-magnetic shape memory alloys over the past few decades [8].
Additionally, this work can benefit NASA space missions, including the space technology research
grants, early state Innovations (ESI) and ARTEMIS by providing a method of extreme thermal
management. Other applications can include passive cooling of all electric aircraft motors.
4. Risk Mitigation:
In the hypothetical situation that my team of subject matter experts determines that the initial
proposed approach is not feasible, we will pivot by designing materials to overcome the obstacle. For
example, if some SMAs do not exhibit the necessary mechanical properties for several thousand cycles
of super-ECE loading, we will attempt to understand why and design a material with the needed
properties (strength, ductility, microstructure, etc.). The proposed project is low-risk and has the
potential for a high-yielding transformative technology to support Green Aviation.
