Apart from proposing design strategies for aircraft NOx emission control, the successful project will generate a state-of-the art modeling framework and set the stage for research in several directions, internally within TTT and NASA but also with external partners. One future avenue is a continued evaluation of NOx emission control from jet engines in tandem with engine engineers and experimental investigations. With small modifications, the modeling framework will, in addition, be applicable to aircraft configurations using other propulsion systems. This includes the use of alternative fuels such as H2 or the use of electrical jet turbines powered by a centrally located combustion engine that would allow for better control of the emitted gases.[12–14]  

Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation: Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot? What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?  

The two main risk predicted for this project are that i), the reaction network for the NOx abatement in generated from combustion of traditional jet fuels becomes overly complex to be properly addressed during the project; and ii), that the more detailed analysis suggests that the amount of abated NOx with the integrated catalytic converter will be insignificant. Both risks can be alleviated by switching to another (simplified) system. In case of i), the reaction system will be reduced to include NO and CO only (leaving the carbohydrates and NO2 aside). This will still allow for extraction of relevant results for the jet engine use case. In case of ii), a future engine design will be considered where the exhaust gas is separated from the jet stream allowing for longer catalyst contact time and enhanced degree of NOx conversion.  

Reference

column1: Health Monitoring for Mechanical and Electrochemical Degradation in Structural Batteries
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT 

FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE 

INSTRUCTIONS 

Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name. 

Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger. 

Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission and do not need to be addressed in this template.  

RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW 

Title: Health Monitoring for Mechanical and Electrochemical Degradation in Structural Batteries.   

Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits).   

Text BoxBatteries are critical for powering future zero emissions vehicle concepts in the automotive, aerospace (e.g., urban air mobility, hybrid/all electric aircraft), industrial (e.g., autonomous drones), and consumer sectors (Figure 1 ​[1]​).  Recently, “massless” structural batteries have emerged that are capable of both supporting structural loads and storing energy​ [2]​.  They are called “massless” because they store energy in structures already needed in aircraft designs, thus no extra mass is required for separate battery storage.  The energy density and multifunctionality of structural batteries will allow a paradigm shift for electrical vehicle designs, leading to increased range and performance as well as a new generation of vehicle designs not possible using conventional batteries.  For these multifunctional battery structures to achieve their full potential, they must be used without external battery management systems.  At the same time, their safety must be guaranteed, especially for manned vehicle applications.  The proposed work aims to address safety assurances for future massless structural batteries by nondestructively studying mechanical and electrochemical degradation mechanisms in these newly developed batteries.  The ultimate goals of this work are (a) to build an understanding of the degradation mechanisms of massless structural batteries and (b) to establish and demonstrate inspection techniques that can be applied during operation to inform maintenance actions and grounding of aircraft before catastrophic failure.     

 

Health monitoring for batteries is important for their safe operation, especially in power-hungry electric aircraft where batteries are stressed through high discharge rates and extreme operating environments.  Battery health monitoring is a new field, with much of the focus in the research community on commercial lithium-ion battery chemistries and their state of health (SOH) and state of charge (SOC) (e.g., ​[3]​, ​[4]​).  Measurements of the SOC and SOH are meant to determine when batteries need to be changed, not on whether they are safe for operation.  On the other hand, NASA’s recent work under the CAS SPARRCI program sought to monitor the internal structure of batteries using resonance-based and guided wave ultrasonic methods ​[5]​.  The developments under SPARRCI included successful monitoring of structural resonance changes in lithium metal batteries during the electrochemical cycling process (Figure 2), as well as a demonstration of in-situ application of the developed techniques.  The resonance-based approaches identified under SPARRCI allow through-thickness structure and material property changes to be monitored, and guided wave approaches allow broad area coverage and localization of damage. 

 

Figure 2: Reflection coefficient spectrum measurements made on lithium metal pouch cell batteries at charge rates ranging from 0.1C to 0.5C, where 1C is the rate required to fully charge the battery in one hour.  Resonances are influenced by the layered structure and are shown as minima in the color maps.  The resonances shift toward lower frequencies during cell degradation.   

In the composite massless batteries that will be explored, the resonance-based methods (local) and guided wave methods (long range) will be applied to allow multi-scale monitoring of battery and structural health during mechanical and electrochemical cycling.  The work will leverage expertise developed in ultrasonic nondestructive evaluation (NDE) of battery health within in LaRC’s Nondestructive Evaluation Sciences Branch (NESB) as well as composite and battery fabrication expertise in LaRC’s Advanced Materials and Processing Branch.   

 

Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion. 

Production of composite structural batteries (Q1-Q2) – In-house expertise in composite processing and battery fabrication will be a key enabler of this milestone, as well as manufacturing methods developed within the research community (e.g.,​ [2]​).  At least 10 battery specimens with qualitatively similar electrochemical performance will be produced during this phase.  Performance will be verified through electrical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) after fabrication. 

Assembly and setup of measurement techniques on dummy specimens (Q1) – In parallel with battery fabrication, inert composite layups using the same materials and stacking sequences as structural batteries will be made without active electrochemical components.  These dummy specimens will allow rapid tuning of the inspection approaches and will reveal any potential issues with acoustic impedance mismatch and attenuation in dissimilar materials.  By the end of the first quarter, a baseline inspection capability will be ready for battery inspection.  Note that this is only possible in this short timeline because of the foundation laid through the CAS SPARRCI effort. 

Baseline measurements on batteries (Q2) – After fabricating battery specimens, baseline data will be collected before electrical cycling or mechanical loading.  These measurements will highlight the reproducibility of resonance and guided wave data among specimens and will be as a baseline to which the degraded response can be compared.   

Cycling and monitoring of batteries (Q2 – Q4) – Mechanical and electrochemical cycling of battery specimens will seed degradation that can be monitored using ultrasonic NDE approaches.   Electrical cycling will be conducted under constant current conditions to achieve a charge and discharge rate between 0.5C and 1C based on estimated cell capacities.  Three degradation scenarios will be examined: degradation due to electrical cycling alone, degradation due to mechanical loading alone, and combined mechanical loading with electrical cycling.    

Report Out (Q3 - Q4) – The novelty of the proposed work makes it viable for technical publication and dissemination to the research community.  In the last phase of the work, the team will output at least one (possibly more) technical publication in addition to a summary report for TTT.   
 

After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps?  Where are the potential areas for transition?  What follow-on research do you anticipate?  

The proposed work will lead to a TRL 4 demonstration of battery inspection techniques in relevant materials in a lab environment.  Both the mechanical and electrochemical loading scenarios will be simple in comparison to real-world operation.  In next steps, a database of degradation and sensor responses in more relevant operational conditions will be developed through random walk electrical cycling and vibration testing.  This data will be essential so that machine learning techniques can be trained and applied to structural-scale batteries to identify hazardous off-nominal conditions.  

The proposed effort works in synergy with NASA’s ongoing battery development and integrated vehicle health monitoring (IVHM) efforts.  Known transition paths include work under TTT for IVHM focused on sustainability, where these battery monitoring approaches could be another input into the framework for assessing vehicle health.  The work also supports structural composite battery development efforts within NASA and industry, where degradation mechanisms have not yet been explored.  

Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation:  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically.  You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot?  What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?  

The highest technical risk in this work is in repeatable production of composite structural batteries and the ability to degrade them in a meaningful way for health monitoring technique development.  If in-house fabrication proves infeasible in three months, then the work would pivot to state-of-the-art commercial batteries.  High energy density lithium-ion batteries like those used in commercial drones or electric vehicles would be purchased and used as the primary test article during test execution.  Through this pivot, the work would bolster and further mature in situ health monitoring approaches for high energy batteries with nearer term application.  The transition paths supporting ongoing IVHM and battery development work would remain valid.  

 

References: 

[1]  

L. Asp, "Tech Briefs," 2022. [Online]. Available: www.techbriefs.com/component/content/article/tb/pub/briefs/energy/39430. 

[2]  

M. S. Siraj, et al, "Advancing Structural Battery Composites: Robust Manufacturing for Enhanced and Consistent Multifunctional Performance," Advanced Energy and Sustainability Research, 2023.  

[3]  

P. Ladpli, et al, "Battery Charge and Helath State Monitoring via Ultrasonic Guided-Wave-Based Methods using Built-In Piezoelectric Transducers," Proc. of the SPIE Conference on Smart Materials and NDE, 2017.  

[4]  

M. Huang, N. Kirkaldy, Y. Zhao, Y. Patel, F. Cegla and B. Lan, "Quantitative Characterization of the Layered Structure Within Lithium Ion Batteries Using Ultrasonic Resonances," Journal of Energy Storage, 2022.  

[5]  

M. Webster, E. Frankforter and P. Juarez, "Evaluation of Ultrasonic Battery Inispection Techniques," Proceedings of the SPIE Conference on Smart Structures and Nondestructive Evaluation, 2022.

column1: Persistent Solar Power Station
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT 

FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE 

INSTRUCTIONS 

Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name. 

Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger. 

Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission and do not need to be addressed in this template.  

RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW 

Title: Persistent Solar Power Station 

Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits).  Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant): What problem are you solving?  Has someone tried to solve this problem before?  Where did they go wrong?  What is different about your approach?  If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not?  How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools/methods or state-of-the art approaches?  If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable? Please include references/citations to back up claims where appropriate.  

 

We are proposing a persistent high-altitude long-endurance (HALE) solar power station. The idea involves an airborne solar panel carried by two HALE aircraft operating at high altitude over a long duration. This is illustrated in the following figure. The electric propulsion on the HALE aircraft is powered by the energy harvested by the solar panel. The power provided by the solar panel can be beamed to UAM aircraft, enabling the aircraft to extend ranges and operate with more passenger capacity. The power can also be beamed to a ground station for energy storage. 

  

NASA Helios was a solar powered UAV designed by Aerovironment [1]. The first flight ended in a mishap. Subsequent investigations attributed one of the causes of the mishap to "nonlinear stability and control problem involving complex interactions among the flexible structure, unsteady aerodynamics, flight control system, propulsion system, the environmental conditions, and vehicle flight dynamics." As a result, the accident investigation board made several recommendations one of which is to "Develop more advanced, multidisciplinary (structures, aeroelastic, aerodynamics, atmospheric, materials, propulsion, controls, etc) “time-domain” analysis methods appropriate to highly flexible, “morphing” vehicles." 

 

The goal of the Helios was largely unfulfilled. If successful, it could have heralded in a new aerospace infrastructure program that could have wide ranging applications from providing power to internet services anywhere in the world.  

 

 

Persistent Solar Power Station 

 

The proposal is different from the Helios in the platform configuration. Applying the recommendations by the accident investigation board, the proposal will focus on developing new capabilities and better understanding of multidisciplinary interactions between nonlinear large deflection structure [2], aeroelasticity, unsteady aerodynamics, and flight control for highly flexible HALE aircraft. New capabilities could include structural dynamic tools, unsteady aerodynamic tools for large motion moving aerodynamic surfaces, and nonlinear aeroservoelasticity tools for flight dynamic prediction and flight control synthesis of HALE aircraft. These capabilities are not widely available. Some capabilities exist at universities, but they tend to be low-fidelity tools [3]. The ultimate goal is to achieve high-fidelity aeroservoelastic capabilities. 

 

[1]	https://www.nasa.gov/wp-content/uploads/2016/07/64317main_helios.pdf, Date of Retrieval: October 13, 2023 

[2]	Nguyen, N. and Ting, E., “Large Deflection Aeroelasticity and Aeroelastic Lifting Line Theory for Examination of Aerodynamic Effects and Nonlinear Limit Cycle Oscillations,” AIAA/ASCE/AHS/ASC Structures, Structural Dynamics, and Materials Conference, AIAA-2018-1954, January 2018. 

[3] 	Palacios, R., Murua, J., and Cook, R., "Structural and Aerodynamic Models in Nonlinear Flight Dynamics of Very Flexible Aircraft," AIAA Journal, Vol. 48, No. 11, November 2010 

 

Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion. 

A tentative set of milestones are as follows: 

 

Month 1 - Concept development and vehicle sizing 

Month 4 - Finite-element model development for nonlinear large deflection structure of HALE aircraft 

Month 6 - Coupled structural dynamics - unsteady aerodynamic (fluid-structure interaction) simulation 

Month 8 - Nonlinear aeroservoelastic model development for flight dynamics and control 

Month 10 - Flight control design for high altitude gust rejection, modal suppression, and station keeping 

Month 12 - Final report submission 

 

The metrics for evaluating the proposed work will be new capabilities and tools that can predict nonlinear aeroelasticity for large deflection structures with wing tip displacement at least 20% of the semi-span. Additionally, metrics for flight control will be used to evaluate the gust disturbance rejection, modal suppression, and station keeping to maintain precise altitude and orientation to within certain specifications. 

 

After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps?  Where are the potential areas for transition?  What follow-on research do you anticipate?  

 

If successful, the immediate next step would involve identifying a potential project (TTT) for transition and briefing to industry (e.g., Aerovironment).  The follow-on research would include: low-speed wind tunnel test at university facility (e.g. University of Washington) on a highly flexible aircraft model with active control surfaces, developing higher fidelity tools for nonlinear aeroelasticity, FSI, and aeroservoelasticity. 

 

Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation:  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically.  You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot?  What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?  

The proposed work is considered highly challenging. Time constraint will play a major role in the success of the project, but if this constraint is removed, then some measure of success will likely be realized by means of having new tools and capabilities. Thus, the technical risk is likely be driven by the schedule. It is possible that not all objectives as proposed can be realized in the time frame. From the operational perspective, the key is to determine feasibility of the concept in terms of flight dynamics, stability, and control. It is possible that the flight control could be very challenging and success criteria could not be met. If so, resizing the aerodynamic configuration to increase stability and structure to increase rigidity may be required. This could potentially increase the aircraft weight and thereby lead to increased power requirements. The flight control challenge might be reduced but the benefit might decrease as well.

column1: Thrust Generation in Electrified Aircraft Heat Exchanger Ducts
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT 

FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE 

Title: Thrust Generation in Electrified Aircraft Heat Exchanger Ducts 

Problem description, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits 

 

Large electrified aircraft produce orders of magnitude more electronics heat than even the most advanced electrical systems on current aircraft. More heat means more drag on ram-air heat exchangers (HXs), which are the existing state of the art for aircraft heat rejection. Ram-air HXs sized for electrified aircraft could create so much drag and weight that they could negate the benefits from electrification [1,2]. A HX that not only eliminates drag but creates thrust would solve this problem. 

Text BoxThere has been a renewed interest in thrust-producing HXs via the Meredith effect [3,4,5]. Meredith effect HXs were previously used in some WWII-era piston engine aircraft, like the P-51 Mustang. Current passenger aircraft do not utilize these designs because jet engines naturally have higher air cooling. Additionally, engine oil heat is typically used to pre-heat the fuel or is rejected via a surface heat exchanger installed in the bypass duct rather than in a standalone duct. However large electrified aircraft likely cannot rely completely on surface (or outer mold line) heat exchangers and will need to reject heat via a pumped-fluid loop to a ram-air heat exchanger [6,7]. The majority of proposed electrified aircraft architectures utilize a single-phase pumped fluid loop [8] operating at temperatures up to 200 °C, which makes them an ideal candidate for a Meredith effect HX. The recent analytical work has shown the potential for thrust production in electrified aircraft HX ducts, however, to date there is little to no evidence that any designs have been built or tested. 

The proposed work would determine the feasibility of a thrust-producing HX for a hybrid-electric aircraft in realistic operating conditions, evaluating potential thrust vs. rejection temperature. This would involve sizing and optimization of the ducted HX at each rejection temperature. If thrust can be produced at a reasonable rejection temperature, a sub-scale HX core would be built and tested at design and off-design operating conditions to measure generated thrust. The HX itself would be of the microchannel type, which have been shown to have higher performance and lower drag and compared to the typical plate-fin heat exchangers used in aviation [9]. The HX would utilize additive manufacturing techniques, which can create the complex microchannel structures more easily and affordably then traditional chemical etching and diffusion bonding processes. HX materials to be investigated include metals as well as plastics, which have recently shown potential benefits in a number of different heat exchanger applications [10,11]. If successful, this work would demonstrate light-weight and zero net drag thermal management which is an enabling technology for NASA’s long-term goals of net-zero carbon emissions from aviation. 

 

Milestones 

 

Month 1-3: Heat exchanger and duct analysis and optimization to determine feasibility of thrust production at realistic single-aisle hybrid-electric aircraft operating conditions 

Month 4-9: Selection of heat exchanger design. Design and procurement of test rig for measuring thrust. Procurement/fabrication of heat exchanger. 

Month 10-12: Testing of heat exchanger. Documentation of results. 

 

Transition Plan and Follow-On Research 

 

After this work is completed, next steps would be integration into an electrified powertrain thermal management system, such as the one being developed under the Convergent Aeronautics Solutions: Subsonic Single Aft Engine project (CAS/SUSAN). Potential follow-on research could include evaluation of methods to increase HX rejection temperatures if this research determines that is desirable. Such methods could include integration of a heat pump or engine heat source. Other follow-on research could include investigating HX designs that are integrated into electric fan ducts, as that has been shown to have greater performance than standalone ducts in certain conditions [4]. 

 

Pivot Plan 

 

If the initial approach is not feasible, it would likely be because the needed rejection temperature is higher than the typical temperature limits for electrified aircraft components. In that case, thrust production would not occur, but drag reduction could still be demonstrated and measured. Alternatively, a heat pump system could be sized and optimized to generate the needed higher rejection temperatures. Testing could still occur without a heat pump, as the fluid temperatures would be provided by the test rig fluid system or by integrated heating elements. 

 

References: 

[1] Freeman, J., Osterkamp, P., Green, M., Gibson, A., & Schiltgen, B. (2014). Challenges and opportunities for electric aircraft thermal management. Aircraft Engineering and Aerospace Technology: An International Journal, 86(6), 519-524. 

[2] Brelje, B. J., & Martins, J. R. (2019). Electric, hybrid, and turboelectric fixed-wing aircraft: A review of concepts, models, and design approaches. Progress in Aerospace Sciences, 104, 1-19. 

[3] Kellermann, H., Lüdemann, M., Pohl, M., & Hornung, M. (2020). Design and optimization of ram air–based thermal management systems for hybrid-electric aircraft. Aerospace, 8(1), 3. 

[4] White, A. S., Waddington, E., Merret, J. M., Greitzer, E. M., Ansell, P. J., & Hall, D. K. (2022). System-level utilization of low-grade, mw-scale thermal loads for electric aircraft. In AIAA Aviation 2022 Forum (p. 3291). 

[5] Meredith, F. W. (1935). Cooling of aircraft engines with special reference to ethylene glycol radiators enclosed in ducts. HM Stationery Office. 

[6] Heersema, N., & Jansen, R. (2022). Thermal Management System Trade Study for SUSAN Electrofan Aircraft. In AIAA SciTech 2022 Forum (p. 2302). 

[7] Kellermann, H., Habermann, A. L., & Hornung, M. (2019). Assessment of aircraft surface heat exchanger potential. Aerospace, 7(1), 1. 

[8] Coutinho, M., Bento, D., Souza, A., Cruz, R., Afonso, F., Lau, F., ... & da Silva, C. R. (2023). A review on the recent developments in thermal management systems for hybrid-electric aircraft. Applied Thermal Engineering, 120427. 

[9] van Heerden, A. S., Judt, D. M., Jafari, S., Lawson, C. P., Nikolaidis, T., & Bosak, D. (2022). Aircraft thermal management: Practices, technology, system architectures, future challenges, and opportunities. Progress in Aerospace Sciences, 128, 100767. 

[10] Thibaud-Erkey, Catherine, & Alahyari, Abbas. Final Report for Project titled High Thermal Conductivity Polymer Composites for Low-Cost Heat Exchangers. United States. https://doi.org/10.2172/1337608 

[11] Rasouli, E., Fricke, E., & Narayanan, V. (2022). High efficiency 3-D printed microchannel polymer heat exchangers for air conditioning applications. Science and Technology for the Built Environment, 28(3), 289-306.

column1: Ion Propulsion Systems and Advanced Multi-Sensor Perception for Unmanned Aerial Systems: Leveraging Space Exploration Advances for Sustainable Terrestrial Aviation
column4:
Ion Propulsion Systems and Advanced Multi-Sensor Perception for Unmanned Aerial Systems: Leveraging Space Exploration Advances for Sustainable Terrestrial Aviation 

 

The rapid advancement of unmanned aerial systems (UAS) technology has revolutionized the aviation industry. However, traditional UAS propulsion mechanisms pose significant limitations, including noise pollution, low energy efficiency, and limited maneuverability. These issues are especially evident in residential settings and sensitive environments where noise and emissions are disruptive. While space exploration has widely adopted ion propulsion, terrestrial applications, particularly in UAS, remain under-explored due to challenges like atmospheric drag. Nonetheless, the promise of silent operations, zero emissions, and minimized waste offers a tantalizing prospect for green aviation. Advances by organizations like Undefined Technologies² and MIT³ have proven the viability of IPS for Earth-bound applications. 

This project aims to develop a sustainable alternative to conventional UAS propulsion mechanisms by integrating ion propulsion systems (IPS), a technology deeply rooted in space exploration, into UAS. This innovative approach promises significant advancements in UAS propulsion, including reduced noise and emissions, enhanced energy efficiency, and increased maneuverability. The project will begin with a comprehensive literature review to assess the current state of the art in ion propulsion systems (IPS) technology and its potential applicability to UAS. This review will inform the development of a specialized sensor system and the integration of a deep learning system directly into the IPS. This innovative approach will ensure that UAS not only benefit from sustainable propulsion but also gain from superior diagnostics and efficiency. In addition, the project will incorporate a Multi-Sensor Perception System (MsPs) that uses neuromorphic-computing-based Deep Neural Network (DNN) to provide real-time feedback on the performance of the IPS and develop advanced diagnostic and predictive maintenance algorithms. 

The successful integration of IPS into UAS is expected to have a profound impact on UAS applications across multiple sectors. By significantly reducing noise and emissions, and enhancing energy efficiency and maneuverability, IPS-powered UAS will open up new possibilities for UAS operations in residential zones and other environmentally sensitive areas. This project has the potential to revolutionize the UAS industry by addressing the key limitations of traditional UAS propulsion mechanisms. The successful integration of IPS into UAS will herald a new era of sustainable, efficient, and maneuverable UAS operations. 

In addition to the aforementioned benefits, IPS-powered UAS could also offer significant advantages in terms of cost and safety. IPS systems are relatively inexpensive to manufacture and operate, and they pose a lower risk of fire or explosion than traditional UAS propulsion systems. These factors make IPS an attractive option for a wide range of UAS applications, including commercial deliveries, disaster relief, and environmental monitoring. 

 

A comprehensive literature review will be conducted to assess the current state of the art in ion propulsion systems, UAS technologies, and neuromorphic computing. This review will identify key advancements in each area and highlight potential synergies. The review will also identify any gaps in the current knowledge base that need to be addressed. 

Upon completion of the literature review, the team will develop a detailed design for downscaling the IPS to operate on UAS and for modifying the UAS to work with the IPS. They will also develop a prototype for the MsPs, which will be based on sensors developed at GRC for the Advanced Electric Propulsion System (AEPS)¹, such as the Retarding Potential Analyzer (RPA), planar probe (PP), Discharge current sensor, and Wide-Angle Potential Analyzer (WAPA). The MsPs will be designed to integrate neuromorphic computing principles and ensure compatibility with the IPS. Key metrics for this phase include the design's adaptability, energy efficiency, and compatibility with UAS structures. 

Concurrently, a deep learning core will be implemented on a Field-Programmable Gate Array (FPGA). This core will be responsible for analyzing data from the MsPs and optimizing and diagnosing the performance of the ion propulsion system. The efficiency and accuracy of the core, along with its speed and energy efficiency, will be critical. 

Once the MsPs and the deep learning core have been developed, they will be integrated and tested in controlled environments to ensure system stability and accuracy. Field testing will then be conducted using UAS equipped with the developed system in real-world conditions to gather pertinent data. Based on the field test insights, refinements will be made to the system to enhance efficiency and address any identified gaps. 

Upon completion of the field testing, comprehensive documentation detailing the project, methodologies, and findings will be prepared for various stakeholders. This documentation will include recommendations for future research based on the project's results. 

The project's success will be evaluated based on factors such as innovation, tangible impacts, efficiency, feedback from stakeholders, and scalability. An expert panel will be assembled for a holistic evaluation, with feedback recorded for future reference and ongoing refinement. 

 

Upon successful prototyping and validation in UAS, this technology has the potential to be scaled for broader applications, such as larger unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and piloted aircraft. As the neuromorphic-based DNN control system proves its worth, efforts would be directed towards enhancing its computational prowess, response times, and adaptability, with potential extensions into other aerospace or ground-based vehicular systems. 

The broader ecosystem in which UAS operate will also be refined, with emphasis on optimized flight paths, charging facilities, and the incorporation of renewable energy resources, which could play a significant role in Urban Air Mobility (UAM) development. The shift towards sustainability might also lead to explorations in other green aviation facets like sustainable materials, advanced traffic management, and contrail management, possibly resulting in partnerships with industries centered on green airport infrastructure. 

As the system evolves, there would be opportunities to leverage richer training datasets to refine the DNN's diagnostic accuracy, making it suitable for commercial UAS maintenance and predictive services. The energy efficiency of ion propulsion paves the way for potential alliances with the renewable energy sector, emphasizing solar, wind, or other green energy sources, culminating in a fully green UAS operation. 

Subsequent research could delve into alternative ion propulsion techniques, advanced energy storage solutions, revamped safety protocols, and integration with emerging technologies like quantum computing. Additionally, considering the societal and regulatory implications of such technological advancements would be crucial. 

Ultimately, this venture marks the onset of an evolutionary phase in green aviation and computational paradigms, paving the way for a sustainable aerospace future. 

 

 

Should technical infeasibility be encountered, a thorough review meeting will be convened with all stakeholders to understand the root causes of the challenges, pinpoint impacted project components, and re-evaluate the project's overall feasibility. Following this, there will be a realignment of objectives, potentially modifying certain facets of the approach to ensure project viability. If ion propulsion as a core technology proves untenable, parallel technologies or alternative energy sources, such as electrohydrodynamic (EHD) propulsion or hybrid systems, could be explored to maintain the commitment to green aviation. Regardless of propulsion setbacks, the potential of the Multi-Sensor Perception System (MsPs) and its neuromorphic-computing-based DNN remains significant; pivoting attention to these systems could enhance other green aviation technologies. 

To address challenges, collaborations with academic institutions or industry experts may offer fresh perspectives, and iterative prototyping could lead to gradual refinements. If the team identifies knowledge gaps, short-term training or even onboarding temporary experts will be prioritized. Maintaining transparency with all stakeholders, including the funding agency, is crucial to ensure trust and potentially gain additional insights or resources. 

In conclusion, while technical challenges are formidable, they can spur innovation. With flexibility, collaboration, and unwavering commitment, the team remains dedicated to the vision of sustainable UAS propulsion, regardless of the path taken. 

 

References: 

¹ Advanced Electric Propulsion System (AEPS) Enabling a Sustainable Return to the Lunar Surface through NASA Gateway - NASA Technical Reports Server (NTRS) 

² Undefined Technologies | Next-Generation Silent Drone | Doral, Fl 

³ https://news.mit.edu/2018/first-ionic-wind-plane-no-moving-parts-1121

column1: Design and manufacturing of 3D woven preforms for composite conformal tanks
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT 

FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE 

INSTRUCTIONS 

Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name. 

Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger. 

Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission and do not need to be addressed in this template.  

RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW 

Title: Design and manufacturing of 3D woven preforms for composite conformal tanks 

Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits).  Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant): What problem are you solving?  Has someone tried to solve this problem before?  Where did they go wrong?  What is different about your approach?  If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not?  How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools/methods or state-of-the art approaches?  If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable? Please include references/citations to back up claims where appropriate.  

As aviation moves to new propulsion technologies, fuels as well as airframes there will be a need to restructure the layout. The current tube and wing design has fuel tanks conveniently located in the wings taking advantage of the available volume as well as providing additional structural support. For airframes such as truss braced wings and blended wing bodies; propulsion systems such as high voltage hybrid electric and fuel cells;  as well as fuels such as hydrogen, it may no longer be feasible or desirable to maintain the current configuration. Conformal storage tanks are a potential solution as they can increase the packing efficiency in the available volume for odd shaped volumes. For maximum weight efficiency they need to be integrated with the airframe’s load carrying paths. This however poses design and manufacturing challenges. Odd shaped conformal tanks are not as amenable to conventional automated composite layup approaches as simpler geometries. This necessitates design compromises or the use of hand layup procedures which impact throughput, product consistency and ultimately the cost of new aircraft and transition to greener aviation. 

We therefore propose investigating manufacturing approaches for the design and manufacturing of 3D woven preforms for conformal tanks to provide both the structural support, fuel holding capacity and slosh prevention while meeting the constraints of the volume available in the new airframes. We propose utilizing high performance carbon nanotube (CNT) fibers as the primary reinforcement for the conformal tanks. Highly flexible, high strength CNT fibers with tight bend radii and high knot efficiency are amenable to automated 3D weaving into complex geometries. These geometries can be optimized for both the fuel carrying, and load path requirements for the conformal tanks. 3D weaving also enables building the structural supports for slosh prevention baffles in the preforms. CNT fibers are macroscopic materials assembled from a hierarchical arrangement of nanotubes.  While still in development, they are now available in lengths and strengths that have enabled demonstration of lined and linerless pressure vessels as well as structural panels for the NASA Space Technology Mission Directorate (STMD) Game Changing Office and other customers [1]. 

 

Conformal tanks have a long history of use as a space saving design. In automotives, conformal tanks are used to store windshield-washer fluid and over-flow coolant from radiators [2]. They have also long been considered for spacecraft for their potential weight savings, volume use optimization and placement flexibility [2-5]. Aircraft, specifically military aircraft, have also used conformal tanks for extension of their range and more flexibility in mounting other payloads.  Manufacturing challenges have thus far limited their wider usage in aircraft (and spacecraft) applications. 

 

3D weaving of fibers has started to gain wider use as an enabling technology for creating complex shapes. An example is the Heatshield for Extreme Entry Environment Technology (HEEET) where, in partnership with industry, NASA has been developing Thermal Protection System (TPS) technology to enable landing of large payloads on other planets [6]. 

 

Combined, 3D weaving of CNT preforms for conformal composite tanks could lead to manufacturing friendly lightweight structures that integrate well into the airframe for greater performance and reduced environmental impact. 

 

Specifically, we propose to investigate: 

Achieving the benefits of conformal tanks and structure in green aviation using Systems Analysis 

Approaches to the design and manufacturing of structural preforms made from 3D weaving of CNTs for tailored conformal tanks that meet the airframe requirements.  

Testing that would be required to support future article fabrication and evaluation.  Complex geometry of conformal tanks means none trivial and varied boundary load cases. 

 

[1]	https://www.nasa.gov/centers-and-facilities/langley/nasa-looking-to-tiny-technology-for-big-payoffs/ [retrieved 10/13/2023] 

[2]	Tom DeLay “Assemblies of Conformal Tanks: Space is utilized efficiently and sloshing is reduce” https://ntrs.nasa.gov/api/citations/20090035878/downloads/20090035878.pdf [Retrieved 10/13/2023] 

[3]	Rivers, H. K., “Conformal cryogenic tank trade study for reusable launch vehicles”, in Space Technology and Applications, International Forum -- 1999, 1999, vol. 458, pp. 1075–1086. doi:10.1063/1.57500. 

[4]	J. Keith Roberts, Michael P. Kovach, William M. McMahon and Jeffrey L. Finckenor,  “Composite, Cryogenic, Conformal, Common Bulkhead, Aerogel-insulated Tank (CBAT) Materials and Processing Methodologies.”  [Retrieved 10/13/2023] 

[5]	J. T. Dorsey, C. Wu, K. Rivers, C. Martin, Russell Smith “Airframe Integration Trade Studies for a Reusable Launch Vehicle” https://ntrs.nasa.gov/citations/20040086814 [Retrieved 10/13/2023] 

[6] Matt Gash, “Heatshield for Extreme Entry Environment Technology (HEEET) Thermal Protection System (TPS)”, https://ntrs.nasa.gov/api/citations/20190031968/downloads/20190031968.pdf [Retrieved 10/13/2023] 

Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion. 

The initial work will yield the following (report(s) as deliverable for a-d, coupon(s) for d): 

Systems Analysis of the potential benefits of conformal tanks from 3D woven preforms  

State of readiness of materials for the manufacturing of test coupons and production 

State of the art on the equipment to manufacture 3D preforms at lab scale and production 

Evaluation of potential test protocols for 3D woven coupons 

Fabrication of woven test coupon path finder(s) 

 

After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps?  Where are the potential areas for transition?  What follow-on research do you anticipate?  

Stage 2 [Indicates deliverable] 

Design and fabrication of 3D woven coupons with increasingly complex geometry [coupons] 

Higher fidelity detailing of manufacturing approaches/parameters that can be used to scale up articles [manufacturing equipment/processing parameters] 

Testing the performance of manufacturing process and bulk mechanical properties of the test preforms  [test data] 

Stage 3+ 

Scale up of the test articles size and complexity 

Integration studies tailored to specific airframe concepts 

The inclusion of additional tank requirements such as barrier materials to the pre-forms 

Use of design tools such as Topology Optimization to further look at optimizing tank-preform designs while maintaining manufacturability 

 

Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation:  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically.  You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot?  What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?  

Case 1: Initial target application/insertion point is not where the most benefit can be realized ® Revector to the components that have the most benefit based on Systems Analysis. 

Case 2: Preferred manufacturing approach not fully able to yield the desired component ®Look into the feasibility of a hybrid manufacturing approach with as much of the automation retained as possible to maintain the efficiency/consistency advantages that brings. 

Case 3: Additional material properties required ® Look into combining CNT fibers with conventional reinforcements such as carbon and boron fibers where needed (e.g. boron for very high modulus)

column1: Mission-Optimal Aircraft Trajectories and Simulation Studies with Contrail Mitigation
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT 

FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL  

Title: Mission-Optimal Aircraft Trajectories and Simulation Studies with Contrail Mitigation 

 

Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits).  Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant): What problem are you solving?  Has someone tried to solve this problem before?  Where did they go wrong?  What is different about your approach?  If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not?  How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools/methods or state-of-the art approaches?  If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable? Please include references/citations to back up claims where appropriate.  

Problem and Objectives:  

Air traffic is a significant contributor to anthropogenic global warming due to the formation of contrails via aircraft emissions. Contrails typically occur at or above 20,000 ft above ground level (AGL) and constitute about 35% of aviation’s global warming effects [1]. As the aviation industry continues to grow, the need for efficient contrail mitigation strategies may be required for greater environmental sustainability. Over the years, many contrail mitigation strategies have been developed which involve both heading and altitude changes [2]. These works often provide trade-off values between fuel consumption and contrail reduction. However, to the authors’ best knowledge, there is very little research over the impact of widespread adoption of such strategies on a network-wide, large-scale operation; existing works only consider strategies for a single flight. For instance, contrail mitigation strategies may lead to greater air traffic density especially with existing ATC (air traffic control) instructions such as holding, flow control, and demand-capacity balancing [3].Thus, the objective of this proposed study is to gain a better understanding of the effects of adopting any given contrail mitigation strategy on an existing airspace network. The specific aims of this study are the following: 

Develop a novel and efficient contrail mitigation strategy based on recent artificial intelligence and search-based techniques for simultaneous flights, rather than just one. 

Examine the aggregate impact a given contrail mitigation strategy would have on an existing airspace network within a simulated environment. Impacts can be measured in the form of sector demand or departure delay and will be assessed by comparing the use and lack of use of a mitigation strategy. 

Approach:  

In the field of Air Traffic Control (ATC) most mission-planning can be classified as either strategic or tactical which is linked to either pre-flight or during flight optimization. Our work will focus on investigating pre-flight or strategic flight optimizations in which we seek to create an optimal flight trajectory for a jet-based aircraft while avoiding creating a contrail as it flies from one airport to another. Tactical or during flight optimization will be a support role in our investigation and might become more relevant when last minute maneuvers are needed to avoid flying into a contrail region. 

To verify the efficacy of our approach, we will apply it different aircraft-types with different aircraft performance specifications such as (regional aircraft, business jets, commercial aircraft), and new entrants such as supersonic passenger aircraft. We plan on using an open-source flight simulator called BlueSky [4, 4] to model the physics of various aircraft and incorporate Breakthrough Energy's open-source contrail models [5] into BlueSky. Simulating the physics-based contrail models alongside BlueSky's flight simulator allows us to test and refine different trajectory optimization methods and discover which approaches might work or need to be improved to perform contrail avoidance and mitigation per different aircraft and missions. 

By comparing different trajectory optimization methods in BlueSky, we will be able to simulate and perform studies on how these new flights will defer from current day-to-day missions. If flights start flying these new mission-optimal routes that avoid regions with high humidity and below freezing temperatures in the airspace that might lead to the creation of contrails [2], then how much of an impact does this have on flight time, energy use, and other optimization parameters compared to current day-to-day missions? These are some questions we hope to address in our studies. 

The novelty of this work is twofold: (1) to design and investigate which trajectory-based optimization methods work for performing contrail avoidance and mitigation per aircraft type and mission profiles; and (2) perform simulation studies for these mission-optimal contrail avoiding aircraft flying in the airspace and how much it would differ or affect the current state-of-the-art aircraft operations. In the second part, we can investigate many different scenarios such as how much extra time these contrail avoiding aircraft will add to their original missions, which aircraft need to avoid contrail regions and which do not, and how will contrail avoidance work with supersonics. Some of these questions have been addressed in prior works but we are proposing an all-encompassing solution metric study and investigate newer aircraft such as supersonics.  

Benefits: 

We advance the state-of-the-art twofold: (1) in flight trajectory optimization by exploring existing and designing new trajectory optimization approaches and incorporate novel contrail avoidance criteria to these methods, and (2) in the ATC realm where we analyze the effect of different missions and aircraft types performing these mission-optimal trajectory-based methods with contrail mitigation. The proposed work will provide several benefits for the public: (1) a contrail model add-on to BlueSky for enabling others to perform contrail detection and avoidance, (2) identify mission-optimal aircraft trajectory optimization methods with contrail avoidance and mitigation, and (3) provide a metric study which analyzes the effects of each different contrail avoidance method. 

References: 

[1]  

P. e. a. Jaramillo, "Mitigation of Climiate Change," in IPCC, Cambridge, UK and New York, NY, USA, 2022.  

[2]  

R. U. S. a. M. E. S. Teoh, Beyond contrail avoidance: Efficacy of flight altitude changes to minimise contrail climate forcing.  

[3]  

J. A. Elmourad, "Evaluating Fuel-Climate Tradeoffs in Contrail Avoidance," Diss. Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 2023. 

[4]  

J. M. a. J. E. Hoekstra, "Bluesky ATC simulator project: an open data and open source approach," in Proceedings of the 7th international conference on research in air transportation, 2016.  

[5]  

B. Energy, "pycontrails" Python library for modeling contrails and other aviation climiate impacts, https://py.contrails.org.  

 

Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion. 

 

Integrating Breakthrough Energy’s contrail models into BlueSky’s ATC simulator. 

Simulating several contrail avoidance and mitigation flight optimization methods. 

Simulating different aircraft types and showcasing our contrail avoidance strategy working for each type and mission. 

Perform metric studies on each contrail avoidance strategy in relation to a large-scale, airspace network. 

Document our results in a paper and publish. 

Publish our code as open source for the community. 

 

After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps?  Where are the potential areas for transition?  What follow-on research do you anticipate?  

Next steps and Follow-on research: 

The adoption of contrail mitigation strategies is not widespread due to poor understanding of the greater impacts on existing aviation operations. We envision that more investigation in developing these optimal flight trajectories while avoiding contrail regions in the airspace is needed. In addition, it would be a benefit to perform studies on an air traffic management (ATM) system where we can study the aggregate effect of multiple aircraft interacting with each other while avoiding contrails. Other steps are in more research applying machine learning techniques such as reinforcement learning and using neural networks.  

 

Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation:  Three months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is not feasible technically.  You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot?  What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?  

One area where we can always pivot is in using another flight simulation software if BlueSky does not work as intended, and we can then try to integrate Breakthrough Energy’s models or create our own python contrail models based on what is currently published by the research community in scientific journals. The second is related to research and is naturally addressed due to the set-up of the proposal, we aim to investigate several methods for performing trajectory optimization while avoiding creating contrail. We may have to experiment with combining and mixing different flight optimization strategies and possibly consider hypothetical aircraft flight performance specifications to enable certain flight maneuvers. These in turn may provide data or insight into the design of newer aircraft types.

column1: Direct Measurement of Charge Transport Mechanisms in Electric Engine Cabling for Coronal Discharge Mitigation and Current Mapping
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT
FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE
INSTRUCTIONS
Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name.
Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger.
Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission and do not
need to be addressed in this template.
RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW
Title: Direct Measurement of Charge Transport Mechanisms in Electric Engine Cabling for Coronal
Discharge Mitigation and Current Mapping
1. Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated
benefits). Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant): What problem are you
solving? Has someone tried to solve this problem before? Where did they go wrong? What is
different about your approach? If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not? How
does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools/methods or state-of-the art
approaches? If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable?
Please include references/citations to back up claims where appropriate.
Aircraft have traditionally used 28 volts for power distribution, but newer aircraft are beginning to use
270 volts. The first all-electric aircraft are using voltages of up to about 500; however, designers who are
looking at megawatt-class electrified-propulsion systems for single-aisle airliners propose up to 3,000
volts and up to 2000 amps.
At such high currents, buckles in cabling and defects in the conductor material can cause unwanted heat
sinks that can destroy cables. Also, high voltages in the reduced air pressure at the cruising altitudes of
commercial aircraft could lead to a potentially hazardous phenomenon known as partial discharge.
Partial discharge occurs when a current breaches the gap between two points with a voltage differential
across or through an insulation (micron level or smaller in size). These gaps, or voids, are typically air
bubbles within the wire’s insulation that occur during wire/cable fabrication. The voltage differential
between the two points creates an electric field inside the gap polarizing the air molecules within. As the
electric field grows stronger, the molecules within the insulation gap are more apt to collide and ionize,
that is, to become either positively or negatively charged due to the loss or gain of an electron,
respectively. Mean free path is the average distance a particle travels before experiencing a collision
(i.e., the average distance any air molecule in the insulation gap will travel before hitting another.) At
high altitudes (low-pressure), despite fewer collisions, the longer mean free path allows the particles to
accelerate over a greater distance and collide with significantly greater kinetic energy. These higher
energy collisions are more likely to facilitate ionization. So new cabling designs and insulation systems
will have to be developed to avoid such hazards.
Current state-of-the-art for high-current measurement breaking the circuit or magnetic induction
(NDG.io). Breaking the circuit at such high currents can add unwanted high failure connection points.
Magnetic induction technology measures the induced current produced by the magnetic field generated 
from cable current. While this a much better way, the induction method is too inaccurate (not greater
than 2%, 40 amp difference at 2000 amps) for aircraft precision, much too bulky to get between cabling,
and are only rated up to 600 amps. Much less than many MW aircraft are projected to require. Even if
all these issues for both methods could be solved, both approaches average out spatial variations and
therefore cannot distinguish the contributions of bulk processes and edge effects or defect-induced
contributions, which are of crucial importance to understanding local current densities in the cabling at
different points.
Current state-of-the-art detection of partial/coronal discharge utilize micro-sonics. One technique uses a
mini network of micro-acoustic cameras to digitally visualize the minute vibrations from breaking the
insulation (Flir). These devices allow a spatial imaging of the conductor and where the breaking is
occurring visually. Another technique uses opto-acoustic imaging through fiber optic cabling (Optics11).
These devices detect the acoustic emission signals of partial discharges and tracks their evolution over
time with fiber optic partial discharge (PD) sensors. The measuring principle behind the fiber optic PD
sensor is based on the acoustic emission technology. Both technologies are a bit expensive yet work well
at detecting partial discharges in high-voltage environments. However, both technologies require microvibrations of an insulation breach or beginnings of the discharge to have anything to detect. By this time
the cable would already be compromised and in need in need of replacement. This may be fine for an
electrical ground station but not an aircraft 30,000 ft in the air full of passengers.
This project aims to create very low SWaP, nano/micro scale magnetic field sensor to measure these
minute magnetic fields and field gradients created by the moving charges in aircraft cabling using ionic
defects in Silicon Carbide (SiC) devices as atomic-scale magnetometers. These sensors would be able to
detect currently accurately, but also determine current vector and deliver spatial current density
measurements. This would allow for accurate hot-spot detection in conductors well before an issue is
created. In high-voltage situation these sensors could measure buildup of charge due to voids or points
in high voltage insulation via their minute magnetic field gradients produced through moving charges.
This would allow for detection of an incurring PD well before it has begun and will allow for diagnosis of
what stage it is in well before the breach. This technology works by using the electronic resonance of an
electron of an implanted defect in a biased-SiC device as an absolute magnetometer. The magnetic
fields are measured as a perturbation of the electronic resonance of the system where magnetic field
intensity, vector, and current density can be derived. This work is early TRL, however, we have built an
initial quantum magnetometry apparatus and have demonstrated the ability to achieve resonance. An
acceptance from this call would allow for completion to the next steps in device realization for future
clean, green aviation systems monitoring.
2. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon completion.
1. Charge transport models will be produced in COMSOL. 2. Characterization of Defects will be done
using Electrically Detected Magnetic Resonance (EDMR) spectroscopy. 3. Device sensitivity will be
determined experimentally, and the theoretical limit will be determined through modeling. 4.
Demonstration of minute magnetic field measurement via defects in SiC will be completed.
This work should be evaluated based on whether the system has the capability to measure minute
changes in magnetic fields, needed sensitivities are determined to measure precursors of partial
discharge and current density in conductors, and device theoretical sensitivity has been determined to
be able to meet these requirements when full device is realized.
3. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? Where are the potential areas
for transition? What follow-on research do you anticipate?
The next steps would be to optimize efficiency, speed, and sensitivity. Then, the miniaturization of the
non-chip laboratory components to chip-scale would come next. Some of this work would be done in
tandem. As of right now, we are adding a preamp on chip which would eliminate the need for off chip
preamplification.
The most reasonable transition for this work would be to be absorbed into a larger project focused on
electric engines and magnetic materials. The continuance of this work would not require huge amounts
of capital to continue so it would not burden a large or medium program at all.
Continued work in understanding the manifestation of partial discharge could be done. Also,
understanding of generation and dynamics of magnetic domain walls at nano scale in nanocrystalline
metal (NSM) materials could be done with these devices. These materials are essential to switching in
electric engines. Because of the much larger power and rate that would be needed for electric aviation
than cars, new more efficient switching materials are much needed for future aviation.
4. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation: Three months
into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial proposed approach is
not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining, how do you pivot? What
alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?
With 9 months still available, there would be much time to pivot. Each milestone has a contingency if
not providing results in a reasonable amount of time. The only real possibilities of issue would be
milestones 3 and 4. Characterization of the defect type would be initially done by Random Telegraph
Signal (RTS) analysis. The RTS is characterized by a well-defined current amplitude between the
high and low level and the average times in the high and low levels following a Poissonian distribution.
Spectroscopic information about the defect responsible for the observed RTS is usually extracted by
observing the dependence of the capture and emission time constants on temperature. If that has
issues, we will do to another method. The onset of RTS with increasing forward bias is accompanied by
the onset of electroluminescence (EL). We would employ a method to use photonics to observe the
luminescent response with change in bias. If there is an issue with this method, we would employ deeplevel transient spectroscopy (DTLS). This would require an augmentation of our setup so this would be
the last step to employ if all fails.
We need to be able to demonstrate the measurement of minute magnetic fields to calibrate detector,
demonstrate principle, and find theoretical limits to complete this year’s work. So, we will apply three
methods to ascertain the needed parameters. If one fails or does not work, we can average it out. The
lock-in output of the spin resonance signal is approximately the first derivative of the Lorentzian or
Gaussian broadened lineshape, which provides a linear response between the signal amplitude and
magnetic field near resonance. As such, the sensitivity of an EDMR-based sensor is proportional to the
signal linewidth and amplitude. The first method assumes an electrical shot-noise limited sensitivity,
which can be simply calculated using EDMR spectrum. The second method outlined in performs a FFT on
the time trace of the lock-in output at the zero-crossing point of the spin resonance response. The last
method applies a square wave modulated external magnetic field of alternating polarity and a histogram
of the lock-in output time trace is used to determine the standard deviation to calculate the sensitivity.
These methods would be applied in order.

column1: High-speed thermometry tool development to assess alternative propulsion technologies.
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT
FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE
INSTRUCTIONS
Please do not include your name or other contact information in this form or in the file name.
Please limit the submission to 3 pages with 11 pt font or bigger.
Answer the questions below. Requested resources will be addressed in the form submission
and do not need to be addressed in this template.
RESPOND TO PROMPTS BELOW
Title: High-speed thermometry tool development to assess alternative propulsion technologies
1. Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated
benefits). Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant): What problem are you
solving? Has someone tried to solve this problem before? Where did they go wrong? What
is different about your approach? If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why
not? How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools/methods or stateof-the art approaches? If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is
unattainable? Please include references/citations to back up claims where appropriate.
Obtaining temperature measurements within the high-temperature and high-pressure
environments of aviation gas turbine test rigs are extremely challenging due to their harsh
environment. Traditional instrumentation such as thermocouple probes do not typically survive
within such environments or are limited to wall-based measurements only. Laser-based, nonintrusive measurements are considered to be ideal within such environments and indeed their
developments within research laboratories have intensified over the past 2-3 decades. Nevertheless,
quantitative measurements within such environments often create their own challenges. An example
of such a measurement challenge would be solid tracer particles introduced into the flow for particle
imaging velocimetry or phosphor thermography fouling windows, thereby limited the life of the
experimental hardware and reducing the utility of such measurements.
Molecular-based measurements on the other hand, especially those that rely on the gas-phase
spectroscopic properties of targeted species, are ideally suited for such environments as they do not
require a physical probe or tracer particles. Among the different measurement tools available within
this category, the proposed work would develop high-speed (10-100 kHz), spatially resolved, 2D
planar temperature measurements of specific targeted molecules using planar laser-induced
fluorescence (PLIF). The targeted molecules would primarily be flame gas radicals naturally present
within the combustion chamber and downstream sections of alternative propulsion systems for
aviation. Such measurements can provide particularly rich insight within the flame zone, as different
radicals such as OH for hydrogen-air propulsion systems or NH for ammonia-air propulsion systems
can be targeted. Temperature measurements within such environments have the potential to provide
crucial insight into the formation of nitric oxide (NO) and other key pollutants, especially in terms of
their spatial distribution and temporal evolution. Furthermore, the NO molecule can also be directly
targeted for measurements of temperature and perhaps concentration using planar laser-induced 
fluorescence if enough NO were to be present in the flame gas (> 100 ppm). These temperature
measurements would be used by engine designers and combustion engineers performing CFD
simulations. Time-resolved measurements would enable the validation of modern computer codes,
such as large eddy simulations (LES).
The proposed work leverages recent developments in burst-mode laser and optical parametric
oscillator technology, including those supported by recent NASA SBIR and NSTGRO awards, to
facilitate such a temperature measurement at high repetition-rates. The state-of-the-art for such
measurements, especially within harsh practical environments, requires using two complex laser
systems simultaneously while being limited to a repetition-rate of 10 Hz. In contrast, the proposed
work utilizes the wavelength flexibility of the burst-mode laser with the wavelength tunability of the
optical parametric oscillator to provide a two-wavelength temperature measurement at 1,000-10,000
times the standard repetition rate. This proposal heavily leverages the state-of-the-art laser and
camera systems recently acquired by researchers in the Advanced Measurements and Data Systems
Branch within the NASA Langley Research Directorate. By utilizing the recent technology investments
already undertaken by NASA, the current proposal can provide critical support to improve the TRL of
this measurement technology so that it can be applied within areas of critical ARMD needs such as
green aviation. NASA programs supporting the next generation designs of gas turbine engines, along
with government collaborators such as the Department of Energy and industry partners such as
General Electric, would benefit from this temperature measurement tool development.
2. Describe the anticipated milestones and how your work should be evaluated upon
completion.
The primary objectives of the proposal research is to demonstrate spatially resolved, 2D planar
temperature measurements of selected species at a repetition-rate of 10-100 kHz for burst durations
of 2-10 ms. Nominal field-of-view for the 2D measurement plane is approximately 100 mm x 100 mm,
with a typical spatial resolution on the order of 0.1 mm. This effort strongly leverages recent SBIR
efforts supported by researchers in the Advanced Measurements and Data Systems Branch at NASA
Langley. The first task for the project would be to complete a literature review on two-line
temperature measurements for candidate molecules within flames such as OH, NH, and NO. Based
on this literature review, one molecule will be down selected for the Year 1 investigation. Work in
the laboratory will be performed for the rest of the year, with the key intermediary reporting
milestones being characterization of the measurement sub-systems and initial temperature
measurements. An end-of-year report would provide a summary of the entire effort for the project,
including data for high-speed temperature measurements with estimated uncertainties within a labscale environment. The end of year report would also provide an evaluation of the measurement
capability for optically accessible combustion test rigs and the proposed way forward to further
develop this research for deployment within an engine-relevant configuration. A summary of the
anticipated milestones is provided in the table below.
Month Task Milestone
3
Summarize literature review supporting down-selection of target
flame radial (OH, NO, or NH) for Year 1 investigation.
Slide Package
6
Report performance of measurement sub-systems, particularly laser
system, for Year 1 investigation.
Slide Package
9
Report initial thermometry measurements of a down-selected flame
radical using the high-speed laser system.
Slide Package
12 Summarize temperature measurements with estimated
uncertainties and propose way forward to further develop research. Report
3. After this work is completed what do you envision as the next steps? Where are the
potential areas for transition? What follow-on research do you anticipate?
The proposed research effort is highly crosscutting as it focuses on the measurement tool
development for high-speed temperature measurements within alternative propulsion systems.
Following successful Year 1 demonstration efforts, Year 2+ efforts may focus on the further
development of the tool through application within increasingly realistic environments relevant to the
combustor or downstream sections of an alternative propulsion system. The grand challenge of such
development efforts would be a demonstration of such measurements within an optically accessible
gas turbine test rig at the Glenn Research Center operating with hydrogen-air, ammonia-air, or
another alternative aviation fuel. The windowed test rigs at Glenn are well suited for these
measurements, as optical access from two orthogonal windows are typically required for PLIF.
Indeed, researchers such as R.J. Locke and Y.R. Hicks from Glenn have performed laser-based
measurements within such facilities over the years. However, neither high-speed PLIF flow
visualization nor PLIF thermometry has been performed at these facilities to the best of my
knowledge. The work could also be extended in future years to study contrail formation in sooting
flames, which would utilize other laser-based diagnostics methods such as laser-induced
incandescence (LII) while leveraging the same burst-mode laser system.
4. Address the following scenario from your perspective as PI. Hypothetical situation: Three
months into this work, your team of subject matter experts determines that the initial
proposed approach is not feasible technically. You still have 9 months of funding remaining,
how do you pivot? What alternative approaches or methods would you pursue?
The planned effort of detailed literature review and down-selection of the target flame molecule
provides a perfect opportunity to evaluate the technical feasibility of the proposed approach. For the
proposed effort we plan to use a two-wavelength thermometry approach for 10-100 kHz temperature
measurements. Such an approach requires two laser wavelengths to be carefully selected and may
limit the dynamic range of the measurement. In the event that this approach would be deemed not
technically feasible, one potential pivot would be to incorporate a four-wavelength thermometry
approach. Such an approach would leverage the developments in burst-mode laser architecture
recently performed by an NSTGRO Fellow who is part of the Advanced Measurements and Data
Systems Branch at NASA Langley. In short, the alternative approach would modify the laser
architecture to provide a group of four laser pulses at four different wavelengths, rather than a pair
of laser pulses at two different wavelengths, while maintaining the overall measurement repetitionrate of 10-100 kHz. Two different measurement schemes could be utilized based on this approach:
1) a four-line temperature measurement probing four different absorption transitions or 2) a fourcolor temperature measurement where two of the laser wavelengths correspond to the peak of two
different transitions and the other two wavelengths are slightly detuned from their respective peaks.
The flexibility of the laser system that we propose to use in this work enables one to easily pivot
towards more technically feasible approaches as the need potentially arises.

column1: Solid-State Li-Air Batteries (SLAB): The Holy Grail for Safe and Sustainable Electric Aviation
column4:
TRANSFORMATIONAL TOOLS & TECHNOLOGIES PROJECT 

FY24 GREEN AVIATION PROPOSAL TEMPLATE 

Solid-State Li-Air Batteries (SLAB): The Holy Grail for Safe and Sustainable Electric Aviation 

Provide a description of the work (describe problem, objectives, approach, and anticipated benefits).  Address any or all of the following questions (if relevant): What problem are you solving?  Has someone tried to solve this problem before?  Where did they go wrong?  What is different about your approach?  If no one has attempted to solve this problem before, why not?  How does your proposed work transform current capabilities, tools/methods or state-of-the art approaches?  If successful, what does your proposed work enable that currently is unattainable? Please include references/citations to back up claims where appropriate.  

 

Description of Proposed Work: 

NASA is seeking sustainable solutions for aviation to achieve zero-emission beyond 2040. Electrification of aircraft is critical to achieve this goal. A key component for electric aviation, if not the most important one, is the energy storage device that is not only capable of powering the aircraft (i.e., high energy, high power), but also safe to fly. LI-air batteries are widely considered the most energy-dense energy storage platform yet the most challenging to develop. A Li-air battery pack has potential to achieve ultrahigh specific energy >1000 Wh/kg that is unattainable with any other battery chemistry. Successful development would be transformational and may enable 737-type short haul or even long haul electric aircraft. 

While NASA has several previous projects on Li-air batteries, they ended with either the lack of required performance metrics or transition opportunities. There has been recent refocus on aviation batteries, with substantial development in energy storage materials and deeper understanding in safe, high energy battery concepts. We herein propose, as a seedling effort, the re-invention toward a new generation of Li-air batteries. The objective of this proposal is to demonstrate the feasibility of combined use of solid electrolyte with holey graphene air cathode for high specific energy Li-oxygen batteries and to project a credible path toward the full development of a 1000 Wh/kg battery pack. The key aspects of our approach are: 

Explore the use of solid electrolyte instead of conventional liquid electrolyte in the battery cells. As such, the Li-air batteries will become non-flammable. 

With the use of oxygen from Earth atmosphere as the cathodic reactant, Li-air batteries are intrinsically the most sustainable option among all battery platforms.  

With our proven holey graphene air cathode platform (developed by PI) ultrahigh specific energy beyond 1000 Wh/kg at the pack level may be achievable.
